name: Der Präsident. –
text: I declare the session suspended on Thursday 9 July 2015 to be resumed.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: Ladies and gentlemen! These days, Europe is facing a historic test. Hundreds of thousands of people are seeking protection from war and persecution. In desperation, families and their children cross the Mediterranean in rubber dinghies. People camp in train stations, force their way through barbed wire, and deliver themselves to merciless smugglers. Many lose their lives – men, women, children who suffocate in trucks or drown in the Mediterranean. As more and more people make their way to Europe and more and more people lose their lives, we must realise that we are not tackling the challenges with walls, with isolation or deterrence. I would like to remind you of something: a few days ago, the so-called Islamic State irretrievably destroyed cultural assets in Palmyra. However, we have almost forgotten that the director of this museum in Palmyra was publicly beheaded by this terrorist gang a few weeks ago. The people who come to us are fleeing these criminals, and they are not deterred by seas and walls in their desperation. We will not respond to this global challenge with national measures or national selfishness. We need a common asylum and refugee policy in response to this global challenge. President Juncker will present a series of measures, including a proposal for a permanent emergency mechanism, for the distribution of refugees here in plenary in Strasbourg on Wednesday. And then, ladies and gentlemen, the question for all of us – not only here, but in all the institutions of the Union – is the question of which Union we actually want. A Union of all against all or a Union of solidarity. The task we face is great. It is perhaps the greatest challenge we face here as a current generation of politicians. In all the debates – on quotas, Dublin III or Schengen – I ask all of us not to forget that we are talking about people and very bitter fates. The people who come to us come because they believe in us and in our values. But the dramatic events of recent weeks have also unsettled many people in the EU Member States. I would also like to say to people who put a lot of questions to us: not everyone who asks a critical question is against refugees. We must take seriously the concerns and needs of the citizens of our Union, because the problems are visibly great. I would like to thank all the people in our Union, the countless citizens who provide water and food to exhausted refugees everywhere at railway stations, on holiday beaches, in many other places, to give them clothes, to toys for their children, and who come forward to volunteer in refugee shelters. This humanity must be our guiding principle so that the terrible image of little Aylan Kurdi, which I believe has burned into all of us, never repeats itself in Europe. (Applause)

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the report by Cristian-Silviu Buoi on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No. 1007/2009 on trade in seal products (COM(2015)0045 - C8-0037/2015 - 2015/0028 (COD)) (A8-0186/2015).

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, please allow me first to thank my colleagues, the shadow rapporteurs, for their work on this file, and the Commission and the Council for their cooperation. Without all the good work and support received, we would not have reached an agreement in June under the Latvian Presidency, bringing the EU basic regulation into line with the World Trade Organisation (WTO) ruling. In 2009, within the basic regulation, the EU opted for a ban in trade in seal products, with two main exceptions: products from hunts conducted by Inuit and other indigenous communities (the IC exception) and products from hunts conducted for the sole purpose of the sustainable management of marine resources on a small scale and non-profit basis (the MRM exception). The aim of this Regulation is to ensure that products derived from seals hunted for commercial purposes are no longer found on the EU market. The Seal Regulation and its implementing act were challenged by Canada and Norway in the WTO. The final rulings of the WTO panel and the WTO Appellate Body were adopted on 18 June 2014 by the WTO Dispute Settlement Body on 18 June 2014, disapproving of one of the two exceptions, namely the MRM exception. Canada and the European Union had agreed that the reasonable period of time to implement the recommendations and rulings should be 16 months from the date of adoption. That period expires on 18 October 2015. The European Commission did not adopt its proposal for amending the current Regulation on trade in seal products until 6 February 2015, bringing the current legislation into line with the WTO rulings by renouncing the MRM exception and keeping the reinforced Inuit exception. Although I very much appreciate that not all MEPs and Member States agree with the deletion of the MRM exception, I am very pleased to announce that the final agreement reached is in line with the WTO rulings. As regards the Inuit exception, the consolidated text encompasses a new set of criteria under which seal products resulting from hunts conducted by Inuit and other indigenous communities could be placed on the market – a clear reference to the needs of such communities to provide food and income to support their life and a sustainable livelihood. We amended the Commission’s proposal, taking into consideration in particular the right to self-determination of the Inuit and other indigenous communities. The proposal was amended so as to reiterate that seal hunting is an integral part of the culture and identity of the Inuit communities, making a major contribution to their subsistence, providing food and income to support their families and small communities, and preserving and continuing the traditional existence of the community and the cultural heritage of bartering.  In the report I have proposed a new article, namely 5a, referring to the need for citizens to be properly informed about seal products placed on the EU market which originate in Inuit and other indigenous communities, and that those seal products are lawful in origin. Last, but not least, as regards Article 7 on reporting, the agreed text asks the Commission to report by the end of 2019 on the implementation of the new rules, paying particular attention to the impact of those rules on the Inuit community. I look forward to hearing what the Commission, the Council and, of course, my colleagues have to say.

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, first and foremost, let me thank and congratulate the rapporteur, Mr Buşoi, and his colleagues for their commitment and thorough and also speedy work on the Commission proposal to amend the basic regulation on trade in seal products.  The amendment had become necessary after the WTO ruling in June last year. While the ruling upheld the EU ban on marketing of seal products, the WTO concluded that the exceptions provided by the EU for Inuit and other indigenous communities and for maritime resource management had some discriminatory effects. We believe that the constructive cooperation between the institutions has led to a very good result. It will enable the EU to comply with its international obligations under the WTO by the very challenging deadline which we were given for implementation and which will expire next month (on 18 October, to be precise). This is a very important step for the credibility of the EU, as one of the main users of the WTO Dispute Settlement Mechanism, in implementing its WTO obligations.  We are very pleased to have come to the end of this process of amending our seal regime and making it compliant with WTO rules. It is a politically sensitive issue for many involved, and we are satisfied that a balanced compromise has been reached.  Throughout the process, the Commission has engaged with all the relevant stakeholders and also those Member States particularly concerned with the proposal. We believe that this dialogue has been very constructive and that its results are reflected in the outcome of this process. The final result upholds the ban with a meaningful indigenous-communities exception and addresses all the shortcomings identified by the WTO, such as the need for removal of the marine resource management exception. It provides for a balanced approach between fulfilling the EU’s international trade obligations and addressing the legitimate concerns of Inuit communities and Member States affected by the changes. Furthermore, some specific requests by the European Parliament were taken on board in the compromise text, such as the provisions requiring the Commission to regularly evaluate the regulation, as well as to inform the public about the ban and its exception.  The Commission has made it clear that we fully support the outcome as far as the substance is concerned. On some procedural issues, changes made to the Commission’s proposal in the course of the negotiations require us to make two statements relating to horizontal institutional issues, which we have forwarded to the European Parliament services for recording in the minutes. Firstly, on the use of the no-opinion clause for the adoption of implementing acts, and, secondly, on the use of the comitology procedure for issuing technical guidance notes. Commission’s Statements on: 1)  The use of the no-opinion clause for the adoption of implementing acts  ‘The Commission underlines that it is contrary to the letter and to the spirit of Regulation 182/2011 (OJ L 55 of 28.2.2011, p. 13) to invoke Article 5 § 4, subparagraph 2, point b) in a systematic manner. Recourse to this provision must respond to a specific need to depart from the rule of principle which is that the Commission may adopt a draft implementing act when no opinion is delivered. Given that it is an exception to the general rule established by Article 5 § 4 recourse to subparagraph 2, point b), cannot be simply seen as a ‘discretionary power’ of the Legislator, but must be interpreted in a restrictive manner and thus must be justified.’ 2) The use of comitology procedure for issuance of technical guidance notes  ‘The Commission notes that the co-legislators have included in the final compromise text a provision according to which the non-binding guidance notes under Article 3(6) will be adopted by examination procedure. The Commission is of the view that the adoption of non-binding guidelines by the Commission should not be subject to the control mechanism under Regulation 182/2011 since the Commission has its own autonomous right under the Treaty to issue such guidance. Considering the urgent need to meet the WTO requirements and deadlines the Commission does not oppose the solution favoured by the co-legislators in this particular file. This is without prejudice to the negotiations of the inter-institutional agreement on better law-making, as well as the position the Commission will take on similar matters in the future.’

name: Bendt Bendtsen
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on International Trade. Madam President! The 2009 regulation made it illegal to sell sealskin products in the EU. The legislation has proved to be a disaster for the Inuit and indigenous peoples of the Arctic. One of the two exceptions was that the Inuit should be exempted and that there should be no consequences for the Inuit. The Commission did not receive an impact assessment! Nevertheless, the text will now be tightened. It's sloppy!  All the figures have shown that the 2009 legislation had a huge damage to the Inuit and that a profession has been smashed as they could not dispose of their skins. Stocks in Greenland have been left with up to 135 000 skins, which are in surplus stocks, which means that indigenous people have been removed from their profession as hunters and turned them into social clients.  We have to note that it is a long way from Brussels to North Greenland. I would like to thank parliament's negotiators today and Mr Barroso. I would like to thank Mr Buşoi for the fact that the legislation has improved much. Unfortunately, we cannot thank the Commission on this matter. I am very pleased that the Commission is now being given an information obligation which it did not take care of under the previous legislation.

name: Janusz Wojciechowski
text: author of the draft opinion of the Committee on Agriculture and Rural Development. – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab The Committee on Agriculture welcomes the report. We are in favour of restrictions on trade in seal products because of the cruelty of hunting.  It is recalled, as Mahatma Gandhi once said, that the level of development of civilization and its moral development can be assessed after animals are treated. Cruelty to animals, the cruelty of these hunts are not only the suffering of animals, but it is also an insult to human dignity, because cruelty offends our dignity in the twenty-first century. Therefore, these restrictions are necessary, although we must also understand the specific situation of these traditional Inuit communities and exceptional solutions must be maintained for them. This is what this regulation is about, which we are debating today, which is why I am in favour of it.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I, too, would of course like to thank Mr Cristian Buoi for his work on this draft implementation for the implementation of the WTO decision. There can be no doubt that the European Union, the European internal market, is subjecting its legislation to the requirements of the WTO, so I am very grateful that this has also been achieved so quickly in the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection.  However, we are faced with the question of how we can reconcile environmental protection, animal welfare on the one hand and other economic and political constraints in the future. The exception we have found takes sufficient account of these balance reasons. We must ensure that the legal possibilities that have remained within the framework of this WTO-compliant implementation process remain acceptable in the end, so that legislation has the value that we actually want to give it. In this respect, Commissioner, we will have to see how this legislation will ultimately have a concrete effect, but the implementation process on the part of the European Parliament has been successful. Thank you very much!

name: Christel Schaldemose
text: for the S&D Group. Madam President! Ladies and gentlemen! We are voting this week on the final proposal to amend the European ban on imports and exports of seal products. We are doing so as a result of the WTO decision that came about.  The Socialist Group supports the result of the negotiations that has been achieved. We do it because we think it's good. Indeed, it strikes a very good balance between three important considerations: we are complying with the WTO decision and hence the EU's international obligations;  I am very pleased that, in the outcome we have negotiated, we are instructing the Commission to inform both the public and the authorities that inuit seal products are legal on the European market. It is important for their livelihoods. We are also here in this House to constantly monitor the consequences of the legislation by means of the reports that the Commission is to provide to us, and I think that is important. Finally, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mr Schroeder, for his excellent report. I would like to say to Mr Buşoi that we have had a very good and constructive cooperation which has led us to get this very good result!

name: Daniel Dalton
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Madam President, for the ECR, WTO compliance was the most important point and, as a result, we can therefore support the deletion of the MRM exemption. It was also vitally important for us that we clarified the wording around the Inuit exemption so that they cannot only eat the seals that they hunt, but also make a living from those seal products. This is vitally important for the survival of Inuit communities, particularly in Greenland, where there is no other source of income. We have also upheld the original seal ban and the EU’s commitment to strong animal welfare legislation from the original ban a few years ago. From the ECR point of view that is also very important. Finally, in line with the ECR commitment for better regulation, I think it is vitally important that we have now put requirements on the Commission to study the effect of these changes, and particularly the effect of the changes in relation to the previous legislation so that we can go forward with better legislation in the future. So from the ECR Group, we supported the Commission proposal, we are supportive of the agreement and we think this is a good step for the future.

name: Kaja Kallas
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, this legislative report was aimed at aligning what is currently legally possible in the EU with the WTO ruling, but something that seems very standard and harmless can get more difficult when it is about cultural traditions in some small parts of Europe. The proposed Maritime Resource Management exception, which was in line with the WTO ruling, was not about reopening the ban on the trade in seal products, but the ban will remain and I, of course, support it. The reality is that, in Nordic and Baltic countries, there are still licenses issued for hunting seals. There are some cultural traditions: in Estonia, for instance, there are 50 licenses granted for this type of hunting and this number is not likely to increase. The fact that they cannot make any use of what they hunt does not contribute to making people aware of it and value it, as they just end up disregarding it. So I stress that this is not about animal welfare, but about the sustainable use of resources. I hope that the Commission will look at current practices and see what is the best way to ensure that, while respecting the ban, we still allow traditions to carry on in the smartest way, since legislation that allows hunting but either leads to a waste of resources or creates a grey economy is not good legislation.

name: Anja Hazekamp
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. – It's a historic moment. Finally, the interests of animals count fully. For the first time, short-sighted commercial interests do not automatically outweigh animal welfare. The Party for Animals therefore welcomes the world trade organisation's ruling. And let there be no misunderstanding: if there is one product that should be banned now, it is seal fur. Because every year hundreds of thousands of seals are bludgeoned to death in a bloody way. These are often very young animals, less than three months old. Babies who are often skinned in full consciousness. And why? Just to make money off their fur. Seal fur is an unnecessary fashion product for which newborn animals are slaughtered in a horrible way. And there's no excuse for that.  That is precisely why Europe decided in 2009 to restrict imports and trade. And of the two exceptions, unfortunately, one remains: the hunt by the Inuit. But if we want to preserve traditional culture, we should not encourage the Inuit to convert their products into money and hunt even more for babies rather than adult animals.  I also believe that European agricultural subsidies should be abolished.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – First of course, sincere congratulations to the rapporteurs and to thank our colleagues for showing a great degree of efficiency in making compromises on a matter that is, of course, very challenging, but at the same time very important. The regulation prohibiting the sale of seal products is, of course, also very important for our group, as its primary and primary purpose from the outset is also to protect the animals for which we are actively committed. Of course, this regulation was also necessary because of the requirements of the World Trade Organisation. What emerged as a problem during the coordination itself was that some groups had shown an exceptional interest in finding as many exceptions as possible in this regulation, which would make this regulation more lax and thus, of course, not to achieve the objective that we have pursued throughout the negotiations. I am pleased that these attempts have been unsuccessful in some way, and we have already rejected these attempts on the IMCO Committee itself, which has also been supported in the negotiations with the Council.  I believe that the so-called MRM exception was the most problematic in the existing regulation, which is why we have worked to erase it, which we have succeeded in. Above all, it will be important that this regulation also comes to life in practice. The Commission will, of course, play an important role here, which will also have to carry out the evaluation of these rules and, above all, whether or not there are still infringements despite this regulation and if it occurs, of course, to take appropriate action. (The speaker agreed to accept the question raised by raising the blue card (Rule 162(8)).

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D)
text: blue card question. – Mr President, in recent speeches we have talked about the protection of animals. However, I would like the European Parliament to also take account of small traditions, as has been appreciated here with the Inuit exemption. However, we also have a few very small islands in the Baltic Sea, which also have a thousand-year tradition of using seal leather. If it is said that this is the protection of animals, then this does not prevent the hunting of animals, nor does it prevent the rescue of those caught in the nets. This prevents only the commercial use of seal skin. At its craziest, this station goes so that once the seal is shot on the rock, it is no longer intense to take it off and use that leather while losing the tradition profession.

name: Igor Šoltes (Verts/ALE)
text: answer to the question raised by raising the blue card. – I think that this regulation achieves the greatest possible compromise, so that, of course, this regulation also respects tradition. Above all, I think of the traditional hunting of both inuats, Eskimov and groups, of course, who make a living through the traditional way of catching whales. And what has already been heard today, products can also be in free circulation for the survival of the Inuites and Eskimov. It is clear, however, that an overly vague definition could provide for such exceptions and abuses, which, of course, could also be very damaging to the seals.

name: Margot Parker
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Madam President, whilst I appreciate that changes to the legislation on seal products are based on World Trade Organisation recommendations and serve the intention of better welfare and the protection of seals, I am deeply concerned about the impact that this will have on the Inuit communities whom these changes will also largely affect. Notably, my concerns lie with the lack of impact assessments carried out prior to tomorrow’s vote. In 2009, when the exemption for Inuit communities was first established, a key priority of Parliament was to ensure that negative impacts would not occur for the Inuit communities, who for hundreds of years have relied on seal hunting as a means of providing food, warmth and economic prosperity. However, like many things that come from this Parliament, this was not the end result. Recent figures from Greenland have shown that the ban has had an overwhelmingly negative effect on those communities.  To ensure that continued or additional negative impacts from future changes do not take place, we must ensure that the livelihoods of the Inuit are held in the same high regard as the welfare of the seals. With this in mind, it is therefore imperative that the welfare of the group is not sacrificed one for the other.

name: Franz Obermayr
text: Mr President, I would like to like to take a iendled with the ENF Group. Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Sustainability and responsible use of natural resources are our guiding values, but as far as the previous ban on trade in seal products was concerned, we did not follow these guide values. As an example, I would like to mention the situation in Greenland: twelve million seals populate the waters of the island, and the indigenous peoplethere hunt around 150 000 animals a year.  Biologists estimate that the annual hunt would be sustainable even for 500,000 animals. However, it is not the increase in catches that is important, but the sensible use of the products from this hunt. For indigenous peoples of this region, only seals remain as vitamin C and protein suppliers. Seals have been hunted by the local population since time it was, and there is no substitute for their nutritional value! And without the European Union's markets, thousands of skins from this hunt have been burned or otherwise disposed of, and this, ladies and gentlemen, has nothing to do with the responsible use of natural resources.  However, we must take care that a purely commercial hunt for these animals does not take place again. And we should also take a closer look at the Baltic Sea, which also limits exceptions. That is why I agree with Greenpeace spokesman Jon Burgwald, who said that we need to significantly increase our efforts to make clear to EU consumers the differences between sustainable hunting by indigenous peoples and commercial hunting.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to congratulate the rapporteur first. I support his compromise. Personally, I believe that the ban on trade in seal products is moral and correct, that animals suffered greatly in traditional killings. On the other hand, it has already been made clear that there is one exception to this ban. I would like to state in general that if a legal prohibition has an exception, it often causes problems in practice, often such a ban is circumvented or interpreted in various ways. I am a little concerned when I look at the exception granted to the Inuit that it contains so many conditions and that it is something so complex that it will be up to the European Commission – and I call on the Commissioner – to monitor very closely whether that exception is being respected.  It must be said that the Inuit are not given scope for commercial trade in these goods. It is clearly written that it is supposed to be hunting, which is rather for non-commercial purposes. That the hunt should be carried out humanely, etc. It will therefore be for the Commission to monitor this so that the exception to the legal prohibition is respected and that the interest of animals, on the one hand, and the interest of the traditional Inuit community, on the other, is really balanced.  So I ask the Commission not to end the whole thing with the adoption of this legislation, but to monitor whether what has been provided for as an exception is being closely respected.  (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Franz Obermayr (ENF)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I could tell the previous speaker that he is very concerned, because exceptions could always lead to something tearing down here that we do not want. However, he missed two points for me. On the one hand, how does he imagine that we will retain the foundations or the possibilities of traditional food procurement for indigenous peoples? Apart from controversy, I believe that we have the recognition here that seal meat serves this purpose. The second is whether he would consider it wise and sustainable, as has happened so far, for the blankets, the skins of these animals to be burned, disposed of and discarded.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – We are not in a dispute, I am merely drawing attention, as a lawyer, to the fact that, in my opinion, the exception is legislatively complicated and that it is now up to the European Commission, when the exception is effective, to check whether it is being respected. I say that, as a politician, I respect that the Inuit community should have the right to hunt seals and to have that right within the framework of its traditional functioning and its traditional livelihood. But I also note that the Commission will have to continue to monitor whether all aspects of this authorisation, this exception, are respected. Whether hunting is humane etc. We're not ideologically in contention.

name: Evelyne Gebhardt (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her In 2009, we enforced the general ban on the sale of products for commercialisation, and that was a good thing. However, we have rightly made an exception for the Inuit, because we know very well that this is part of their livelihood.  Without this hunt and without the products they have from this hunt, they simply cannot survive, and therefore we cannot simply say that we cannot make this exception, or that it is too complicated, or it is too difficult to control. No, we must respect the fact that these people also need a livelihood, and we have said, yes, we must do so. The second exception was a more difficult exception: the conservation of marine resources, what can be understood by it all? What can be hidden behind it?  I think it is a good thing that we have now completely removed this exception. We have done a good job of doing this, and I think we can vote in favour of this compromise tomorrow, because it really sets the right tone, and it has also been taken into board that, in the future, we will once again check how this will actually affect the Inuit, because we do not want to abolish its livelihood. Thanks!

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for I would like to start by saying that something that is good in the WTO decision is that, for the first time, animal welfare is mentioned in its actions. It can put rye in the back when we discuss what trade globally should look like. That is why something is very good. Another good thing about our process is that we have made exceptions so that the Inuit can continue their millennia-old cultural deed and something that is a basis for continuing their culture and economy. What's bad is that we can't make a difference between hunting and hunting. In Sweden, for example, we have strictly regulated hunting of seals. Now, however, Parliament is told that if you have hunted seals perfectly legally to protect fish stocks or to protect small fishing activities, the seal should be burned or dumped in the lake. If we have been given legal and strict regulation of the possibility of shooting seals, we will of course also have to deal with the resource that the seal represents.

name: Christofer Fjellner (PPE).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for So now we are going to ban trade in seal products, including ethically and sustainably hunted seals from Sweden, for example. Let me be clear, because this is stupid. We will continue to hunt seals, increasingly seals, which is something the Commission itself acknowledges in the same breath as it proposes to ban trade in it. Stocks are increasing. Ordinary, responsible game management requires us to hunt seals, but now we're going to kill the seals and then discard them, burn up, bury. What now becomes law is downright unethical. The new ban is justified by protests from the World Trade Organisation, but there were several ways of addressing these problems, as we in the Trade Committee pointed out.  Let me just point out three solutions that are better than this one, which is the worst of all solutions. The ban could have been completely abolished. One could have banned the trade in unethically hunted seals. Or it could have been decided that the ban should not apply to seals that have been hunted for purposes other than commercial purposes. This proposal is completely unreasonable. We just introduced a ban on catching fish and throwing it dead back into the sea, but with this requirement, it becomes, in practice, law to do the same with seals. That's why we should do it all over again – tear up, do new, because this is not how we can have it.

name: Jens Nilsson (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Sustainable management of marine resources is incredibly important, not least in the Baltic Sea, which is a sensitive inland sea. The MRM exception that has existed disappears with this decision, which is extremely unfortunate. The number of grey seals in the Baltic Sea is constantly increasing. We must continue to shoot seals in order to have ecological balance in the Baltic Sea.  The problem that I have raised in committee all along when I oppose the removal of this derogation is that it is difficult to get hunters when we are going to hunt seals. The county administrative boards in Sweden, which are responsible for making decisions and ensuring that we hunt down the seal that needs to be hunted, already have difficulty in finding serious hunters. Because serious hunters want to take advantage of what they shed, not least in this case seal skins, which can actually be traded. What will be the problem is that we do not get hunters for the hunting that we have to carry out. The problem then is that we can't call in the army to shoot seals. What will happen? My worst case scenario is that we get a number of event companies around the Baltic Sea that offer weekends where you get to shoot wild animals without having to take responsibility for finding out. This is a bad decision.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Madam President, considering the final rulings in the dispute settlement body of the World Trade Organisation on 18 June 2014 defining the Inuit and MRM exceptions as an arbitrary and unjustifiable discrimination, we have no choice but to adopt an amendment to the current regulation on trade in seal products in order to bring the EU regulation into compliance with the World Trade Organisation rules. As stated by the World Trade Organisation, the EU did not address animal welfare in Inuit hunts given that the overall objective of the regulation was based on animal welfare concerns, and the ambiguity of some of its conditions could lead to the use of the exception for hunts in ways which should in reality be characterised as primarily undertaken for commercial purposes. I therefore strongly agree on the links made in the proposal between the use of the exception and respect for animal welfare. This provides for a mechanism that could help prevent its misuse.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the European Union's main priority must be to protect species at risk of extinction as a result of poaching, as is the case with whales and seals. Trade in seal products has led to the extermination of the species and should therefore be banned. That must be the rule. The only exception we could accept is the hunting traditionally served on Greenland by the Inuit Community. But here too we must lay down strict conditions. Firstly, hunting must be carried out in a traditional way by the Community, secondly, hunting for seals must contribute to the survival of the Inuit Community, thirdly, hunting must not be carried out for commercial purposes, and fourthly, hunting must be carried out in such a way as to reduce the pain and suffering of the animals hunted.  Under these conditions, there can be effective protection of seals at global level and, at the same time, the conditions and conditions for the survival and self-determination of the Inuit Community, as seal hunting is a source of life and part of the cultural tradition for these inhabitants of Western Greenland. Thanks.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to make it clear right from the outset that there is a clear distinction to be made between what traditional fishing means for Inuites and the traditional life of native communities from what excessive fishing or even burning of seals means, or in some way the traffic of seal goods that are certainly not necessary. However, regardless of what today's topic is, and I want to stand in solidarity with all that is happening around these animals, I want to emphasize another problem that we are not talking about here, and I come as you know from Croatia, and I want to talk about the problems that exist in the Western Balkans where they disappear, literally rare animals like big wild cats disappear, bears are killed , wolves are killed and foxes are killed, all for trade, and I think the topic also needs to be sensitised to the public, and I expect the Commission to do something about it.

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D).
text: – It should be emphasized that the majority of Portuguese citizens do not agree with the hunting of wild mammals. The capture and death of pinipedes is far from consensual. However, another characteristic of Europeans is tolerance and respect for difference, with other subsistence cultures that have traditionally hunted and used seal products in a sustainable way. It will be up to the informed consumer to decide and choose which products seem to be most suitable. One thing is the capture of some animals in a geographical and social context in which man is part of the ecosystem of these same animals and another, completely different, is the mass, unsustainable and culturally unjustified capture of cetaceans by industrial forces or by the simple practice of bloody rituals. European citizens know the difference and the European Commission and this Parliament has also been able to mirror that distinction. (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Fredrick Federley (ALDE)
text: question ("blue card"). "I think the commitment that exists in here is very, very big for the Inuit. However, we must also remember that in the Nordic countries – in Norway, In Sweden, Finland and Åland – we have an Arctic tradition. Since the ice retreated and humans and animals were able to move to our part of the world, we've been chasing seals.  What are we going to say to those fishermen who have their entire fish stocks eaten, because of the ecological imbalance that arises when we get too much seal? What are we going to say to anyone who has the legal right to shoot seals with strict rules, but who then has to burn it or put it on land or sink the seal into the sea instead of actually doing something sensible with it? Yes, what do we tell them?

name: Ricardo Serrão Santos (S&D)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – In my view, in fact, the issues of hunting in wild species should be allowed to indigenous populations who have secularly used these resources and who are not really able to access other resources. These conditions will have to be seen in fact throughhistory, through geography, and must be acted on according to these perceptions.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: – The European ban on commercial seal products has an eventful history. My own party, the NVA, was at the heart of the ban in 2009 with former European Parliament member Frieda Brepoels. The ban gave a long-a anticipated answer to the demand of millions of citizens not to allow products from cruel hunting into our market. The law didn't miss its effect. In Canada alone, that meant the rescue of more than 2 million seals.  The ban has been challenged several times, but it is holding up. And the fact that the WTO is also giving the green light is crucial. With some targeted changes to ensure WTO compatibility, the ban is now firmly enshrined. Parliament and the Council have reached a defensible agreement that meets WTO requirements in a timely manner, puts animal welfare first and does not undermine the original legislation. Our delegation will therefore support the agreement tomorrow.

name: Miapetra Kumpula-Natri (S&D).
text: Madam President, I would like to begin by thanking Theresa May for Thank you to the Commission for being represented here. I think I can support animal welfare and support the WTO principles, but what I have difficulty with is telling people who live on Åland, who live on the small islands, who live in Estonia or Sweden or on the coast, where I live, in Ostrobothnia. There is a single school in Finland that learns how to use this production. It is something we have learned a thousand years ago, and now it is something that only the Inuit have. It is very difficult to go back home and say that you were too small, we did not hear you. I am therefore also asking the Commission now that you have promised to come out with this exception in the field of research, could it also be museums? Who decides the Inuit are equal? Could it include those who can show that they have had the tradition for a thousand years?

name: Karmenu Vella
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, thank you to all those who have participated in this debate. Let me once again thank you for being engaged in this process so constructively, despite the sensitivities surrounding the subject, which have been well reflected in most of the points which you raised. The updated regulation aims at ensuring that the fundamental economic and social interests of those communities traditionally engaged in the hunting of seals will not be affected adversely. The hunt, as has been explained, is an integral part of their culture and identity and represents a source of income and, as has already been highlighted by most of the speakers, contributes to their subsistence as well. Indeed, the marine resource management exception is not part of the outcome, as it clearly is incompatible with the WTO. However, rest assured that we have thoroughly examined each and every proposal that we have received but found no possibility for keeping the exception without running a great risk of WTO sanctions because of continued non-compliance. The revised legislation will enable the EU to comply with the WTO ruling and provide a non-discriminatory legal framework in line with public moral concerns. So thank you for giving the proposed regulation your support.

name: Cristian-Silviu Buşoi
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, I can understand that the agreement reached does not completely satisfy some of the Nordic and Baltic countries, but I do appreciate that they also understand that this agreement is more valuable and should be adopted, especially as we succeeded in having a new set of criteria for the Inuit exception and because of the agreed text on Article 7 on reporting. I agree with Mr Bendtsen’s remarks and I truly believe, after the meetings I had with the representatives of the Greenland and Danish Parliament, with the Inuit community, different NGOs and with the Commission itself, that the hunt conducted by Inuits and other indigenous communities does not harm or threaten to harm the habitat and health of the seal populations, and there is no chance that it is made primarily for commercial purposes. The Inuits hunt because this is their way of supporting their family and their small communities. Their livelihood needs are very simple and modest. They have been doing it for hundreds of years as part of their tradition and cultural heritage and they have respect for animal welfare. We have a very fast-track calendar, and without good cooperation we could not have reached an agreement and met the deadlines in order to give the Commission time to prepare all the necessary subsequent acts by the October deadline. Thank you very much once again. I look forward to the vote tomorrow.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Jørn Dohrmann (ECR)
text: Written. Thank you to mr. I would like to ask Mr Bușoi for his report and to the colleagues who have tabled the amendments reflecting the importance of preserving the culture and well-being of the Arctic peoples.  The 2008 EU regulation banning trade in seal products had a dramatic effect on Greenland. The so-called "Inuit exception" could not only protect the market for Greenland seal products. The economy in this area has suffered heavy losses and, more importantly, the EU's reputation has suffered a serious blow among the area's residents. The appreciation by the Greenlanders of their close cooperation with the EU, which concerns many areas, is overshadowed by the regulation.  It is close to impossible to understand Greenlandic culture and identity without the traditional and sustainable seal hunting. It damages our chances of succeeding in the EU's Arctic policy of banning trade in seal products. This is happening at a time when the region is becoming increasingly important on the international political agenda. The 2014 WTO decision states that the two opt-outs included in the EU Regulation do not comply with the WTO's regulatory framework. Despite the efforts of the Commission and despite the amendments, the situation is not improving for Greenland. That is why I am voting against the proposal. Our ban on animal products should always be based on the environment, sustainability and animal welfare. There are no such arguments against Greenlandic seal hunting.

name: Puhemies. –
text: The next item is the report (2013-2014) (2014/2254(INI) by Laura Ferrara, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union (2013-2014) (2014/2254(INI) – A8-0230/2015).

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the image of little Aylan Kurdi, found lifeless on Turkey's beaches, is the symbol of a denied right: the right to life. I wondered whether to bring here to plenary the image of little Aylan to look at the deaths that this Europe is also causing, but then I felt it was inappropriate to respect his memory and I preferred not to exhibit it publicly. You see colleagues, if the vision of images like Aylan's had effects that go beyond outrage, anger, pain, perhaps today we would see in that body a sacrificial victim, a martyr, at least worth protecting and saving so many other innocents. But history teaches us that this has never been the case, and so, alas, it will not be this time either, because after the emotional wave has passed, Europe will once again deal with these rights with the indolence and short-sightedness that has characterised it so far. Immigration is just one example. Every day we witness stories of denied rights, and we must not go beyond European borders to trace them: – children born sick with cancer due to the presence of toxic waste and illegal landfills, – 122 million poor people, many of them without citizenship income and therefore without means to survive, – austerity measures that impose cuts in health and welfare , leading to the suspension of the supply of medicines in public pharmacies or, indeed, to the closure of hospitals. We are talking about predictable stories, avoidable stories, if only that anger and indignation that one feels in the face of these examples translates into a reaction, a driving force to change this Europe, so as to prevent further and further violations of fundamental rights. Another Europe is possible inso far as an alternative is wanted. And you don't have to indulge in the imagination to look for ideal examples.  There is, in fact, another true face of a Europe made up of solidarity, fraternal acceptance, commitment to protect the best interests of the child, social inclusion of minorities, the daily struggle to guarantee formal and substantial equality, the protection of working mothers, respect for others' thoughts and tolerance for all beliefs. A Europe that denounces injustices and refuses to hide in the hypocrisy of a protection of human rights recognised only on the Charter or in the Treaties.  It is to this Europe that we must look again, these are the examples that must drive the work of those who, like us today, are debating the degree of protection accorded to fundamental rights in Europe, if it is to be improved. We ourselves are the controllers and guarantors of those rights and values which under undersea this Community and which legitimise the existence of the European Union itself. Every day we see blatant violations of fundamental rights throughout Europe, yet nothing is done to stop or prevent them. So, let us be hypocritical, omertous and finally complicit. The proposals put forward in the report therefore go in the direction of ensuring greater control and interaction with citizens: knowing what is happening in each individual Member State will enable the European institutions to put in place the necessary measures to protect fundamental rights. This is not an inquisition, nor is it a question of going beyond the principle of subsidiarity: it is a question of gaining common awareness and receiving information that is lacking to date. I believe that this has been one of the most debated aspects of meetings with the shadow rapporteurs: I hope that the proposal for greater transparency will not frighten anyone and that we will decide, together, to improve the fortunes of European citizens. I would like to thank the rapporteurs of the opinions of the other committees and all the other shadow rapporteurs, with whom we have carried out a demanding but also very exciting work together. Be brave: let us build a Europe of rights now.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I welcome this annual debate on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union and I appreciate the huge amount of work done by Ms Ferrara. The European Parliament’s call to all EU institutions and all Member States to protect and promote fundamental rights is loud and clear. The European Commission fully supports this call. Allow me to start by addressing some of the substantive questions raised in your report, before turning to more institutional aspects pertaining to the mechanisms at our disposal for the protection of fundamental rights. Equality is a central issue in your report, and indeed this principle is at the heart of the European project. Yet discrimination all too often continues to occur in every single Member State. Take the recent case concerning a town district inhabited primarily by Roma citizens, in which the electricity meters were placed on poles six metres high, whereas in all other parts of town they were placed at a height where they could easily be monitored. I am glad that the European Court of Justice clarified that such practices are not acceptable under EU law. Much remains to be done to secure equal treatment everywhere, regardless of religion or belief, race or ethnic origin, gender, age, disability or sexual orientation – and EU law has a crucial role to play in this respect. I therefore welcome the call in your report for the rapid adoption of the Equal Treatment Directive, which remains a priority for this Commission. It is highly regrettable that it has not yet been agreed. Another issue that worries me is the rise of intolerance and hatred in our societies: you can see it on a day-to-day basis now, certainly linked with the refugee crisis. We are going through a period of crisis right now which is not just social and economic. It is political and moral. In times such as these, we see again the old tendencies of trying to identify scapegoats – of always looking for somebody else to blame – and minorities are always at the receiving end of the blame. Therefore, combating prejudice, racism and xenophobia has to be a focus of action. This is also the reason why the Commission will devote its first annual fundamental rights colloquium at the start of October to issues related to hate crime and discrimination, and in particular the fight against anti-Semitism and Islamophobia, which are distinct but related phenomena. Another important set of challenges raised in your report concerns the protection of personal data, the right to privacy, and the maintenance of security. In this respect, let me first of all stress that getting the data protection reform agreed by the end of the year remains a top priority for the Commission. Both the Data Protection Regulation and the proposed directive for criminal-law enforcement authorities are crucial pieces of legislation to ensure that citizens across the EU continue to benefit from solid, up-to-date rules safeguarding their right to the protection of personal data. I am confident that we will succeed in adopting a meaningful and strong reform package by the end of this year, and I count on your continued support in this respect. We will also continue to insist on the full observance of data protection standards in our relations with third countries, including the United States of America. I am pleased to note that we are on the point of finalising negotiations for an umbrella agreement with the United States, setting out ambitious and comprehensive standards for the protection of personal data when such data are exchanged between law enforcement authorities in the United States and in the European Union. Let me also stress that there should be no doubt that personal-data processing – for any purpose, including the enforcement of criminal law – must comply with the Charter of Fundamental Rights, and in particular be necessary and proportionate. This being said, we also need to take into account the fact that there can be duly justified situations requiring – for legitimate reasons of criminal-law enforcement and in order to ensure public security – that the personal data of persons not immediately suspected of criminal activity also be processed. Let me now turn to the more institutional questions in your report, in particular the question of whether we need new mechanisms for the protection of fundamental rights, including a new strategy for fundamental rights. At this stage, today, I am not convinced that we do. Mainstreaming the Charter of Fundamental Rights should be a reflex for all EU institutions throughout the policy cycle. We have the existing 2010 Strategy on the application of the Charter of Fundamental Rights and, before considering new mechanisms, we should continue to implement it. This means a systematic screening of all relevant legislative and policy measures to ensure their compatibility with the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights. The adoption of the Better Regulation package is a further step in this direction: it provides for fundamental rights to be taken into account systematically in the assessment of all significant policy initiatives. Of course, this also is a shared responsibility of all the EU institutions. Therefore, as outlined in the Commission’s proposal for an interinstitutional agreement on better law-making, a similar assessment should also occur when significant amendments are made to Commission proposals during the legislative process. The Commission, as guardian of the Treaties, is also committed to ensuring that the Member States respect the Charter – including, if need be, by means of infringement proceedings. In 2014, the Commission launched 11 infringement procedures against Member States specifically to ensure that Charter rights are respected. The main areas of concern are asylum and immigration, in conjunction with the lack of free legal assistance, the right to an effective remedy, detention conditions and the situation of children. Your report also calls for a strengthening of the framework for the protection of the rule of law in the European Union. I fully agree that ensuring full respect for the rule of law is crucial to the protection of fundamental rights throughout the Union. Without the protection afforded by independent courts, and without effective judicial redress mechanisms, fundamental rights will remain on paper only. That is why the Commission, two years ago, adopted a Rule of Law Framework setting out a structured process according to which the Commission will react when there are specific indications that there is a systemic threat to the rule of law. I can assure you that we remain vigilant as regards any threats to the rule of law, wherever they may occur, and that we will not hesitate to activate the Framework when necessary. I can also assure you that the Commission’s approach will remain objective and impartial, and based on the law and the facts on the ground and not on political speeches. Let me also stress that the Commission remains fully committed to EU accession to the European Convention on Human Rights. Accession to the Convention will serve to strengthen our fundamental values. It will improve the effectiveness of EU law and the coherence of fundamental rights protection across Europe. I strongly believe that the European Union should accede to the Convention, and I am confident that we will find solutions to the legal issues raised by the European Court of Justice in its opinion of December last year. Let me conclude as you did, Ms Ferrara, in your opening statement, with a few words about migration. I fully agree that our reaction to this crisis must also be about protecting fundamental rights: the fundamental right to asylum for those in need of refuge; their right to be protected from risking their lives in the hands of ruthless traffickers; and also their right to be treated with dignity wherever they are and under whatever conditions they have to live. This is why we have put respect for, and the promotion of, the EU values of human dignity, the rule of law, human rights, solidarity and equality at the centre of the EU Agenda on Migration. Our reaction to the current crisis must be about saving lives. It must also be about processing asylum applications faster and effectively, in full accordance with fundamental rights. We must never forget that asylum is a right to be protected. At the same time, our priority has to be the correct and full application of EU asylum and migration law, in accordance with the twin principles of responsibility and solidarity. This must include an effective return policy, fully respecting the fundamental rights of the migrants concerned. Only if we ensure correct application of the system will we be able to offer protection and humane reception to all those who deserve it, and we will reduce incentives for those who have no right to stay to undertake the perilous journey. Here, you see our societies often greatly divided on the issue: humanity and the humane treatment of migrants in conflict with a feeling of being overrun or flooded. We need to get out of that contradiction. There is no need to fear being flooded, and certainly not if we can apply asylum policy as it was intended. And there is certainly no need to take leave of our fundamental values. That means that people who flee from war and persecution have a place in our society. Let me conclude by stressing that it is a joint responsibility of the European Parliament, the Commission and other institutions to ensure respect for, and the promotion of, our common values. Democracy, fundamental rights and the rule of law must be, and continue to be, a reality for every single citizen and anybody else who is in Europe. All institutions and bodies, including the Commission and the European Parliament, need to work closely together to make it happen. This is essential for a common European future.

name: Ramón Jáuregui Atondo
text: Drafts member of the Opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. – Madam President, thank you very much, Mr Timmermans, thank you very much, Mrs Ferrara, I think the issue we are dealing with is very important because human rights are probably the universal ethical floor that everyone has to establish the rule of human dignity. Since the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, we have highlighted three ideas that I would like to highlight. Firstly, the importance of the European Union being able to monitor itself. Many times we want to be a reference, we want to be exemplary, we look at everyone to see how it behaves in relation to human rights. There is a growing need - Mrs Ferrara stressed this - for us to look at ourselves, because today in Europe, in many countries, in many Member States, human rights are not being respected. Secondly, this issue is particularly important in the area of the protection of economic and social rights. The crisis has shown that there has been a progressive devaluation in the protection of economic and social rights, and this deserves to be highlighted. Thirdly, I share with Mr Timmermans the need for the European Union to accede to the European Convention on Human Rights.

name: Daniela Aiuto
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Women's Rights and Gender Equality. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank my colleague Laura Ferrara for the splendid and truly commendable work she has done in the LIBE Committee on this report. In the area of respect for fundamental human rights, however, the protection of women's rights certainly plays a major role.  In the FEMM Committee, I was the rapporteur for the draft opinion on the report that we are going to vote on tomorrow, and in our report we have focused in particular on the many violations and forms of discrimination that, unfortunately, women still suffer today in Europe and throughout the world. I am referring to all the physical and sexual and psychological violence to which women are subjected, to child abuse, to harassment, to persecutory acts that often also occur through the distorted and incorrect use of new technologies and the Internet.  There is an urgent need for greater commitment on the part of the States of the European Union, we cannot continue to witness helpfully the continuous feminicides, honour killings, cases of homophobia, and all other forms of discrimination, both in the daily private experience and in the work, political and decision-making contexts. We therefore hope that new and more incisive measures will be taken to strengthen prevention, guarantee protection and punish those who commit crimes. Only in this way will we be able to guarantee real freedom of choice for women and equal treatment in relation to men, thank you.

name: Soledad Cabezón Ruiz
text: Draftser of the opinion of the Committee on Petitions. – Mr President, Mr Timmermans, Mrs Ferrara, from the Committee on Petitions I have to say that one third of the requests we receive denounce alleged violations of fundamental rights, which has been heightened by the crisis situation we are in. It has served as an excuse to attack public services, cut freedoms, such as expression, or limit free movement between Member States, as well as solidarity with third-country nationals of our Member States, denying them, for example, access to health care.  We have seen 'hot returns' on migrants and how the recognition of minority rights in the Member States of the European Union has been delayed. Ladies and gentlemen, the European Union is recognised in the world, and it must continue to be, as it is the largest guarantee of citizenship, wherever it comes from. I appeal to the Commission that it should continue to be not only the guarantor of the transposition of European legislation but also of its correct application in each of the Member States and, in particular, to ensure that it is currently struggling, in which the present speaks for itself.

name: Ελισσάβετ Βόζεμπεργκ
text: , on behalf of the PPE Group. Mr President, all European citizens and all the people of Europe are undoubtedly entitled to enjoy fundamental rights. I believe that fundamental rights should not be a field of confrontation between the political groups because this may lead to the wrong conclusion, namely that there are multi-speed sensitivities in the European Union. There are, however, elements of controversy, which stem from different perspectives and from different positions and which may be implanted in the reports, so that they appear to serve specific purposes. Mrs May's report on the Ferrara lends itself to fruitful and constructive dialogue but can undoubtedly also be evaluated from different perspectives. The European People's Party has an alternative motion for a resolution but we believe that, despite our divergences, we are pursuing the same objective. We argue that no new mechanisms are needed. Existing ones are adequate and can ensure the supervision of those Member States where fundamental rights violations occur. We also support what the Vice-President, Mr Timmermans, has repeatedly said, that in cases of violations a mechanism of constructive dialogue between the Commission and the Member States must be activated immediately and these issues addressed. We also argue in our report that there is a need to strengthen public security but under conditions of protection of fundamental rights because otherwise, there is a risk that one will be subject to criminal offences at a time when there is a real need to protect and protect against terrorism and other phenomena that may harm the European Union.  Ladies and gentlemen, fundamental rights cannot be distinguished or exceptions. In our report we fully record all the fundamental values and recognise the respect required of all of us.

name: Péter Niedermüller
text: on behalf of the S&D Group. – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank Ms Ferrara for her excellent job on this report, but I would also like to take this opportunity to thank all colleagues, assistants and advisers for their hard work, especially those who constructively contributed to this report. This report was adopted in the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs (LIBE) where the majority of the committee decided in favour of the report. I hope that the outcome of that vote will also be respected in this Chamber. This report also has other important implications for the fundamental rights of minorities: Roma children, women and LGBTI people and for those seeking asylum. The European Union was founded on the principles of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. These values stem from the common constitutional traditions of all Member States. Upholding these values is of crucial importance for the proper functioning of the European Union, because they guarantee that Member States fulfil their international law obligations and that they can trust each other and the institutions of the European Union. Upholding these values cannot be a matter of current political needs or inactions. The already—existing tools and mechanisms are insufficient for dealing with breaches of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. This has been proved in the last couple of years and must be rectified. That is why in this report we call for a new mechanism that is automatically triggered in cases of breaches of fundamental values and rights, to remedy the breaches, to avoid the materialisation of systematic threats in Member States. Our common European fundamental values are being threatened first and foremost from within, right before our eyes. Democratic parties of Europe have to unite to protect these values. Failing to do so may have severe consequences, including the possibility of the European Union falling apart. Almost 60 years have passed since its foundation. We cannot let the efforts of the last 60 years vanish into thin air. I ask you to vote in favour of this report.

name: Helga Stevens
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – This is a comprehensive report covering many areas. Due to the lack of time, I would now like to focus on the rights of people with disabilities. In Europe, this group continues to suffer from deprivation and exclusion.  Last week, on behalf of the EP, I was present in Geneva at the exchange of views between the UN Monitoring Committee and the European Commission on the implementation of the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities. Their concluding comments were just published. The committee was more than clear: the rights of people with disabilities are fundamental human rights. That is why we must play a leading role at European level, not only in terms of social policy, but also in the areas of work, infrastructure, mobility, foreign policy, EU funds and so on. After all, the handicap works in all policy areas. All policy-makers must take into account the handicap dimension in their policies and also sweep on their own doorstep. This means that people with disabilities should also be able to have equal access to EU funds and EU projects. For example, there should be a separate budget that covers the additional costs of, for example, sign language and real-time subtitles for deaf people at conferences and workshops and personal assistance for the blind and less mobile. The European Parliament must also be much more transparent and accessible to this group of people in the same way. They too are citizens of Europe.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, Commissioner, I too, and in a very sincere way, and in a very sincere way, do not give the rapporteur an oratory formula for her work and perseverance, which enabled her to present us with an ambitious and quality report. It once again assesses respect or non-compliance with fundamental rights within member states.  Today, it must be admitted that fundamental rights are applied too often according to different interpretations, sometimes comfortable for the authorities in place.  I obviously agree with everything that has been said in favour of the report, but I would still like to address in particular the dear colleagues of the EPP Group. I am stunned today. The resolution that is being proposed as a replacement for the report is a real slap in the face to what we are defending in this House. How can we support a resolution that completely obscures the situation of our homeless people? Where are the democratic values when we refuse to condemn the CIA's detention and torture programmes on European territory? Why are you removing all the paragraphs on freedom of expression and the media? Don't your humanist values make you want to criminally prosecute the barbaric perpetrators of genital mutilation on little girls?  Everything else in your report is obviously in the same line. You go through everything, including the gender equality and violence against women, LGBTI rights, children's rights, migrant protection, and the protection of people with disabilities. I don't quite understand that way of looking at it.  So, ladies and gentlemen, before blindly pursuing a group line that reflects unease— because some of your eminent members are clearly in violation, in their country, with the spirit and letter of the treaties - it would be good to measure the moral price.  I know that a significant number of members of the EPP group think the same way, so I really appeal to these Democrats to support Mrs Ferrara's excellent report. (The speaker agrees to answer a question "blue card" (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the regulation)

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card.  – You consider this report to be excellent. The report calls for a total, complete opening of the European Union's borders to immigrants. Do you share this point of view and would your federally represented party in Belgium also support such a far-reaching demand? Do you support such a radical demand to open the European Union's borders to immigrants?

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: "blue card" answer. Mr President, first of all, this is very typical of the disinformation technique that is being used. I do not think that in this report it is as simplistic as that, even though, as a personal matter, I do not have any major moral problems with this issue.  For me, man is universal. He is everywhere the same with his sufferings, his joys, his genius and his talent. I am therefore a little surprised that parliamentarians who should, in essence, defend European values come here to throw in pasture - in a very populist way for that matter - statements which, moreover, are totally false. As you know, we must distinguish between, on the one hand, humanitarian refugees, who are asylum seekers leaving their country because they want to flee violence, fear, tyranny, despotism and, on the other hand, economic migrants - this has been very well said by Commissioner Timmermans - who, if they do not comply with European or national rules and laws, cannot stay there.  So stop being simplistic, I think it's not honest to be simplistic like you are!

name: President. –
text: Will you accept a blue—card question from Mr Zdechovsk?

name: Louis Michel (ALDE).
text: Mr President, that is enough, I am not used to exchanging words once I have answered a question, it can only be the same barrel. Therefore, I do not accept this kind of debate.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, first of all, I also want to thank Laura Ferrara for the work she has done and all those who contributed to this report. Many agree at home and abroad that the European Union is experiencing a crisis of values. The issue of refugees, and more broadly that of migrants, is an unfortunate symbol of this. What are so-called universal values if their application is variable in geometry by state and population categories? No, the tools do not exist. Sanctions do not exist for violations in this area. If we need testimony, look at the UN reports, look at the Council of Europe reports: they are all damning about the setbacks of the European Union and its Member States in this area. For a long time, European states have been able to appear models thanks to the struggles that have advanced universal respect for these rights. But for a number of years, the direction of walking has been reversed. There are more and more setbacks. Civil liberties are attacked in the name of security, the widespread registration of whole sections of the population is put in place, hatreds are stoked and scapegoats, including migrants and Arab-Muslims, are thrown to the vindictiveness. Fears are being surred to push through increasingly regressive legislation as social inequalities and poverty take on dramatic proportions.  So, certainly, respect for others, whatever their differences and socio-cultural choices - a term I prefer to that of ethnic, at least ambiguous - religious, philosophical, sexual and political, and living it together are fundamental principles without which nothing is possible.  I hope that here we will be able to come together largely around Mrs Ferrara's report.

name: Ulrike Lunacek
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, first of all let me thank Laura Ferrara and the shadow rapporteurs for this very good text. Let me repeat what they said, that another Europe is possible, especially when it comes to rights for refugees. This continent has to be one that welcomes refugees – especially when they come from war—ridden areas like Syria – and that does not throw them out or hinder them from having their rights respected.  I also appreciate the approach adopted, which focuses on the institutional structure that we need to change but also on certain specific areas of human rights and of fundamental rights – on media pluralism, anti—discrimination, ethnic minorities, sexual minorities, people with disabilities and race. As rapporteur of this Parliament for the Equal Treatment Directive, I very much appreciate what Vice—President Timmermans said and I am optimistic that the Commission and Parliament will make the Council go ahead and have this Equal Treatment Directive finally become law, to make sure that the fundamental rights of all minorities are respected on this continent, and that the fight against racism, xenophobia, homophobia, lesbophobia and transphobia and all the other forms of discrimination will succeed.  With that, I also have to say that the institutional structures need to change. The Copenhagen dilemma is that when countries accede to the European Union they have to fulfil everything, but when they are in well, big nothing! I would say to the EPP that Article 7(2) simply does not work. We need new mechanisms, and this report asks for new mechanisms that are automatically triggered, and for country—by—country reporting. This is not about controlling everyone: it is about safeguarding our common values to make sure that in no country of this European Union are fundamental rights violated. That is what this report is about. It is about a common understanding and a common awareness. I really do wonder how Madam Vozemberg can speak of her report being a good alternative when that alternative means deleting pages and pages of jointly agreed text. We were there in the debates together, but now she is saying that her alternative is better. Well I am sorry, but her alternative is not better, because if you do not talk about discrimination and you do not want to see it, that does not mean that it goes away. We need to address this, and that is what this report is about. This bonfire of deletions will not, I hope, find a majority tomorrow because we need to stand together to make sure that fundamental rights are safeguarded on this continent for everybody – with no exceptions. (The speaker agreed to take a blue-card question under Rule 162(8)).

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". A very brief question: you said that refugees are welcome. Does this apply unrestrictedly to both war refugees and poverty refugees? And if so, is there any upper limit where you would say that's what we can still integrate, and that's too much?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. Mrs von Storch! I have said that it is now primarily a question of war refugees. I was really happy. Mrs Merkel is not from my party, and I often have a lot of criticism of her. But in the case of when she said that in Germany refugees from Syria are no longer sent back to Hungary or anywhere else – that was right and proper. And I am glad that my country has finally done so. We are talking about war refugees here, and we need space for them, for which we really need support. But refugees from poverty – how many have left Europe, fled terrible poverty from Ireland, including from my country, and from Germany elsewhere, when times were bad? We must also contribute to changing world trade structures and the like on the ground, so that people no longer have to flee.
