But if someone is fleeing from the climate disasters that we are helping to cause, poverty that we are also causing because we are not paying enough for raw materials, then we have to look closely here and see whether these people can survive at home or not, or whether they do not have a right to live with us. (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Zoltán Balczó (NI)
text: Blue card question. – When you talked about accepting refugees, you mentioned primarily those who save their lives from the war zone – to whom the European Union provides shelter according to its rules. What explanation do you have for the fact that when these people reach the Schengen border, the Hungarian border, they do not cross the legal border crossing, but arrive at the green border by discarding the documents they have used up until then. What's the explanation for that?

name: Ulrike Lunacek (Verts/ALE)
text: blue-card answer. – Sir, many refugees – and the definition of a refugee is someone coming from a warring area – do not even have passports or documents with them because they had to leave everything behind because everything was destroyed, so we really have to take care of them. I found it totally unacceptable when just recently the Hungarian Secretary of State said on Austrian Radio that Muslims are not welcome in Hungary because we are not used to them. Would we apply the same rhetoric and say that women are not accepted on boards of companies because men are not used to them? This is simply outrageous. Things like that should not happen in our common Europe.

name: Gerard Batten
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, this place talks a lot about fundamental rights. The idea might be novel to some of the countries represented here, given their recent histories, but we have fundamental rights in England established over centuries. We recently celebrated the 800th anniversary of Magna Carta, a key milestone in that process. Our rights were further established under such things as Habeas Corpus, the English common law and the Bill of Rights of 1689, to name just three.  But the fundamental rights of the English are being destroyed and swept away by EU law. The EU is creating its own system of criminal law, a process which it euphemistically and laughably calls creating an area of freedom, security and justice. Well, it may be news to people here, but we have had one in the UK for centuries. Under a European arrest warrant, for example, any British citizen can now be arrested and imprisoned on the basis of vague accusations, with no prima facie evidence against them, and a British court is powerless to prevent this happening. Under the common recognition of fines and confiscation orders, an EU state may confiscate the assets of a British citizen without a British court having any power to prevent it. Soon it will be possible to compel British police forces to investigate British citizens on behalf of foreign police forces under the proposed European Investigation Order. All of these are fundamental breaches of the Bill of Rights. If the British want to protect their own fundamental rights, then they need to leave the European Union. If you want to learn something about those rights, come and study the English system.

name: Vicky Maeijer
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. – Today we are discussing the European Parliament's report on fundamental rights in the European Union, a pompous term that the European elite is increasingly abusing to mask the fact that these human rights only apply unilaterally to a group of people they have selected. These fundamental rights have many guises. Under the guise of human rights, solidarity, moral duty, justice, diversity and dignity, achievements such as democracy, freedom, security and prosperity are sacrificed. The question is: whose fundamental rights actually protects the European Union?  Not that of the European people whose safety is compromised by the unchecked admission of hundreds, thousands of illegal immigrants, including terrorists, under the guise of solidarity and moral duty. And not those of the European people whose freedom is at stake because of imported terror and the Islamisation of our continent, under the guise of freedom of religion. Not those of writers, politicians, cartoonists and critics whose freedom of expression is increasingly restricted by accusing them of hate speech, Islamophobia and racism.  This abstract morality is particularly evident in the debate on mass immigration. Europe's elite is mainly concerned with putting away critics. The elite is now taking the measure of critical Member States and is blaming the original inhabitants. The danger to democracy therefore comes not from Eurosceptics, but from the European elite who are at the button. The danger to the rule of law does not come from the citizens who demand a say through referendums, but from the political elite who see referendums and participation as ballast. The danger of fundamental rights does not come from the Member States, but from cultural relativists who limit and deprive our free-spirited values, norms, freedoms one by one.  We do not need the European Union to protect fundamental rights. In fact, the greatest danger to all the values that the European Union claims to stand for is the European Union itself.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I miss two fundamental and generally recognised human rights in this report. One is the collective and individual human right to belong to a national community in our homeland, to use its language, to preserve its customs, traditions and religious roots. I mean, for example, We have the right to live as Hungarians in Hungary. The other is national self-determination, the essence of which is to decide for ourselves how and how we want to live in our own country. The vast majority of Hungarian people send a message to you that we want to live as Hungarians in Hungary, we believe that the Hungary the Hungarians. And in the context of national self-determination, if, for example, our German friends think otherwise and think that they want to live in a multicultural country, it is the right of their hearts, it is also a human right. We, on the other hand, want to exercise the right of national self-determination according to what I have said, so we believe that Hungary of the Hungarians. What is your position on this as a human rights context?

name: Monica Macovei (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I propose that we talk about something else than we have talked about so far, namely what we humans do to defend our individual rights, our rights, starting from the idea that only when we fight for them, when we protest, when we go out on the streets, when we shout, when we scream that our rights are being violated, only then will we have them. It's a daily struggle to maintain and preserve our rights. Let's take two situations - I was thinking about freedom of speech and freedom of demonstration. Freedom of expression is that of the journalist who, of course, must also respect the holy rule of journalism - the facts are true, opinions are free - but also our right, of the people, of public opinion, to be informed. We have journalists harassed, kicked out, banished, staying at home, having nowhere to work, because they didn't want to break their principles, because they didn't want to listen to their bosses, and they stuck with the principles and they have nothing to live on. I write on personal blogs - very well, because at least some of us are informed. But we humans, what do we do to protect their right to continue to exercise their profession and to give us the right to be properly informed? Another example is the right to free association - what do we humans do when we have governments full of corrupt, liars, impostors, plagiarists, incompetents - what do we do, take to the streets to defend our lives against them?  That is the problem I see - this lack of reaction in many European countries, the lack of reaction against the violation of rights. We have given two very important examples for our lives - journalists and our right to know what governments are doing with us and our right to control governments and take them down. It's very easy to take down a Government just by taking to the streets, a hundred thousand first.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Fundamental rights are at the heart of the European project and the annual report is a very important part of parliamentary life. It is an interesting coincidence in time that we are also talking about the State of the Union in this plenary session. And just as not everything is at its best in the state of the Union, so is fundamental rights. They are often seen as a cosmetic accessory, and there is a competition for displacement through many other issues, which repeatedly leads to fundamental rights remaining a secondary matter somewhere. I am very grateful for Mrs Ferrara's report, because I believe that it really is a very important element, that it really points in the right direction. Firstly, because it is very systematic, secondly, because it highlights current references, such as mass surveillance and its impact on individual freedom, because it addresses the refugee situation – this must be done in times like these – and because it also raises the issue of the impact of the economic crisis on human rights. This is very important. It is also important that he also has an implementing aspect, namely that he also asks how this can be enforced. The weakness is that we do not have good instruments for actually enforcing human rights. I think it is very important that the establishment of the Fundamental Rights Agency is mentioned positively, that it is wanted to strengthen it, that we need an observation mechanism that, irrespective of day-to-day political assessments, determines where human rights and fundamental rights are being violated. We also need a mechanism for enforcing these fundamental rights. That, I believe, is the most important point. I would ask all My fellow Members to vote in favour of this excellent report.

name: n/a
text: Mr. President! Today we are talking about the report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union. It is also, of course, about refugees, not distinguishing between the persecuted and the migrants of poverty, nor do we discuss the question of why the Middle East and North Africa are in such terrible chaos. But that is not the issue now. Hundreds of thousands are in Germany alone, need help and we need to help.  Let us stop talking, let us do something concrete! It needs living space, lounges, meeting rooms and a large canteen. If we stopped moving with this Parliament once a month from Brussels to Strasbourg for three days, we would have all this here in the Parliament building in Strasbourg for almost 1 000 people. 750 offices of members, each one has a bed, each one has a bathroom. There is a large canteen, there are many halls that you could use for training. In the plenary, you could do benefit concerts, all of which are available 27 days a year. Let us stop the travelling circus — we are saving hundreds of millions of euros and making Parliament a great asylum-seekers' home - it would be more useful than it is now. You shall know them by their deeds.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: James Carver (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – You raise a point which so often comes up with the frequent hot air in this Chamber when people argue about the way we have to travel between Brussels and Strasbourg. You raise a very valid point about this huge expense – this huge waste. But could I perhaps take your suggestion a step further? Of course, we have the mothballed chamber over in Luxembourg as well. We have this huge amount of waste – and is it not symptomatic of this place that we have a lot of hot air: a lot of people coming forward and saying we have to do the right things? Well, perhaps we should start practising what we preach and actually look very closely into the money that is being squandered by this institution, as it has been signing off its own accounts for 19 years.

name: Beatrix von Storch (ECR)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. I believe that there are many good ideas that go beyond using Parliament and other buildings. However, I believe that it is time and it would be a good signal if we were not just talking about the problems here, but were to do something that we could do in a very concrete way, where we could work to make good use of this building. We could implement this immediately. No time would be wasted. The rooms above are finished, they are empty, people could move in immediately.

name: Cecilia Wikström (ALDE).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would also like to thank the rapporteur, Laura Ferrara, for her dedicated work on this report and, at the same time, also to thank alde's shadow rapporteur, Louis Michel, for his report last year, which has clearly set out a road map for how we ensure respect for fundamental rights and freedoms in the EU. Individual human rights include all citizens, including those citizens whose rights are undermined by their own governments, as is happening in some parts of our Union. When these freedoms and rights are threatened in our countries, then the European institutions must be able to intervene. When a country wants to join our Union, it promises loud and clear that it will live up to an independent rule of law and that it will safeguard human rights, but if you are in, then you are almost free to do anything. Unfortunately, the Member States have taken the habit in the Council of holding each other's backs rather than standing up and defending fundamental rights. It is absolutely crucial for our credibility in europe now to have a binding, independent and objective review of each Member State and how to live up to fundamental rights – an ongoing review that applies to everyone. Remember that it is fundamental rights that form the basis of our Union and of our entire cooperation. Perhaps the Member States will only begin to understand the seriousness when they have financial consequences, and I would say that, because another Europe is actually possible.

name: Martina Anderson (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the situation of fundamental rights in the EU is wholly unacceptable. Compassionate protection and the promotion of rights to life, dignity and freedoms, such as asylum, are being undermined, if not ignored, in the current context of the ongoing humanitarian refugee crisis. Rather than approaching this crisis with humanity, a fortress Europe is heavily financed, and indecent and dehumanising language, border fences, tear gas, religious discrimination and the shirking of responsibility are comfortably adopted. Only the solemn protection of fundamental rights can resolve this crisis. That can be accomplished by providing safe and legal access, scrapping the Dublin Regulations, and empowering and encouraging Member States to take a progressive and humane approach to the most pressing humanitarian crisis the world faces. Clearly we will not uphold fundamental human rights or resolve the refugee crisis by dropping more bombs on Syria. Enforcing fundamental human rights is crucially important, and therefore I thank the rapporteur and the shadows for their sterling work.

name: Julia Reda (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, first of all congratulations to rapporteur Ferrara and her colleagues for compiling this excellent report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU. It highlights the discrepancies between freedoms promised in law and the freedoms denied when people put them to the test. Anyone whose fundamental rights have been denied deserves our support, whether they are taking to the streets of Barcelona in defiance of national gag laws, whether they are rallying across the continent in support of the citizens’ initiative or, indeed, demanding access to documents from ongoing TTIP negotiations without 95% of their contents being redacted. The report also takes a decisive stance against fundamental rights violations in the self-proclaimed war on terror, and it does not buy into the myth purported, for example, by the EPP shadow that blanket surveillance could guarantee our safety. Safeguarding the rights to be informed about government actions, to have one’s privacy respected, to speak out against injustice and to participate in the political process are all fundamental rights vital to democracy. It is this Parliament’s duty to safeguard these rights, and I count upon my colleagues to adopt the Ferrara report and to ensure that comprehensive monitoring of the Member States’ fundamental rights obligations is ensured.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr In Article 116 of the proposal for a new European Convention on Human Rights, the European Parliament deeply regrets the repeated and tragic loss of people in the Mediterranean. points out that the EU and the Member States should do more to prevent new tragedies at sea; I can only agree with this, but when some parliamentarians want to integrate human rights into everything related to EU migration policy, they always assume that all the people fleeing must come to Europe to have their rights respected. The solution will therefore be to encourage the EU and the Member States to open new, safe and legal entry routes, so that all migrants can enter the European Union. This, my friends, is an untenable solution. Of course, politicians have assumed a sense of care and goodwill when they once wrote the ECHR, but that feeling has led us completely wrong. (The speaker agreed to answer a question (blue card) in accordance with Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: David Coburn (EFDD)
text: blue-card question. – I wonder if Madam Winberg would agree with me that Saudi Arabia and the Gulf states should be doing more to set up camps in Turkey rather than displace large numbers of people, and that they should be helping their fellow Muslims. I think it is a disgrace that they are not doing more and that Britain is doing more than any of them. I wonder if she agrees with me about that.

name: Kristina Winberg (EFDD)
text: answer ("blue card"). Yes, I absolutely agree with that. They have the same language, they have the same culture, they have the same way of life. Why don't they open up? No, they buy themselves free. They need to take more responsibility. We in europe cannot take this large number of migrants. We are cracking, we will not be able to function if we are to continue to have open borders. I certainly think they can take a much greater responsibility.

name: Lorenzo Fontana (ENF).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, but I have to say that even in this debate, I find some hypocrisy on the part of this Parliament and the European institutions, because we want to talk about fundamental rights, but I cannot understand what fundamental rights we can guarantee to other minorities at a time when we are struggling to guarantee fundamental rights, for example: on the safety of citizens who may want to live peacefully on their territory , or perhaps we cannot guarantee the right to work for so many young people, in Italy we are more than 25% unemployed young people, we cannot guarantee the fact that a family can have children, because, evidently, there is this difficulty, we cannot have more children and we are dying out, you know very well.  But above all hypocrisy, I find it at a time when the European Union has so often endorsed things in the rest of the world, which have not guaranteed fundamental rights in the rest of the world, for example, the war in Libya. In the end, who caused it? So let's think about fundamental rights here when we created disasters? But not just in Libya. Let us also think in Syria, now there is the problem of refugees. But there's someone who has responsibilities. We gave the Nobel Peace Prize to a Us Present and in Syria he has some responsibility. Or we want to talk about when we do business with Saudi Arabia, which is certainly not a state that guarantees fundamental rights or with China.  In short, I believe that perhaps we should examine our consciences and see what we really want to do instead of filling sheets of paper.

name: Janusz Korwin-Mikke (NI).
text: – Mr President, the most fundamental right of humans is to be treated like humans, not like cattle. Look at Iceland. It is an island with 70 000 families. 10 000 of those families – not the government – have accepted to take refugee families. How many would German families accept? 8 million or perhaps only 800 000? How many would Poland accept? 2 000, 10 000, 200 000? Nobody has asked them. His Holiness Francis I has demanded that every parish accept one family. We have 53 000 parishes in Poland.  But here we must deal with families, not with governments. Governments treat people like cattle, like the Jews in 1944 when 300 000 Hungarian Jews were sent to Auschwitz. The refugees are not being killed of course, but cattle are not usually killed either. Still, refugees are being treated like cattle and this is unacceptable. We have 11 German concentration camps in Poland now. Germany is paying us with EU money to keep refugees behind barbed wire. They are escaping to Germany and the Polish police catch them and taking them back.  Finally, if we pay the refugees social benefits, we encourage more to come. They move and then there will be another thousand drowning in the Mediterranean. Those who pay social benefits have blood on their hands. Remember, Socialism kills.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Dear Laura, you know that I appreciate your hard work and I express to you this great compliment for the work you have done on this report. However, the fundamental right of our faction is to disagree with you and to bring about an alternative text of its own resolution, which I personally consider to be more balanced. I'd like to answer a colleague over there who wasn't willing to have any discussion. Dear colleague, you may hear me, but our faction's fundamental right is to disagree with the text. And that's why we're bringing an alternative. Next, I would like to answer my colleague Lunack. It's a little cheesy to follow up on our text. Our text is no better or worse than Laura's. Our text is different. And that's the principle. The principle of democracy is debate. I would like to bring two important points to the debate on human rights. The first point is the child's right to both parents. I consider this to be quite crucial. In Norway, children's rights to have two parents, their biological parents, are permanently violated. And we can't close our eyes to this condition. They are taken from children by the deaf-mutes, people who do not speak or hear. This also needs to be criticised here on this ground by the European Union. And the second thing I want to talk about. We have talked about women's rights, let us also talk about men's rights. I myself was a victim of stalking. And when I came, I was being sued. And no one's talking about what even men are going through. And let's talk about men having rights, right. It's very important. We men are ashamed to be men. And that's the third thing I wanted to talk about. These are the rights of victims of crime. I think there's very little emphasis on that and they're quite a bit of a schming. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Laura Agea (EFDD)
text: Blue card question. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this is a question of method, given that he said 'we do not criticise' and 'our alternative motion is neither better nor worse, it is different', I would advise and ask my colleague: why, then, does he not present it in the appropriate forums and not as an alternative to the work done by Mrs Ferrara. Because I believe that there are appropriate forums, this is an own-initiative report. Do the same with your group and then in Parliament the plenary will decide on your report or that of your party. I think it is a lack of respect for Mrs Ferrara's work.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – Dear colleague, thank you for your question that I can explain what I did not have time to say, because the President was too strict with me. Yes, you're right. It's a right, a fundamental right to choose between the two versions. There's no better or worse. Each reflects that thing from a different side. That is why we have put forward an alternative text so that this discussion can take place and we can mention things that are not mentioned in that text. I gave a big compliment to Laura for her work and her hard work. Please accept our work, our hard work.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Timmermans, I would like to thank Mrs Ferrara for her report. Today, more than ever, I believe, it is clear that there is a need for an effective mechanism for the protection of fundamental rights in the EU that can prevent possible violations that unfortunately are sometimes also found in the Member States, contrary to the principles contained in the Charter of Fundamental Rights. I therefore agree with the idea of establishing a permanent process of thorough monitoring of the situation of democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights in all Member States in order to make up for the shortcomings of the current protection instruments.  Furthermore, at this historic time when Europe is facing an unprecedented humanitarian crisis, with hundreds of thousands of migrants pressing on our borders, we cannot forget, I believe, that the fundamental principles of the Union enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights and included among the aims of the EU's external action require us to ensure decent treatment and reception for all migrants. , regardless of their formal status as refugees and refugees and asylum seekers, and they also require us to pay particular attention to the most vulnerable people, and I am referring to children. We mentioned little Aylan at the beginning of our debate, but I am also referring to the many unaccompanied minors, who are even more defenceless victims of the traffickers of criminal organisations. She's report focuses on and calls for urgent action on this matter, so I hope it can be adopted as soon as possible.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. The European Union's mission is to uproar the fundamental rights of the human person, those at the core of the European legal tradition: the right of the human person to life, the right of the family, freedom of expression. I am also pleased that these new fields of sensitivity have been appreciated. First of all, it is about the rights of people with disabilities, as well as freedom of the media, the fight against corruption. On the other hand, I am very sorry for the fact that once again the report falls victim to ideological correctness. After all, Islamophobia cannot be stigmatised in a situation where Europe's problem is not Islamophobia, but radical Islam threatening our continent. This is very irresponsible. It was also very irresponsible to criticise European policy towards immigrants as insolidar and closed. These are not fragments that serve Europe well and the rights of the human person.

name: Maite Pagazaurtundúa Ruiz (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner Timmermans, Mrs Ferrara, thank you very much for your work. The report on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union has 178 paragraphs: about 30 grams in weight. These 30 grams define us and defend us because they force us to act in front of the bigots, force us to help victims of hateful aggression, persecution, victims of abuse of all kinds, and also war refugees. It forces us for the first time —positively, if we approve it — with mechanisms that provide common indicators and real objectives, real control mechanisms for real violations happening within our real borders, with real states. These 30 grams are much or little, because they house the values of the European Union, our truth, our future as a society if we are brave, or, if it is mutilated by part of the groups in this House, will give us the irrelevance and nothing of a missed opportunity.

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, thank you Mrs Ferrara for the report.  If we are talking about fundamental rights in the European Union, we must talk about the right of women not to be murdered, raped, threatened or beaten by being women.  This summer, in the Spanish state, 17 women and 8 children have been murdered. In 2014, 59 women were killed.  This report refers to the study by the Agency for Fundamental Rights and highlights that 33% of European rights have experienced physical or sexual violence and that 9 million Europeans have been victims of rape. More violence if we talk about women with functional diversity, migrant women or transgender women.  Gender-based violence is terrorism, sexist terrorism, but it seems that in Europe there is "first- and second-rate" terrorism, "first-rate" victims and "second-rate" victims, and gender-based violence is undoubtedly in this second division.  There is no troika ultimatum to governments that do not implement policies against gender-based violence; there are no threats of expulsion from the European Union to those who do not allocate resources against this gender-based violence. And when is a Summit of Heads of State to address this terrorism?  (She agreed to answer a question posed in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Regulation)).

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card question. "I think the issue of violence against women that you have raised is very important, and that is why I ask you what you said about the scene that was all over the press when a migrant Muslim man became frustrated. He took his wife, who was five months pregnant, and his toddler, dragged them off the railway tracks, and all this – of course, the Hungarian police professionally intervened, trying to protect the woman and child from abuse – was described as violence by the Hungarian police. And this wife abuser was also made to look like she was entitled to some kind of glorification for what she did. What's your position on this?

name: Marina Albiol Guzmán (GUE/NGL)
text: "blue card" response. – Mr President, I believe that we obviously cannot take advantage of the talk of gender-based violence in order to make speeches which, on the other hand, may seem xenophobic. Gender-based violence is condemnable, wherever it comes from, and it is condemnable, whether by a person of Muslim, Christian religion or who does not profess any religion. I believe that gender-based violence is always condemnable, always.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, Mrs Ferrara, the completeness of your report I think is a powerful indicator of European ill health in the field of human rights , in Europe and beyond – but we will defend it with our vote because it tells the truth without disguise. It's a biannual report and maybe that's why it has so much content. But at the same time, this report is already in some respects overflowing, as evidenced by the debate we are having at the moment.  The situation of immigration today is the genuine and dramatic portrait of our democratic setback, of our problem as a European society and as holders of a system of values that we cannot and cannot prevent from being continually and increasingly denied and humiliated. Reading the report and at the same time rereading the European Charter of Fundamental Rights is an exercise in contrast that is difficult to digest.  The report refers to the economic crisis and the serious consequences it has had. The crisis is not a weather accident and the seriousness of human rights involvement is not a contagious disease: it is our decisions that motivate it. It must be our decisions that correct it and invest the process. This report is a good starting point in this direction.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to sincerely congratulate my colleague Laura Ferrara on the great work she has done, which is a work that she has done with passion, with commitment, with great technical knowledge and which have led to a truly complete report.  It is also an ambitious report, because when you realise – because it is undeniable that there are problems within the European Union, it is undeniable that there are human rights violations within the European Union – and then when you go to try to create monitoring mechanisms, control mechanisms, mechanisms that can actually improve the state of fundamental rights within the European Union. I expect both Commissioner Timmermans and colleagues, especially colleagues from the People's Party, to support the will of a young colleague to improve the state of fundamental rights in Europe.  So I am trying to appeal to those who may not even have read the report and who are simply listening to the party voice, a voice that comes from above and says to vote against it, to rely on another report, read it, and look, if you want a better Europe, to support mrs Laura Ferrara's report.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the It is astonishing that such a report on the human rights situation in Europe simply fails to say that there is discrimination through political persecution in the EU member states. Especially in Greece, Austria and the Federal Republic. There are messengers of opinion, bans on work, bans on meetings, hotel bans, house bans. In Germany, 12 000 investigations are opened every year against patriotic citizens, more than 1 000 are in prison, most notably my friend Horst Mahler, who only got twelve and a half years for his opinion, who was only amputated in August because he was not given enough opportunity to move in the German prison. Mr Timmermans, you are talking about being impartial. If you omit that, you will not be impartial, because fundamental rights are indivisible.

name: Csaba Sógor (PPE).
text: – I welcome the findings of the report on the situation of fundamental rights concerning minorities, and I would particularly like to highlight the points on which, irrespective of the outcome of tomorrow's vote, there appears to be a consensus among the parliamentary groups. Everyone already recognises the need for greater consistency in the protection of minorities, the need to avoid the application of double standards, and therefore the need for a mechanism to monitor the effectiveness of the rights of minorities. Likewise, we agree that the European institutions are responsible for developing a comprehensive EU system and call on the Member States to ensure effective equal treatment of national, ethnic and linguistic minorities on the basis of international standards and best European practices. There is also no debate between the factions about the need for effective implementation of international conventions drawn up within the framework of the Council of Europe and the OSCE, and the fight against discrimination based on language use and the removal of administrative barriers to linguistic diversity are already our common goals. I think that these are very serious advances, and representatives of national minorities have been calling for the European Union to approach their situation in this spirit for years, even decades. We must therefore all strive for the Commission, after the European Parliament's resolution, to adopt this approach and to start developing and operating a European minority protection mechanism.

name: n/a
text: Mr. President! The European Union sets high standards for every candidate country, and no country can become a member of the EU if it does not make a clear commitment to democracy, the rule of law and respect for fundamental rights, and, above all, if these values are not also enforced. The EU is a community of values, and it must therefore be a matter of course that fundamental rights are fully guaranteed even after a country's accession, but unfortunately this is often not the case.  Why should the EU be able to monitor compliance with European values effectively only before a country's accession, but no longer after that? Of course, Article 7 of the EU Treaty exists, but it is a blunt sword because of the high hurdles to its application. The Commission and the Council have taken the first steps to remedy this situation. That is certainly to be welcomed, but it is not enough! What is needed is a genuine fundamental rights mechanism, with continuous monitoring of the situation of fundamental rights in each country, and country-specific reports that are published regularly.  The EU institutions must be able to intervene in good time in the event of serious violations of fundamental rights in a Member State. At its core, this is a question of one's own credibility. Objective criteria and a transparent process would, in my view, guarantee that no country would be unfairly pilloried. I support Mrs Ferrara's report and I hope that, if the report is adopted, the Council and the Commission will also take up the call for the establishment of a fundamental rights mechanism. Thank you very much!

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Mr. President, reports on fundamental rights in the European Union are generally ideologically colored and promote left-liberal ideas and policies. This time, unfortunately, it's no different. The content of the report did not surprise me in the slightest, but I cannot help but wonder how much better it would be lived in Europe if the rights of individuals were taken into account as much as the rights of various minority groups were taken into account. Today, in this house, we no longer speak at all about the right of the individual, the smallest minority in the world. We don't devote too much time and energy to his right to live from his own work, instead of the state taking most of his income, or the right to raise his own children, rather than indoctrinating them through the public education system. And when that individual is an unborn child, all these great advocates of minority rights would not allow that helpless human being even that basic right —the right to life. That is why I will never support such reports that promote positive discrimination against minorities, while at the same time fundamental human rights are being violated by other citizens across Europe.

name: Josu Juaristi Abaunz (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, it is a good report and I also congratulate the rapporteur. From my country's perspective, the Basque Country, Euskal Herria, would, if possible, miss more concrete proposals to overcome not only the Copenhagen dilemma but also, more precisely, the double standard sometimes set out in conflict resolution.  Civil and political rights, individual and collective, are not respected throughout the Union and, from the Basque Country, I must recall again the persistence in the Spanish State of political judgments, even in peacetime. This autumn, without going any further, two more will be held, against Batasuna and Askapena. I must also recall the violation of rights to political prisoners and their relatives and relatives, who continue to suffer, for example, from dispersal. Finally, I would like to recall the closure of the Spanish Government to accept something as democratic as the right to decide in Euskal Herria or Catalonia.

name: Laura Agea (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that Mrs Laura Ferrara's report is not only an excellent piece of work and not only has she called on members of this House to take an act of courage, but I believe that we need a due act, because fundamental rights must be relied on and we are in a position to do so. We have a responsibility to demand rights for those who have no voice to ask for them, because that is the task for us 751 Members of this Parliament.  I believe that an act of courage is sometimes to risk one's life by looking for something else, an act due is to give an opportunity to life to those who do not have that opportunity. I believe that this Parliament very often sees its voice ignored by institutions that are not democratically elected by the citizens, and to come out divided in such an important report would give even less strength to our action. I therefore appeal to each of these colleagues to support Mrs Ferrara's report with strength and conviction.

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE).
text: – On fundamental rights I would like to highlight three ideas. First, that are the basis of European values, second that it is the fight that never ends and third that are a cause that must unite and not divide.  First, human rights are the deepest basis of the ideals and values on which the European Union is based. It is for the defence of these rights that every day we must work to promote their respect throughout our continent. Second, as the Ferrara Report well identifies, in 2012 and 2013 there were still many, perhaps too many, violations of fundamental rights. This job is never finished. In order for us to do this, we must be able to scrutinise in an exempt manner. This report is only useful if it provides us with a picture of reality that allows us to identify our focuses of action. And third, the fundamental rights in this house must unite and not divide. The Ferrara Report goes too far. It extends into debatable censorship considerations and goes beyond the scope of the Union's competences. And it proposes a mechanism that should certainly not be discussed here. Changing the nature of the European Union and distinguishing between what is European and what is national is a matter for the Treaties. A broader compromise should have been reached in this area. Mr President, there is no doubt that we must continue to work to promote and ensure respect for the fundamental rights of the European Union. But in to achieve this, this Parliament cannot use fundamental rights as a political weapon of combat. On the contrary, we must look at fundamental rights as the core of European construction as a unifying element of all European peoples. That's the only way we're going to make a difference.  (The speaker agrees to answer a question under the blue card procedure in accordance with Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Gilles Lebreton (ENF)
text: "blue card" question. Mr President, mr Mep, I agree with you that fundamental rights should not be used as a political weapon that will once again enable the European Union to interfere more in the internal affairs of States, most of which in Europe are capable of defending their own fundamental rights.  Having said that, I ask you an additional question: do you not think that this report also risks blurring the border between the European Union and the Council of Europe, an organisation specialising in the defence of freedoms?

name: Carlos Coelho (PPE)
text: Response according to the "blue card" procedure. – Mr President, Dear Colleague, I do not share your view that the defence of fundamental rights is not a European competence. I believe that it is a European competence and I believe that, in the name of these values, we have every legitimacy to give an opinion on them. What I do not agree with is that a factual report on human rights goes beyond the limits of a clear picture of reality and, as I have said, I do not consider that the defence of a new mechanism – which was indeed very well contested by Vice-President Timmermans – should take place here. It is a matter for the Treaties, it is not a matter for a report on human rights.

name: Ana Gomes (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I greet Mrs Ferrara for this important report. Another Europe is possible, she said, and I add: it is indispensable and urgent. The situation in europe's fundamental rights is illustrated by the crisis arising from the influx of refugees. This is a European crisis because, by action, omission and incoherence in our internal and external policies, and also by the prevalence of the perverse neoliberal ideology that is anti-European, we end up helping to manufacture refugees and migrants outside and inside, including the more than three hundred thousand Portuguese who in the last four years have had to emigrate, not to mention those who have been pushed into poverty by neoliberal policies , including the elderly and a quarter of the children, only in my country, Portugal.  That this is a crisis of lack of European values is also seen by the way we are belatedly reacting to the effects of war, oppression and misery in the neighbourhood. If we have a majority of governments and citizens with historical memory and solidarity generously welcoming the fugitives, we also have rulers who shame us, such as the prime ministers of Hungary and Slovakia, who by word and deed violate fundamental rights and bring back old demons against peace, freedom and democracy in Europe. The Union and the Member States have an obligation to act and put the fundamental rights of migrants, refugees and their own citizens at the heart of their policies, ensuring coherence between internal and external policies. Only in this way will we stop the terrorist threat, only in this way will we not allow it to be instrumentalised to jeopardise the security, freedoms and fundamental rights of European citizens themselves and those who seek protection for their lives and for their families in Europe.

name: Peter van Dalen (ECR).
text: Mr President, I am not particularly enthusiastic about this initiative report, a report with 65 recitals and 178 paragraphs. There have been reports in this House for less referral to the relevant committee. Yet I take one point: the refugees. Unfortunately, the Member States have not been able to take a common decision before the summer on a redistribution of a limited number of refugees across Europe.  We have seen the shocking images of the past few days and weeks and we now know: the refugee crisis is getting worse very quickly! Joint European action is now needed, and the heads of government of Central and Eastern European countries in particular must no longer hide. Moreover, a mandatory redistribution of refugees only makes sense if it includes a broader package of measures, with safe havens, well-equipped camps in the Middle East and North Africa, with firm agreements on safe countries and the return there and finally with a full commitment to tackling people smugglers.

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: – I asked for the floor in order to give my support to the alternative proposal of the European People's Party. The PpE motion for a resolution focuses on the protection of fundamental human rights. It states that the subject of the protection of fundamental rights should not be abused. I appreciate that the EPP also considers it important to protect the rights of indigenous minorities. I would like to highlight points 24 to 27 of the People's Party proposal, which state that the EU must respect the rights of indigenous national minorities, those who have been enriching Europe with their culture and language for decades. It is important that the proposal calls for the EU institutions to better protect the linguistic, cultural and educational rights of minorities. It calls on the Member States to implement effectively the Council of Europe and OSCE minority protection documents and calls on the Member States to adopt a national legislative framework to address all forms of discrimination. I welcome the fact that the proposal also calls on the Commission to develop a comprehensive EU system that would ensure equal treatment of indigenous minorities and thus stability in Europe. I also support the idea of the EU joining the European Charter of Human Rights as soon as possible. I believe that this is the path we need to go down, which strengthens European cohesion and the identity of European citizens. (The speaker agrees to answer a blue card question under Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI)
text: Blue card question. –I was very pleased with many things, but, my fellow countryman and fellow Member, used the term 'indigenous national community' quite rightly in his oral speech, but in the written variation it is called a minority. In the Hungarian translation, it starts at point 24, and then there is the title "support for minorities". We know this very well that Europe is constantly mixing these concepts, they do not understand what it is to be an indigenous national community. We are trying to push this, and I ask my fellow EPP members to force this to be included. All the more so because it was already in the Michel report, the previous fundamental rights report. So there's a setback here, and that's what needs to be corrected. Are you willing to support this?

name: Pál Csáky (PPE)
text: Blue card answer. "Indeed, Mr. President, I would like to thank you for your support. The written document uses the term that is also used in international documents , i.e. the term 'minority'. We citizens of national communities use the term 'national community'. I very much hope, My Dear Fellow, that this will soon be reflected in our document. Let's try to do it together.

name: Soraya Post (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr As an MEP in the European Union, where far-right forces are growing like poisonous mushrooms, I see this report as one of the most important reports before us this year. It is about how countries are to live up to what is fundamental to our democratic society: respect for the rule of law, respect for human rights and respect for the Union's treaties. Democracy that is not founded on human rights is not a democracy to talk about. We have seen this before in our history about 70 years ago. If we are unable to fulfil these commitments, we will not succeed in any other ambition either.  Unfortunately, this report is strikingly thick. I would like it to be on one or two sides, but there are more than 40 pages dealing with a wide range of areas, where the EU and the Member States must act now. This shows that we are in trouble – 40 pages in 2015! A key issue is, of course, the human rights review mechanism that Parliament has repeatedly called for, which is crucial for the EU to live up to its fundamental values. We see member states violating human rights with regard to refugees. We see that there is systematic discrimination against Roma in all Member States. The EU needs an alarm mechanism for discrimination and human rights violations wherever they occur, and there is a need for severe sanctions against those countries that are unable to respect human rights and the fundamental values of the EU. I support Mr Ferrara's report. Well done!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, in this period of economic crisis, memoranda and austerity policies increase poverty and unemployment and lead to a violation of the fundamental rights of the citizens of the European Union and, above all, of their social rights. The memorial measures, especially in Greece, deprived the poor Greek people of the right of access to basic public goods such as health, education and social security. For this reason, the European Union, and in particular the Commission, must also enforce respect for the Charter of Fundamental Rights in Greece. But that's not the case. Mr . Moscovici even replied, in response to a question to the Commission about the troika's violation of the European Social Charter in Greece, that the European Social Charter is not binding under EU law and therefore does not impose legal obligations on the Union and its Member States within the legal order of the European Union. In other words, in this respect, does the European Commission wash its hands of the violation of the Charter of Social Rights in Greece, even though it is itself a member of the Troika that has imposed these measures on Greece? I would like an answer to this issue because it is very serious. Is it possible for the Commission itself, in its reply to an MEP, to say that the European Social Charter is not binding?

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Reports assessing the situation in the field of the protection of fundamental human rights in the European Union and the Member States can have a good impact on the improvement of justice systems in countries, and i therefore support such reports, as well as discussions, of course. I come from Slovenia, which unfortunately has become a European champion in human rights violations. Indeed, the European Court of Human Rights published statistics in August, identifying an average of 148 violations per million inhabitants. By comparison, in Germany only two infringements per million inhabitants. Of the 100 cases in Slovenia, the most high-profile example of violations of fundamental human rights is Janez Janši, who has been prosecuted by the Slovenian unreformed justice system for seven years on the basis of a completely absurd indictment. The intention was to remove from the political field the leader of the opposition, who was twice a successful prime minister and even president of the European Council. Last year, just three weeks before the state election, he was even imprisoned without any proof. Six months later, of course, the Constitutional Court found Janša not guilty and overturned all past judgments. Can you imagine such a case happening in the heart of Europe? In order not to repeat itself, I call on the European Commission to draw up as soon as possible the promised sixth-round action in the area of justice, which will allow external, systemic control of the functioning of the judiciary in the Member States. Perhaps this requirement may be redundant for someone in orderly environments. For post-communist or transitional countries, however, this is the only way to the rule of law and respect for human rights and freedoms.

name: Kati Piri (S&D).
text: – The protection of fundamental rights is a core task of the European Union. Our credibility is therefore closely linked to this. How can we pursue a values-based foreign policy when we sometimes don't have our own affairs in order? If the situation of 10 million Roma has not improved in recent years? If lgbt rights and acceptance are far from guaranteed? Then there is the refugee crisis and, in particular, the reactions of a number of European heads of government. For the first time, I have genuinely asked myself: do we share the same values within the European Union? Can we allow EU heads of government such as Viktor Orbán and Fico to openly and sometimes proudly discriminate on the basis of faith and to put Syrian refugees away as a danger to Europe because they are Muslims? We must take strong action against this, and I hope that the European Commission will lead the way in this fight.

text: – Sur President, il-ħarsien tad-drittijiet fundamentali huwa wieħed mill-valuri bażiải fuq liema l-Unjoni Ewropea hija fondata.
