name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the speeches that have taken place today on the excellent report by Mrs Ferrara, whom I thank, have been very focused on the subject of migrants, as might have been expected. Instead, I would like to focus on the aspect – which may seem marginal at this time, these days, but which has a great role in the report – which is the aspect of rights, the protection of lesbian, bisexual, transgender and intersex people.  What this report does is to put our Parliament, the European Parliament, as a beacon in the fight against the too much discrimination that there is, the prevarications, the absence of the rights and protections of LGBT people. This report makes our Parliament understand the change that is taking place in Europe.  It also emphasises – I would like to say, if I may turn the words of the report – it underlines our role as politicians who are close to the citizens, and it must be a more humane role than we have been in recent months, in recent years, trying to take care of the lives of citizens. Combating homophobia, Mr President, as the report points out, means combating the many fears that run through our Europe, and which, unfortunately, are highly represented in this House and often also find a political shore.

name: Patricija Šulin (PPE).
text: – I would like to draw attention to the need for fundamental human rights to be violated in certain courts of the Member States. The European Court of Human Rights last month released alarming data showing that Slovenia, where I come from, has found itself at the European peak in terms of the number of human rights violations per population. In 2010 Slovenia was convicted three times for human rights violations and 29 times last year. She has been convicted in as many as 94% of all cases, which puts us in the same place as Russia. In Slovenia last year, a survey of a former constitutional judge was carried out, which found that in 2004-2014 human rights and fundamental freedoms violated 442 Slovenian courts and at least 1200 judges. All these shocking data remind us that Slovenia still has a lot of work to do in the area of the protection of human rights and fundamental freedoms. But we have to deal with the problems now.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, today's debate on the subject of fundamental rights in the European Union is central, because Europe is currently called upon to demonstrate explicitly that the statements of its founding principles are still solid and worthy of faith. In fact, and inexorably, we still have many violations of fundamental rights, as evidenced by the judgments of the European Court of Human Rights. I am thinking of violence against women, which is sadly the most widespread in the European Union, but also the situation of children. According to the WHO, at least 850 young people under the age of 15 die as a result of ill-treatment.  I congratulate Mrs Ferrara on her excellent work, but we cannot fail in this debate to take account of what is currently taking place on the doorstep of the European Union. I believe that this document is in danger of merely being a sign of good intentions if we do not manage, each individually, first of all to take responsibility for overcoming the emergency of these hours, preventing the suspension of those fundamental rights that form the backbone of the Union as barbed-wire walls and the marking of human beings.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mrs Ferrara, Commissioner, I would like to support the Commission's request to implement the instruments at its disposal to protect fundamental rights in the European Union. The principles of the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union are prepolitical, and subsidiarity is not. Credibility in this area is gained when citizens perceive that they work accordingly, and the restriction of basic rights and freedoms, such as those of demonstration and assembly; the accumulation of convictions for not investigating torture; refusal to follow Un recommendations to offer justice and reparation to thousands of victims of a dictatorship; the non-recognition of sentences served in other countries, for pure reasons of electoral opportunity, with the accompaniment of sumissed judges, who clearly fail to comply with European law, are part of the many complaints we have brought here about the systematic deterioration of freedoms in Spain. They deserve, as this report argues, an objective and transparent assessment, and should result in automatic activation of correction mechanisms.

name: Kateřina Konečná (GUE/NGL).
text: - Madam Rapporteur, thank you for a very good report. However, several important topics were missing. For example, the report makes no mention of the rise of modern slavery in the European Union. Because we know that there are 3,000 children from Vietnam in the UK who are forced to work for drug manufacturers. I find this completely unacceptable and the European Parliament should demand that this inhumane practice be put to an end.  Your report mentions the negative consequences of a non-conceptual policy of cuts on European employment and social policy. However, I wanted to point out that the various specificities of individual professions should also be taken into account. I consider it reprehensible, for example, that miners in some countries of the European Union, such as the Czech Republic, are not entitled to early retirement. Especially when we consider how physically and mentally demanding they are doing work and that there is a very real risk that they will not live to see the limit not lowered. However, I am very happy, rapporteur, for the space you have given to European citizens' initiatives, CIA torture on European territory, the NSA programme and other topics.

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, my thanks to my colleague Laura Ferrara are enormous for the commitment and great passion with which she has approached this report on behalf of the entire delegation of the 5 Star Movement. I will touch on issues that have been little touched on in this debate: the famous white-collar crime, which has been touched on in depth; corruption; money laundering; tax evasion and avoidance. Crimes that may have less emotional impact, but which precisely for this reason in a cowardly and sneaky way kill those fundamental rights and that welfare state that we are talking about today, corroding it from within and draining its resources, abandoning the marginalised, refugees and the weakest to their fate.  I am sorry, Commissioner, but unfortunately the efforts and instruments on the ground have not been enough even remotely. Any form of tolerance – involuntary or voluntary – blindness and indifference, is intolerable, indeed it is complicit! With this report, with this vote, I would like our Parliament to send a clear message for once: true European values are those that cannot be deposited in a current account, because they have no price and no political colour. Remind your conscience when you press that button tomorrow and do the right thing!

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, in this debate on fundamental rights I would like to raise two issues in reaction to the honourable Members’ contributions. The first is that of the rule of law which, of course, is the basis upon which we develop our fundamental rights. Socrates, when he was convicted on dubious grounds, was approached by friends who said ‘We will help you flee’, and he said ‘I will not’, because if you accept the premise of the rule of law in a consensual society you do not get to pick and choose which laws are applied to you and which are not. That would be my first point. If you accept the premise of the rule of law you cannot, here in Parliament, debate by saying ‘Well I want this to be applied to me but not to them’, and ‘We have more rights than others’, etcetera. The rule of law applies to every single individual citizen in Europe, regardless of their citizenship, when they live in your country – some people are applauding: I think they misunderstood me, but we will see in a moment – so why would you then accept the premise that you could have the rule of law organised also on a level higher than the national one? The answer is part of our European history. We saw in the 20th century, and especially in the 1930s, that you can use democracy as a pretext to undermine the rule of law by saying ‘We have the majority so we decide what the rule of law is.’ Of course, that is impossible. If you can change the principles of the rule of law with majority votes, you endanger, especially, individual rights or minority rights, if you are not very careful. That is why one of the greatest politicians of the 20th century thought of the idea that you could have an organisation of fundamental rights and the rule of law going beyond the nation state – an organisation at European level, capable of imposing its rulings on nation states if they did not observe the rights enshrined in the rule of law – and that European nations would subscribe to that principle willingly and democratically by signing conventions. Now some of you will be surprised that the politician who thought up this idea was Winston Churchill, and Winston Churchill had a high regard for the British system. He had such high regard for the British system, and so much self-confidence, that he did not mind a court in Strasbourg having oversight over what the British system produced. He had enough self-confidence to say ‘We are good enough to accept that oversight.’ And this is the basis upon which we work. In effect he said ‘Tie me to the mast so I do not succumb to the sirens when they call me.’ And that is the basis upon which our rule-of-law system in the European Union, and in the Council of Europe, was constructed – by Member States saying ‘We will be tied to the mast, so that we do not make mistakes, and if we make mistakes our peers will check and correct us.’ (Heckling) Honourable Member, perhaps you should read a bit more, instead of shouting, and you will know that Odysseus made a very wise choice. My point is this: any nation with enough self-confidence will accept its peers’ checking on its observance of human rights and the rule of law. We have nothing to fear if we are sufficiently self-confident. Do we? My second point concerns diversity. Europe is by nature a diverse community, a diverse continent. Our societies are by nature diverse, and throughout our history we have been strong when we celebrate our diversity: we are strong when we are welcoming to minorities; we are strong when we are welcoming to those who seek protection because they flee persecution and war. And we are weak when we try and confine ourselves to our own culture; when we see anybody who comes from elsewhere as a threat to our culture; when we believe that we can be overrun – 500 million of us – by a few hundred thousand. That is a testimony of weakness, of a lack of self-confidence, of a lack of trust in the strength of our European culture and our history. I strongly believe that if we claim diversity when we are elsewhere, and if we claim respect for our rights when we are elsewhere, we should also be able to give the same rights to those who come to us. What would Europe have looked like if, in 1956, other Europeans had said ‘I do not mind where those Hungarians go, so long as they do not come to us’? What would have happened then, or in 1968 if people from Czechoslovakia fleeing communist oppression had not been allowed, as refugees, into other European nations? (Applause) I celebrate the fact that so many hundreds of millions of Europeans today are saying to those genuinely fleeing from persecution, ‘You are welcome in my country, you will find protection on these shores, we will not send you back.’ Here again I want to come back to the rule of law. It works both ways. The rule of law deserves respect. Those who have the right to asylum should get it. Those are our values. Those are our international treaties. Those are our national obligations. But those who claim asylum without having the right to asylum should be refused asylum and should be returned to where they come from. That is also the rule of law. I strongly believe this is the basis upon which we should discuss fundamental rights. Fundamental rights apply to everyone on this continent – in this European Union – and disregarding respect for the fundamental rights of one individual hurts us all. Europe is nothing if it does not protect its minorities. Europe is nothing if it does not have an eye for that which is weak. Europe is nothing if we close our doors to people who flee persecution and war elsewhere. We will hurt not only the interests of those people: we will hurt our own values, we will do harm to ourselves and we will harm our souls, if that is our attitude. That is the background against which we should be discussing the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner Timmermans, thank you to all my fellow Members who have spoken in this debate. Despite the diversity of certain positions, I believe that it has become clear that, for all Members, over and above the political colour, fundamental rights are of great importance.  I would like to focus on just a few speeches, in response to some of the speeches made by some Members of the Conservatives and The People's Party, about the fact that little space has been devoted to individual rights and instead much more space to minority rights. Well, perhaps, if we look at the report a little more, we can see that there has been a great deal of room for freedom of expression and information, women's rights, gender equality rights, children's rights, the rights of LGBTI people, the rights of people with disabilities, the rights of the homeless, solidarity in the economic crisis, calling for all legislative proposals to be taken into account. , the European Union's policies and actions, including in the economic field, have been examined ex ante and ex post on fundamental rights.  It examines how fundamental rights are violated by organised crime and corruption, and ample scope is given to the protection of victims of crime. Well, I ask myself: are not all rights that place the person at the centre of interests? Are we not talking about the rights of individuals? I would also like to focus on the new mechanism, on which many still have doubts. Well, Commissioner Timmermans, as you will have seen, paragraph 9 already takes account of existing instruments, refers to infringement procedures and refers to the automatic initiation of Article 7.  Nevertheless, I believe that we in Europe can be much more ambitious. Today we have enumerated several stories of violations of fundamental rights, and I believe that this is a mirror of how the instruments that today's Europe equips themselves with are probably not enough. We need to be more ambitious and the ambition is to prevent and not to intervene ex post, when the violations have already been committed.  The new mechanism: briefly in paragraph 10 – please give me a few more minutes – we are talking about common indicators and objectives on the basis of which the Commission can assess the state of protection of fundamental rights. Well, some members have already referred to this, we are talking about the Copenhagen criteria for the accession countries. Why not continue to apply, to refer to the same indicators for the countries that continue to be part of the European Union, we refer to monitoring, country by country. You yourself, Mr Timmermans – and I will end here – paraphrase what you yourself said – Mr Timmermans – any state that has confidence in itself must not be afraid of control by others, on the basis of human rights.  Well, if that confirms to me, what is the fear of calling for an annual report on the state of protection of fundamental rights country by country? Then there is talk of a formal appeal, of an institutional dialogue, very often we are frightened by the terminology used, a new mechanism, that is probably what frightens us, but it is simply common sense. I call on you tomorrow to vote conscientiously and to make us the spokesman for the will of the European citizens.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place on Tuesday 8 September 2015. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Hugues Bayet (S&D)
text: In writing. The report adopted by Parliament on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union highlights essential elements related to respect for democracy, the rule of law and fundamental rights. It addresses, in a progressive way, such essential areas as equality and non-discrimination, the rights of children, migrants, LGBTI people, people with disabilities, violence against women, the protection of minorities, etc.  I would like to highlight a particular point in the report, namely the need for a permanent mechanism to monitor the respect of fundamental rights and the rule of law by each Member State. This is obviously fundamental for the protection of all European citizens.  I can only welcome the fact that a majority of Parliament has supported this report, which reminds us of the importance of Member States' respect for human dignity, freedom, non-discrimination, diversity and the fundamental principles of democracy, all of which underpin the construction of Europe and must therefore be respected at all times by each Member State.

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: in writing. – We still have today national linguistic minorities living within EU borders which face discrimination and are treated as second-class citizens. As Co-chair of the Intergroup for Traditional Minorities, National Communities and Languages, I am sorry to see plenty of cases that are missing from the report. I would especially like to raise the situations of the Hungarian minority in Romania and Slovakia.  The report is a highly political document which, under the veil of ‘fundamental human rights’, covers a whole range of positions that overstep EU competence and are highly controversial among European citizens. Although being sympathetic with Mrs Ferrara for the huge amount of energy she had to put into this report, as in 2010 I was also rapporteur for the same report, nevertheless I cannot agree with her proposal. The report proposes a new rule-of-law mechanism, which I do not consider necessary because a mechanism to check the state of fundamental rights in Member States already exists. As we have witnessed during past years, the political groups of the left use fundamental rights politically and would use a new rule-of-law mechanism politically against governments led by PPE parties, such as in Hungary.

name: Paloma López Bermejo (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. - I value the rapporteur's efforts to highlight the many violations of civil liberties and social rights in the EU. But little can be made when States act as a judge and part of their abuses of the Charter of Fundamental Rights. The EU's mandatory accession to the European Convention on Human Rights remains pending: it is certainly appropriate, given the extreme violence of its militarised migration and security policies. As regards the European Social Charter, its presence in fundamental treaties or their binding nature for all Member States is ignored. In Spain, the European Committee on Social Rights has ruled on the inadequacy of social protection and the multiple violations of labour rights, such as the right to a decent wage, a safe work and a reasonable time: yet the EU continues to applaud the labour cuts and reforms that have led to this situation. The Social Charter and the Convention on Human Rights are proof that another Europe is possible - another Europe very different from the current EU.

name: József Nagy (PPE)
text: Writing. – The task of the human rights report would be to provide a mirror to how we stand in respect for fundamental values and freedoms in our countries. There's still room for progress. With my amendments to this report, I have drawn attention to the phenomenon of the rise and spread of extreme nationalism, racism, xenophobia and intolerance throughout Europe. The reasons for this include terrorist attacks, but one thing is the cause and the other is the phenomenon itself, which urgently needs to be addressed. Mistrust among citizens is growing, especially towards unfamiliar or mainstream cultures. This not only affects immigrant communities, but also has a particularly negative impact on the situation of indigenous national and ethnic minorities. I urge you to take concrete steps to stop aggression, including hate speech. We politicians must choose our words with particular care. He plays with the future of Europe, who excites aggression from populism, momentary vote-winning, and deepens mistrust.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: in writing. – The legal basis for respecting the fundamental rights of EU citizens used to be in the references in the Treaties to the ECHR. However, with the Treaty of Lisbon coming into Force, the Charter of Fundamental Rights was given the same legally binding status as all other treaties, meaning that all member states shall prioritize the respect of Fundamental Rights. The situation is not exactly desirable. Of course, we seem to be within the limit of normal, there are no evident cases of capital punishment or tortures, nonetheless, as a member of the Petitions Committee I have observed that the petitions regarding breaches of fundamental rights exceeds the acceptable standards. Most of them concern the discrimination on sex or origin basis. Moreover, the easily noticed tendency is that the less economic stability, the higher the amount of fundamental rights violations recorded. I believe that we should be able to strengthen the monitoring mechanism in order to prevent the breaches from happening in member states of EU. Unfortunately, having in mind the migration crisis, we must be prepared for the significant increase of number of petitions concerning violations of fundamental rights based on the origin, and since no consensus has been reached so far, we will not be able to control it.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the one-minute speeches on important political issues (Article 163 of the CRP).

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr President, as Europe opens its borders to refugees, in Venezuela, Nicolás Maduro expels them.  That is the reality of Venezuela today. But not only that: misery, insecurity, lack of freedom, human rights violations and persecution of independent media. Nearly a hundred political prisoners whose only crime is to be the voice of opposition to a government that prevents the Venezuelan people from living in peace and addressing the basic needs of citizens. Meanwhile, Canarian Andrea González de León and her partner are still illegally detained on completely false accusations, and from here we ask for their probation and, where appropriate, a fair trial.  The Government of Venezuela knows that it has an expiry date of 6 December, and we know that it will do anything to ensure that the change Venezuela needs does not take place. Europe must say enough is enough! The people of Venezuela have the right to live in peace and freedom.

name: Doru-Claudian Frunzulică (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with our neighbours from the Republic of Moldova, we the Romanians share a common language, traditions, culture and history. Last year Moldova set the record in ratifying the EU association agreement, clearly showing its interest in becoming a close partner of the European Union. This is why I believe the European Union should strongly support the Republic of Moldova’s objective of further integration into European structures and should develop increasingly close relations with Moldova, going beyond simple cooperation to gradual economic integration and a deepening of political cooperation. To define prospects of EU membership should be a key priority of both the Republic of Moldova and the European Union. This should have to lead to the accession of Moldova into the European Union in the future. We have to give clear EU membership prospects to the citizens of the Republic of Moldova. This is clearly in the interest of Europe as well.

name: Yana Toom (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in the context of the refugee crisis I would like to address the problem of statelessness in Europe. The right to nationality is an internationally recognised human right. In the European Union the large stateless population originates mainly from the break—up of the Soviet Union and Yugoslavia. For example, there are almost 90 000 stateless people in Estonia and more than a quarter of a million in Latvia. The large size of the stateless population is among the main reasons for reluctance of Estonians and Latvians to bring a worthy contribution to the solution of Europe’s refugee crisis. The problem of statelessness will not go away by itself, at least in the foreseeable future. The fight against statelessness should be promoted at EU level for the sake of European values, internal peace and stability.

name: Inês Cristina Zuber (GUE/NGL).
text: – The European Union is today faced with a shameful reality in which it has a huge share of responsibility. Has it not the European Union and the majority of this Parliament that has done everything for libya to be bombed for? They were then told to free the Libyan people. Aren't they the same ones who had been enthusiastically supporting everyone for a while, regardless of whether or not they belong to terrorist organizations, fighting the Assad regime in Syria? Syrians today say they just want peace. Those who lived in Libya also say they wanted peace. There, as in other African and Middle Eastern countries, NATO and the European Union have done everything they can to destabilise and be able to shad.  The consequences are the millions of refugees who, trying to survive, face Europe-Fortaleza with their doors increasingly controlled. Now, if the European Union takes in the meagre number of 120,000 refugees, fulfilling only an international duty, it will try to solve only the problem of those who manage to survive and not drown.  When are safe and legal routes set up for migrants and refugees to travel, thus avoiding having to risk their lives?

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to remind the House of two important events for Catalonia that are going to take place this September. The first is this week, on Friday the 11th, when we will celebrate our national holiday and, in three weeks' time, on 27 September, we will have a crucial election in which citizens will be able to express themselves democratically about whether they want to start a process that culminates with the independence of Catalonia. The Government of Spain, in addition to preventing an official referendum, has taken steps that would prove unimaginable in any other European country, such as putting Spain's Constitutional Court at the service of the ideological and partisan interests of the Government. I hope that, in due course, this House will be sensitive to the cry of freedom and democracy of the people of Catalonia and support the majority will of its seven and a half million citizens.

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to talk about the relationship between the European Union or european funds, agriculture and the Mafia, which seem to be three words put to chance together, but there is a great deal of relationship between the three, because the European Commission, through the CAP, the common agricultural policy, has in fact financed, over the years, a great deal of money. , with a boat of money, organized crime.  Think that only the Mafia in Sicily has made something like EUR 400 million disappear, which is not abrupt for a region that is collapsing, where the agricultural sector, which was precisely the main productive activity, is completely collapsing. Think that all the land that has been seized from the Mafia is land that had benefited from EU funds, so basically we would like to try to ensure that there are better control procedures and that there are lower thresholds for these funds.

name: Philippe Loiseau (ENF).
text: Mr President, the current crisis in French agriculture is symptomatic of the failure of European policy. Your policy of enlargement and financing of the agriculture of the accession countries no longer makes sense and if you add to it the result of your liberal ideal of producing at low cost, it obviously creates strong unfair competition from some Member States, such as Germany, for example, with pigs.  For us, there are two urgent steps to take. First, it is necessary to give states the opportunity to protect an area synonymous with a country's independence, that is, agriculture. Secondly, it is essential that the European Parliament cease its declarations of intent and take the decision on mandatory labelling, thereby ensuring the traceability of products. This is a strong demand from our compatriots and Europeans in general. Therefore, agriculture should not be condemned by a globalist liberalism.

name: Krisztina Morvai (NI).
text: – I quote from an open letter from the mayor of Ásotthalom, a much-suffering settlement on the Serbian-Hungarian border, illustrated with photographs. Yesterday, after a few kilometres, the group of invading migrants crossing the border illegally blocked a busy road in the administrative area of Ásotthalom. In addition to being extremely accident-prone, can you imagine how the law-abiding, taxpayer-paying Hungarian citizen who confronted this raging, threatening society must have felt? Especially when his children were in the car and they saw that he wouldn't let them get home to their own homes. Because of the insane decisions of the leaders of the European Union, more and more people are coming, they are becoming more aggressive, they are becoming more demanding, they see that they do not have to abide by the laws. Commissioner Timmermans, as a great expert on rule of law, how do you feel about that? And the idea of equality of rights... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Francesc Gambús (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to draw this House's attention to one of the most dangerous latent threats to biodiversity in the Union: the apple snail, which arrived in 2009 in the left delta of the Ebro and pushed for a Commission decision in 2012 to combat it, has expanded its laying area.  Three days ago the appearance of 43 snails was known in the right hemidelta of the Ebro and this summer copies of this invasive species appeared in Pals, in northern Catalonia. Although the evidence makes us think of an intentional setting – and obviously these environmental crimes must be prosecuted – this does not mean that from the European institutions we do not face a problem that threatens to expand to other European countries.  The longer we act, the worse the consequences for local producers and the greater the chances of an expansion of this invasive species that we have to regret later.  (He repeated the last sentence of his intervention in Catalan.)

name: Anneliese Dodds (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the Commission released a package of measures against aggressive tax planning just before the summer, and we have all now had time to digest them. Although many are welcome, some serious gaps still remain. Above all, we need a robust, objective definition of tax havens to underpin the list produced by the Commission; we need concrete measures to stop those who use tax havens benefiting from EU funds; and we need protection for those whistleblowers who have done so much to lift the lid on aggressive tax planning in Europe. In addition, the Commission must not create new loopholes with the new loss adjustment mechanism it has proposed. Parliament’s special committee on corporate tax has, for the first time, provided democratic oversight of the activities of tax authorities, which until now have largely been hidden from their domestic populations. I hope that while the Commission follows up the welcome proposals in its own tax package it will look seriously at the proposals now emanating from that Special Committee on Tax Rulings and the report on tax matters being produced by the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs. Our constituents demand nothing less.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – Commissioner, I would like to interest the Commission in the situation of Polish farmers affected by the drought on an unprecedented scale, as is clearly demonstrated by the lowest water level in the largest rivers in our country in two hundred years. The losses estimated so far only in crop production go into billions of euros, and all indications are that they will move to livestock production in the autumn due to the dramatic lack of so-called roughage. Although Polish government has announced support for farmers, but only under de minimis aid, which means that some farmers will receive it when the basics of the existence of most farms are at stake. Moreover, budget appropriations of around EUR 100 million have been prepared for this aid, which means that it is not enough not only to compensate for losses, but even to restore agricultural production for the following year. I therefore ask the Commission once again to take an urgent interest in the effects of the drought in Poland and other central and eastern European countries and to mobilise aid appropriate to the scale of the threat, from the so-called crisis reserve. Thank you very much.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in Spain alone, between 1 July and 27 August last year, 16 women and 8 children have been victims of gender-based violence. Four assailants have committed suicide, 18 have been arrested and in the incidents the boyfriend of one of the murdered and the friend of another have died: 33 dead. In order to resolve this scourge, we need, in addition to each other's radical commitment to equality, a European response. We remain without homogeneous statistics on this domestic terrorism, a consequence of the unacceptable differences that criminal treatment of these crimes has in some States: a mistake that we must correct. We lack minimum legislation to prevent these attacks and protect victims and include at-risk minors in these programs. Today is too late for all victims of a silent, everyday, upcoming drama that produces tragedies and images that should also remove consciences.

name: Matt Carthy (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, the ruling by Eurostat to the Irish Central Statistics Office has exposed the pathetic attempts to impose another tax on ordinary families in the guise of water conservation. Having already lost the political and democratic argument, Irish Water has now been deprived of any economic rationale. It is ironic that it was at the behest of the Commission and the ECB that a Fianna Fáil government first proposed the introduction of water charges in Ireland, and that it is a decision of another EU institution, Eurostat, to the effect that Irish Water has to remain on the books, that will be the final nail in the coffin of this regressive taxation policy.  Contrary to spin, Eurostat are clear that Irish Water cannot reach any sort of off-book status, especially with such a high non-payment rate. The report is a damning attack on the incompetence that has been a hallmark of Irish Water’s existence. It is now time for the Irish Government and the European institutions to accept the wishes of the Irish people and scrap water tax once and for all.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – (He began his intervention in Catalan.) Mr President, in recent weeks, the Catalan question has been fully on the European agenda. Mr Cameron and Mrs Merkel, with their statements, have been the authorised notaries of this inclusion on the agenda of the European Union. Now, the final notary will be Catalan citizenship itself with its free and decisive vote.  Five years after the constitutional aggression from the Spanish state, continued today, Catalan society has laden with reason to incredible limits. We aspire to exercise fully as a European State, assuming all the rights and obligations that such a condition entails.  We call on Europe to prepare to welcome us, not only to manage a problem or arbitrate in the conflict, also to receive an injection of the best Europeanism, to incorporate net added value, to work together on the recovery of this European project, which is now at risk of extinction.

name: Gerard Batten (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, the biggest problem facing my constituents in London is the unavailability of affordable housing. There are thousands of people on the public housing waiting lists in every one of the 33 London boroughs. Most people have no chance of being allocated housing or, at least, they will have to wait very many years. Now David Cameron has said that we are going to take 20 000 of the Syrian migrants over the next five years and this will be on top of the one million or so migrants that come to Britain every three to four years.  Since mass migration is not going to stop any time soon, where are we going to put them all? Let me offer a solution. England is a very densely populated country. Scotland, on the other hand, is a very sparsely populated country. There is plenty of space to build new towns and cities in Scotland to accommodate the UK’s ever-growing population. I am sure that the generous Scottish people and their political representatives in the Scottish National Party would welcome such an exciting and humanitarian policy.

name: Sophie Montel (ENF).
text: Mr President, on 24 September in France, more than 100,000 sheep will be bled in good conscience during the Muslim holiday of Eid-el-Kebir. However, Regulation (EC) 1099/2009 of the Council of 24 September 2009 on the protection of animals at the time of their killing stipulates that many methods of killing are painful for animals. Stunning is therefore necessary to cause unconsciousness and loss of sensitivity before or at the time of death. All these written precautions to finally authorize exemptions for ritual slaughter. What hypocrisy! Countless reports, studies and video reports bear witness to the terrible suffering endured by animals slaughtered alive without prior dizziness, some taking nearly 10 minutes to die.  The exemptions for these religious rites must be abolished in France. France must follow the examples of Sweden, Denmark, Switzerland and certain regions of Austria, which have banned these exemptions and made pre-stunning mandatory. In conclusion, ladies and gentlemen, Gandhi said: "We recognize the greatness of a nation by the way it treats its animals." (The President withdraws the floor from the speaker)

name: Pál Csáky (PPE).
text: – I would like to say two sentences on migration from the point of view of the Visegrad Four. It is not that the Visegrad Four would not be in solidarity on this matter. We are ready to take part in the resolution of this crisis, but we would like to point out that the migration crisis cannot be solved only on the territory of the European Union. The quota system will not work in the medium term either. The events in Budapest last week clearly show that almost every migrant wants to continue on to the western part of Europe. We are not convinced that the solution to global crisis situations is that we will relocate the most mobile and perhaps the most eduing layers of these companies to Europe. Our proposal is: action must also be taken towards migration for the African and Asian countries concerned and, in cooperation with them, solutions must be sought to limit these migratory movements, including by establishing security and stabilisation zones in these regions.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the producers of the dairy sector, with their tractors, took to the streets in defence of something which is fair: fair prices that allow them to live worthily from their work. The European Union and the Member States have an obligation to hear this cry from the farmers of Galicia, Spain, Europe. They have an obligation to take extraordinary measures so that our rural world does not disappear. Advance payments – as the Commission has proposed today – or enable specific measures and aid is appropriate, but it is not enough. We need to ensure the structural sustainability of the farmers in our territory, of dairy farmers, if we want the rural environment to be alive, not to be depopulated and to have a future in Europe. And Europe, to do so, must not leave farmers to its fate. Europe is more than just a market where prices are set; must demonstrate this by committing to the future of farmers and the rural environment.

name: Jana Žitňanská (ECR).
text: – The Slovak Republic ratified the UN Convention on the Rights of Persons with Disabilities more than five years ago. Nevertheless, in Slovakia, children with disabilities are still not normally educated in classical schools, because the state cannot provide them with the necessary number of teaching assistants. This start of the school year was so important for many parents, teachers, headteachers and, in particular, hundreds of children in a sad spirit. Although they could be fully integrated, most of these children will not be able to. When we talk about quality education, we always underline the fact that it is an investment that will be returned to the individual, but also to us as a society. This also applies to children with disabilities. Early diagnosis, quality early care, breaking down barriers and, as soon as possible, inclusion among a healthy part of the population are prerequisites for fulfilling the lives of these children and protecting them from the threat of poverty. That is why I also want to appeal from this place to the Slovak Government to provide children with disabilities with the necessary teaching assistants or to allow children to be accompanied at school by assistants who could also be carried out by their parents ... (The President interrupted the speaker)

name: Ivo Vajgl (ALDE).
text: – All of which I would like to say a few words are in Europe: they are called Golden Dawn in Greece, Jobbik in Hungary, NPD and Pegida in Germany, the National Front in France, the FPÖ in Austria, The Boots Boys in Norway, the Skinhedo Front in Venet, Italy, the neo-10ths and non-fathers in Croatia and Serbia. Each one in its own countries, with few exceptions, does not yet pose a serious threat to the constitutional order, to our common European values.  However, when we add up their objectives and look at the programmes, we cannot pass the realisation that, in the shadows and under the auspices of the crisis, economic and refugee, the dangerous power of intolerance, discord and aggression grows. I therefore consider it important that I speak today about the importance of right-wing extremism and the threat it is predicting today, even if only for one minute.

name: David McAllister (PPE).
text: – Mr President, two weeks ago in Brussels the High Representative hosted another meeting of the high-level dialogue for normalising the relations between Serbia and Kosovo with Prime Ministers Aleksandar Vučić and Isa Mustafa. The goal of the meeting – to finalise the implementation of four key agreements – has been reached. Both parties agreed on the general principles on the main elements of the Association of Serb-majority Municipalities. This paves the way for its establishment. Both parties further agreed on the implementation of the energy agreement, the action plan for telecoms and an arrangement for the Mitrovica Bridge. These agreements mark a further step towards the normalisation of relations between Serbia and Kosovo and provide momentum for the high-level dialogue. The significant progress made in the dialogue ought to be acknowledged. I believe the time has come to open the first chapter in the process of negotiating Serbia’s accession to the European Union.

name: Richard Corbett (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the refugee crisis is a massive challenge for Europe, but let us not forget that it is an even bigger challenge for Lebanon, Jordan and Turkey. But, on our side in Europe, have we met a common challenge with a common response? No. Too many governments, far from recognising that, whether we like it or not, we are facing a common problem, are trying to pass the problem on to their neighbour.  But, worst of all, there are those – for instance in my country – who are trying to play political games with this tragic humanitarian situation. Some of them, with a view to our forthcoming referendum, are trying to blame the EU’s freedom of movement for this crisis. It is, of course, nothing to do with the EU’s freedom of movement. These are not EU citizens. They are refugees fleeing wars from outside. It is, though, a situation that would exist as a common challenge whether the EU existed or not. It is high time they started looking at the EU as a provider of.... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Андрей Ковачев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, shame and disgrace to the so-called international community that I have so far endured before our eyes to grow the Islamic State tumour and its various metastases, which have led to an unprecedented migration wave to Europe's borders.  These barbarians have lost their right to be part of the human community. The so-called "civilized world" has left Syria and surrounding countries between plague and cholera, between the Assad regime and Islamic State. Now in Europe we are trying to deal with the symptoms - millions of refugees. We swing between European solidarity and national selfishness. I call for immediate coordinated action by all parties, above all the European Union, the US, Russia, Iran, Arab countries. This is no time for geopolitical games and propaganda with mutual accusations. We need to help, we need to restore statehood and security in this region, any postponement leads to thousands more refugees to our sea and land borders. It's been a while. If the civilized world does not act now, even more difficult times await us in the future.

name: Tonino Picula (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, as we try to find a way to take care of the hundreds of thousands of refugees arriving at our borders, thousands of European citizens working as economic migrants in the countries of North Africa and the Middle East should also be reminded. One of them is Tomislav Salopek, a 31-year-old Croatian citizen, a father of two, whose fate after his abduction in Egypt at the end of July is uncertain. Unfortunately, the published photos point to the worst – another barbaric act by the so-called Islamic State. However, this case stands out from others because Tomislav is a worker of a European company in Egypt, he did not reside in the territory occupied by the Islamic State, but unfortunately he was not provided with adequate protection. This indicates that the scale of the problem of the so-called The Islamic State is expanding than thought. I don't know what's more dramatic, the increasing influx of afflicted refugees or the lack of our coherent response to the problem where it arises. Let's send a clarice to European companies operating in these volatile areas: provide your workers who only want to secure a better future for their families.

name: Marijana Petir (PPE).
text: "Mr. President, I would like today to point out the events over which I am appalled and deeply shaken, but which hide from the public eye. The Center for Medical Progress released nine video clips that clearly show the Planned Parenthood Association of America is involved in illegally selling aborted babies' body parts. Video clips show that these activities are not limited to one institution, but are greatly expanded. Planned Parenthood Association of America is part of the International Planned Parenthood Federation, which is financed by the European Commission, among others, in generous amounts. The organisation's branches are located in most Member States of the European Union. Therefore, we cannot exclude the possibility that the same is not happening in the European Union. Taking into account the seriousness of this situation, I ask that an investigation be launched and the immediate cessation of funding for this organisation engaged in such intimidating and heasy illegal activities.

name: Adam Gierek (S&D).
text: – Climate change leads to extreme events, violent floods and catastrophic droughts. The large financial resources currently being spent on mitigating these changes are not able to reverse adverse trends. Climate discussions have dominated the issue of greenhouse gas emissions, while the increasingly pressing issue of adaptation to climate change is being pushed to the fore. The recent drought in Europe and later flooding is a clear alarm signal. This is an indication of the need to revalue the EU's climate policy, which should focus more on adaptation methods, including afforestation to mitigate climate change. And that's what the main funding should be directed to. In the case of my country, Polish, it will be, among other things, a necessity to return to the ambitious investment concept of the Vistula programme. Thank you.

name: Esther Herranz García (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, exactly one week ago today, a huge cliff, a tremendous hailstorm, ravaged 6,000 hectares of some counties in my region, La Rioja. Municipalities such as Tricio, Leiva, Nájera, Hormilleja, Hormilla, Azofra, Nalda, Islallana, Albelda or San Asensio saw crops such as vineyards, pears, as many fruits and also pepper shattered, all with denomination of origin. Go from here, of course, a recognition of all those citizens who have already set out to clean their streets, premises, homes and so on to continue their work.  But what this has shown is that only 20% of producers had agricultural insurance to cover these enormous damages. I draw the attention of Members and the European Commission here in order to carry out information campaigns to producers on the benefit that agricultural insurance brings to them and to make available a budgetary envelope for these agricultural insurance to be co-financed with European money.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: – There are European governments that see European solidarity as a one-way street. They accept the European Union's money, but they refuse to take responsibility for anything. Such is the Hungarian Government, which is building a pointless barbed wire fence on the country's southern border and keeping the refugees who come to us in inhumane conditions. This government is preparing to pass a law in the Hungarian Parliament next week that will also be able to use the military against refugees from weakened war zones. And, of course, he finds the culprit, he's looking for a scapegoot. After all, it has put forward a proposal for a parliamentary resolution blaming the European Union, including you, my fellow Members, for the deaths of refugees and the development of this refugee situation. However, thank God, the Hungarian government is not equal to the Hungarian people. The Hungarian people have passed the test of humanity in recent weeks. I would therefore like to thank the Hungarian civilians, volunteers and migration aid staff for showing that we are not the same as our government, what is more important... (The President has withdrawn the floor from the Member.)

name: Jaromír Štětina (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this Saturday I met the Kurdish commander, Nesrin Abdullah, in Prague, who played an important role in liberating the city of Kobani from ISIS forces. Armed Kurdish forces play an essential role in the fight against ISIS and deserve the support of the European Union.  Last year, the Czech Republic supplied 500 tons of ammunition to the Iraqi Kurds. I call from here on the governments of the European Union countries to support the Syrian Kurds as far as possible by supplying ammunition and infantry weapons. The Syrian Kurds greatly appreciate the intervention of coalition aircraft against ISIS, but at the same time believe that only a ground operation is possible to root out this evil. I therefore recommend that the European Union initiate negotiations on this possibility with NATO. It would be a good gesture if the European Parliament invited representatives of Syrian Kurdish fighters to Brussels or Strasbourg to introduce ourselves. Let us not forget that the existence of ISIS is one of the main causes of mass migration to Europe.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes this item.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Richard Corbett's report on the procedures and practices at the hearings of Commissioners – lessons to be learned from the 2014 procedure (2015/2040(INI)) (A8-0197/2015).

name: Richard Corbett
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, sometimes what we do here is an example that national parliaments might consider emulating – just sometimes – and, in my view, the process we have of holding public hearings of candidates for the Commission, before we take our vote of confidence on the Commission as a whole, is an example that they might consider. Just imagine how it would be if, when a government takes office in a national parliament, each minister, before taking office, had to go for a three-hour public grilling, with incisive questioning. I think it would be revealing. We do it here, and it is to our credit, but what we do can always be improved, and my report has been about looking at how we operate this system and making a number of suggestions for improvement. Let me highlight just three. The first is about the questioning – the incisive nature of the questions. We had at the last hearings, I think, 42 questions by individual Members to Commissioners and 42 answers. I propose that we cut that number to about 25, but allow each questioner to come back with a follow-up question. That would be more incisive: it would permit a real to and fro. The purpose of the hearings is not to give the floor to a maximum number of Members: the purpose is to get precise information and answers out of the candidate Commissioners. The second proposal to improve things is to look at how we evaluate the Commissioners after the hearings. At the moment, the coordinators from each Group have a meeting, but our rules are not very clear on this. Indeed, our rules as they currently read could require a vote in every single committee, on every single Commissioner, at the request of just one Political Group. I do not think that is wise because formally, legally, the only vote that matters is the vote by Parliament as a whole on the Commission as a whole. The vote by individual committees on individual Commissioners has no legal consequence. Therefore, we have to make sure it has political consequences and carries weight. In other words, a vote should be taken on a Commissioner only in a case of genuine doubt, and not as a matter of routine. Then, if as we have seen in the past there is a negative verdict, it will have consequences. That is how I think we should proceed, and my report proposes to clarify the procedures in that regard. A final point I would mention is the question of gender balance in the Commission. This Parliament has always attached importance to improving the gender imbalance that has existed up to now, but of course we are tied by the nominations that come from national governments if they all nominate just one candidate. Last time, however, there was at least one country which nominated two and allowed the President of the Commission to choose. Why do we not institutionalise that and propose – as a parliament we can only propose in this case – that each country’s government nominates two candidate Commissioners at least, one of each gender, two people in whom the national government has full confidence? The Commission President would then be in a better position to get gender balance in the team as a whole, and that would go some way to improving the balance. There are some other suggestions in this report, but those are three worth highlighting. I urge colleagues to read the other suggestions as well because they all would improve the situation.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Ever since I became an MEP, I have been very upset about this issue. First of all, I have found that we have a really undeled system of appointing Commissioners, and I have already suggested in this House a few times that we should do everything we can to ensure that the President of the Commission, elected here in Parliament, has every opportunity to choose the maximum competent and sexually balanced team. The current way, if I may focus only on the nomination, on the recruitment of Commissioners from the Member States, is not good. I agree with you, Rapporteur, that it would be right for the Member States to nominate at least two candidates, a man and a woman. Ideally, however, we would also propose different types of expert profiles of candidates, so that later the President of the European Commission could have the maximum choice and create a maximum competent and balanced team of Commissioners.

name: Biljana Borzan (S&D).
text: – Mr. President, I would like to thank my colleague Corbett and other colleagues on the other committees with whom I have had the opportunity to work on this report. Hearings of candidates for European Commissioners is a process that gives the European Union, and in particular Parliament, great attention and great visibility. Since we then elect the people who will hold the most responsible positions and positions in the European Commission for the next five years, we must make sure that they are competent, qualified and that their morality is unquestionable. The hearing process exposes commissioners to the public who are scissing their lives and careers, and that's the way it should be. However, I believe that we need to include citizens of the European Union in the whole process so that they can participate in hearings with their questions. I am extremely pleased that my proposal to extend the financial interest check to family members has also been entered into the final document. In conclusion, we want member states to propose both a man and a woman, i.e. two candidates, each time so that we have real gender equality.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, I believe that the procedure for hearing Commissioners is a very important process because that is how democratic control is shaped. Can the European Parliament really exercise its rights and give – when necessary – a vote of confidence, as a whole, to the Commission itself. Of course, the process must be more open to society itself. Citizens must also be able to participate. I had the opportunity, like you, to take part in this process last year. We received many e-mails from citizens who raised issues for various commissioners- candidates. I think that, as Members, we need to have a bigger role and we need to have more time to ask questions. We shouldn't leave the whole game to the moderators. Finally, I would like to raise a key issue and stress that the Commission must be a truly independent body – as we want it – and not just serve the Troika. This is very important, Mr Timmermans.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I respect Mr Corbett’s attempt to make the Commission a little more accountable, even if it is merely a drop in the ocean. There are some good suggestions here and also in the committee opinions. Allowing follow-up questions and genuine scrutiny is a great idea, for example. And, who knows, if we introduce something like that in the European Parliament itself, we might get something approaching a real debate here too. But we are completely ignoring the elephant in the Chamber. Commissioners hold huge power and yet we are given the opportunity to interview just one potential candidate. I can think of another union which used to love elections with just one candidate. Ultimately, though, the problem is that it is we, here in this Chamber, who give away those positions of huge power. The people have no say. Unelected Commissioners are unaccountable Commissioners.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Mr President, I am tempted to ask Mr Arnott how many candidates he can hear in the House of Commons, let alone in the House of Lords, but we shall not go into that debate. I want to thank the rapporteur, Mr Corbett, for his excellent and well—reflected report on a topic that Members will understand is of great relevance for the Commission. The Commission welcomes and fully supports the pursued objective of making the hearings a more flexible and dynamic exchange. The hearings not only allow for Parliament’s scrutiny of the Commission, in line with the Treaty, but also provide an important window for citizens on the workings of the Union. Incidentally, I was a Minister in a national government, then I became a Commissioner and all of a sudden, in the media, I went from being in some quarters a politician to an anonymous bureaucrat, whereas the scrutiny I went through in this Parliament was much tougher than the scrutiny I had to face in the national parliament in the Netherlands before becoming a Minister. By the way, in quite a number of Member States – because the second objection you always get is ‘unelected’ – how many governments do you suppose there are (I do not know the exact number, but there are quite a number of governments) where Ministers are not elected? Parliaments are all elected like this Parliament. So it is very often simply a matter of perception.  For the Commission, it is of foremost importance that the hearings are conducted in an open, fair and consistent manner. In particular, hearings for all Commissioners-designate should follow the same approach for questions and answers, both in the written and in the oral phase, and for the evaluation of each Commissioner-designate. For Vice-Presidents-designate, who have a horizontal responsibility spanning the competences of a larger number of EP committees, it is indeed appropriate to foresee that hearings are carried out in an adapted format, such as an open Conference of Presidents.  More generally, the confirmation period should be enough time to ensure that the new Commission can take up office immediately on the normal expiry of the previous Commission’s mandate. In this context, the Commission supports the call on Member States to make timely and gender-balanced nominations for candidate Commissioners.  As to the conduct of the hearings, the Commission supports the envisaged increase of written questions from five to seven, on condition that sub—questions are abandoned. The Commission also welcomes the limitation of questions in the oral phase to 25, with the possibility of immediate follow—up questions.  In principle, the Commission supports Parliament’s objective to ensure that the hearing process is accessible and transparent for EU citizens. Hearings are, however, for the elected Members of Parliament to exercise their scrutiny on Commissioners-designate. Therefore, it is the right of Members of the European Parliament to directly put questions to Commissioners—designate.  The Commission is open to considering how best to facilitate Parliament’s examination of potential conflicts of interest of Commissioners-designate. Should the Commission consider it appropriate to come forward with an amendment to its Code of Conduct, it will seek Parliament’s opinion, as foreseen by the Framework Agreement.  To ensure that Commissioners-designate are evaluated exclusively with regard to their personal competencies and knowledge of the envisaged portfolio, the Commission maintains that the results of the evaluation of each Commissioner-designate should be published individually within 24 hours after completion of her/his evaluation.  As for horizontal issues affecting the composition and structure of the Commission as a whole, the Commission recalls the need to fully respect each Institution’s competences and prerogatives. The Commission looks forward to examining the concrete proposals for amendments to Parliament’s Rules of Procedure regarding the hearings of Commissioners—designate. I would like once again to thank Mr Corbett for a job very well done from the Commission’s perspective.

name: Richard Corbett
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I did save one minute of my speaking time to be able to come back at the end, but I will be very brief. Firstly, I am pleased that I gather there is quite a high level of consensus between the Groups in Parliament on what I have proposed. I was also delighted that Mr Timmermans, for the Commission, went through in detail some of the things that I did not have time to cover in my speech, and that the Commission is very supportive of the thrust of what I propose – indeed, almost everything, bearing in mind his caveat that the devil can sometimes be in the detail. I am very glad of that support. I thank him very much, and may I at the same time thank him for his earlier speech, which was an exemplary reply in the previous debate on human rights.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: That concludes. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015.

name: Der Präsident. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the brief presentation of Marietje Schaake's report on "Human rights and technology: the impact of spying and surveillance systems on human rights in third countries" (2014/2232(INI)) (A8-0178/2015).

name: Marietje Schaake
text: rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to say to the shadow rapporteurs in particular that I enjoyed our discussions and cooperation on this report on human rights and technology, so thank you very much. In addition, I would like to thank the people from all over the world who have shared their input and suggestions. Many did so online and they have made the draft text that we voted on in the Committee on Foreign Affairs, and will vote on tomorrow in this House, a lot stronger. I think crowdsourcing works. Technological developments have a major impact on human rights, both to advance them and to restrict them. They can advance access to information, freedom of expression and association, but the documentation and sharing of human rights abuses or uncovering of corruption have benefited too from mobile phones and access to the open Internet for more people. Disaster relief, aid efforts, election monitoring, they increasingly rely on technologies to help emancipate and empower people.  However, technological systems can be and are also misused as tools for human rights violations through censorship, mass surveillance, tracking and tracing of individuals, unauthorised access to devices, jamming, interception and a lot more. So besides technological specifications, the context in which ICTs are used determines to a great extent whether these tools advance or violate human rights: what country, which user or buyer, and what legal safeguards or democratic oversight are in place.  These contextual aspects should be assessed carefully in EU policies. More transparency and accountability in the market of the most intrusive and damaging technologies is key, both for security and for human rights. This is too often presented as a false dichotomy between security and freedom or actually justifying restrictions to peoples’ rights and freedoms in the name of advancing security when in fact they should reinforce each other and, at the very least, EU-made systems should not be sold in an unrestricted market. Without smart policies, proliferation of these systems is inevitable and in fact I am sure that we here in the EU institutions, the European External Action Service, struggle to protect our own people, our own diplomats and our own information from the very same systems that we are discussing here. Intelligence services, criminal networks, hackers with bad intentions, all can buy and use intrusive technologies that are made in Europe.  The credibility of Europe’s foreign policy is undermined directly when an Italian company unjustly gets a licence to sell to Sudan or Russia, or when a French company sells digital keys to open any door, even the ones we may think are protected or locked by passwords, or much stronger measures. But, much worse, human rights defenders in Mexico, Azerbaijan, Colombia, Egypt, Turkey, Iran or Russia should be protected by EU policies and not harmed with the help of EU-made technologies.  In concluding, EU policy should mainstream human rights in the way that technologies are designed and used and mainstream the role of technologies throughout all human rights policies, and this report presents many concrete ideas. One of the strong recommendations is that there should not be a ban on encryption technologies or requirements to hand over the keys. Instead, we, through our EU policy, should train and equip journalists, human rights defenders and others facing repression and violations with the knowledge and the tools to protect themselves and their communications. Europe has the opportunity and should have the ambition to be a global leader in ensuring technologies benefit human rights and this is only possible if we lead by example.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I would like to thank you for presenting this report, because, in my opinion, it is indeed very important and is heading for the substance of the matter. That means, to some extent, the question of how much more is it able to sell our conscience for. For how much companies that do business in the European area are willing to sell their consciences in other countries, where, for example, they operate activities that are completely unthinkable in the Czech Republic or the European Union.  It is therefore a report on the extent to which all human rights are actually transferable to other countries. And I think we should have a very strong debate about that. I see that there are a number of fundamental human rights that are universal, which really represent a value for which other problems, such as employment, GDP, etc. can be put off in some way. But there are certainly human rights considerations that, unfortunately, the whole world has not yet shared with us. And we should be looking for that line firmly.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, the motion for a resolution highlights – I must say at last – the risks of compression and violation of human rights arising from the use of new technologies, in particular the Internet. It is clear from what I have said several times in two written statements last year on the ethics of technological innovation and e-health, as well as in numerous questions, that this is a risk inherent in the very use of these technologies.  This connoted, if not properly regulated, risks making any ex post control impossible, which is so true that in terms of human rights, even the simple use for a noble end of these technologies can make – and indeed makes – each of us more exposed and more vulnerable. The vulnus has therefore moved from the possible illegal practice, to the lawful act and consequently the regulation must cover every aspect, including those of common use, without neglecting the ethical questions related to it. I therefore agree with the motion for a resolution and the call for the inclusive and responsible participation of all involved: governments, civil society, the private sector and users.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, I congratulate Mrs. Schaake on her report and right at the beginning I want to say that the Internet has of course opened up great new expanses of freedom. However, this reminds me a bit of what one great man, Alfred Nobel, did, who invented dynamite believing that he would serve peacetime purposes, and later, as we know, served for wars. So is the Internet. In a way, he opened up great spaces of freedom, but on the other hand, the great dangers of abuse of that freedom. In particular, abuses of this freedom from dictatorial regimes with which, as we know, the European Union also trades and does large, lucrative deals. That is why it is good that this report warns of such facts, of the possibility of abusing our freedoms, and I believe that the Commission will also use the basis of this report in its future work.

name: Heidi Hautala (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, there is no doubt that ICT is a human rights issue. It is ‘both and’– it is both an advantage for people to communicate and spread knowledge of human rights violations, but it has also become something of a trap for people who defend human rights. Mrs Schaake has produced an excellent report which we have to defend in the vote.  I think we should be ready to recognise that the complicity of some enterprises, including some from the EU area, has greatly damaged our reputation by creating serious human rights violations in Iran, in Uzbekistan, in Belarus and in other countries, and I am talking about some telecommunications providers, that is Astellia, Sonora, Nokia, Siemens. I think we also have to defend the point in the report which says that the service providers and the network providers should publish reports about their connections between themselves and oppressive regimes. We have also to protect whistle—blowers.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, there is actually quite a lot of good stuff in this report. I believe that we must take great care to avoid unnecessary censorship – particularly of the Internet – although I personally believe that is best achieved through national governments, rather than through EU diktat. However, I would like to draw your attention to paragraph 17 of the report. This paragraph is all about the politicisation of trade. It is about imposing our Western values upon third countries as a condition of trade with developing nations. To me this is not only unacceptable but also supremely arrogant because it assumes that we know better than developing countries what their laws should be, and that we can tell them what they ought to be doing. This is riding roughshod over their sovereignty, and I cannot support a report which contains such phrasing.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I want to thank Ms Schaake for this excellent report. Reading it, you sometimes get a bit of flavour of Dave Erus and his writings about the downsides of modern technology and the ICT world. The report contains a number of very timely, pertinent and often challenging ideas and recommendations for action. The Commission appreciates the strong call to the EU to step up its efforts and strengthen the link between human rights, digital freedom, development, Internet governance, trade and security. This same message can also be found in the Digital Single Market Strategy recently adopted by the Commission. The EU is committed to promoting human rights in all areas of its external action. Nowadays, given the increasing importance of ICT in our daily lives and the expansion of Internet access and access to mobile telephony, the promotion of human rights online and offline and the linkage between new technologies and human rights are key to our endeavours towards promoting human rights and democracy worldwide. We therefore share the European Parliament’s view that ICTs are key in safeguarding and fostering human rights and fundamental freedoms. We also share the concern voiced in the report that certain fundamental rights, notably the right to freedom of expression and information, the right to privacy and the protection of personal data, may be violated as a result of unlawful or arbitrary surveillance, censorship, the unlawful interception of communications, or the collection of personal data, in particular when carried out on a mass scale and not for legitimate purposes. This requires us all to unite in our efforts to protect fundamental rights. We need to promote the development of democratic oversight capabilities in order to monitor activities by intelligence and law enforcement services, lest these are used to suppress dissent and free speech. This is firmly anchored in the EU guidelines for freedom of expression online and offline, and we are highly committed to promoting these guidelines in our relations with third countries. That is also why the Commission is very supportive of, and welcomes, the appointment of the United Nations Special Rapporteur on the Right to Privacy. It is very important to ensure that our response to terrorist attacks does not impact negatively on fundamental rights, notably freedom of expression and information and the right to privacy. The European Security Agenda adopted by the Commission this year has made clear, therefore, that the Commission will strictly test any security measures for compliance with fundamental rights, while ensuring their effectiveness. The EU is committed to assisting human rights defenders, civil society activists, and independent journalists to use ICTs to fight for freedom. The EU is also active in defending media freedom and pluralism, and has launched two new independent projects within the framework of the European Centre for Press and Media Freedom, with the support of this Parliament. The projects will address media freedom violations in the EU and neighbouring countries and promote action to support threatened journalists, complemented by digital training. The European Union has also adopted sanctions to prevent authoritarian regimes using technologies to crack down on human rights defenders, for example in the case of Syria. In addition to country-specific sanctions, the EU is reviewing its export controls to prevent exports of sensitive technologies that could be misused in violation of human rights. In December 2014 we introduced new controls on exports of intrusion software and of internet monitoring technologies, and we are further exploring options to extend export controls to rapidly evolving cyber-surveillance technologies that might be used for Internet monitoring and/or telecommunication surveillance in violation of human rights. As Ms Schaake writes in the report, there is indeed a need to mainstream the impact of technologies on the improvement of human rights in all the EU’s external action. The Commission and the External Action Service are working together towards this goal. ICTs have helped to promote freedom on a global scale, and preserving the benefits of freedom is a shared responsibility for all of us – the private sector, civil society, governments, international organisations and individuals. The European Union stands, therefore, ready to reiterate its commitment to promote unhindered, uncensored and non-discriminatory access to ICTs.
