name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Petri Sarvamaa, on behalf of the Committee on Budgetary Control, on protecting the European Union’s financial interests: towards performance-based controls of the Common Agricultural Policy (2014/2234(INI)) (A8-0240/2015).

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: rapporteur. – Madam President, we need efficiency. Checking 40 million transactions and other common agricultural policy controls costs around EUR 4 billion a year. As the rules and regulations governing the CAP have only got more diverse and complex it is expected that monitoring costs of the almost EUR 58 billion CAP budget will only grow if nothing is done.  So as I said, the cost is currently estimated at EUR 4 billion at Member State level. The farmers face a never-ending mountain of paperwork which has to be submitted to national officials, with increasingly complex regulations and control measures.  A Finnish farmer illustrated the absurdity perfectly by displaying next to each other all of the official forms demanded annually by the national authorities. The documents ended up stretching over 33 metres in length. That is approximately the length of two full rows of EPP Members in this Chamber and that is a long, long line.  If we do not manage to streamline the CAP and ease the burden of controls on farmers, we cannot hope to attract new entrants to agriculture. It will be a struggle to even retain the current beneficiaries.  But this is not just a matter of agriculture. Complex rules and controls of those rules inevitably mean that taxpayers’ money is not spent efficiently. Even worse, with inefficiency comes uncertainty about correct and responsible use of EU funds. The promotion of performance-based controls can be an answer to some of those questions. The report at hand insists that the definition of performance in respect of controls should primarily entail the quality of the Member States’ checks and administrative systems: that is, the efficiency, consistency and reliability of the managing and certifying authorities.  In order to ease the burden on the beneficiaries, the authorities should aim to organise on-site checks in a way that would not subject the farmer to multiple annual on-site checks by the national authorities, the Commission or the Court of Auditors. This should be done by advancing and implementing the famous single audit scheme that we have been waiting for too long.  Furthermore, the report advocates identifying the best and worst performing Member States in its policy area, with the best performing States being rewarded with a reduction in controls. Now in some quarters this is being suspected of not being in accordance with the basic ideas of the Union, but let me underline that this fear is in vain: it is indeed in accordance with those ideas. And a key part of this approach is the sharing of experience and best practices with the worst performing States.  The key factor behind the thinking of the report is this: simplification is inevitable. The Commission is on this path and so should this Parliament be.  Your rapporteur has been driven by the ultimate desire to release farmers from behind their desks into the fields and simultaneously provide better control for taxpayers’ money.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I believe that the best PR of this institution is the results it achieves. Nothing speaks better than the results we achieve together here, and I believe that what Mr. Sservama does is precisely such an outcome, because the programming period 2007- 2013 taught us something very important, and it is that long procedures, many documents, long queues do not help us. If I can summarize my hundreds of meetings with beneficiaries of European funds in several things, then they will be as follows: We need to dramatically shorten the time from submission of documents to real repayment of funds; we need to base risk control – those who do well should be checked less, those who perform poorly should be checked more. We need to get away from the paper and use as many electronic services as possible so that people don't line up, but file their paperwork from home with less waiting. I believe that with all this we can not help but optimize the funds for spending management and controlling European projects.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, during the two rounds of reform of the common agricultural policy, the rules have become more heterogeneous and complex, and it is well known that for more complex rules they also lead to more errors.  The objectives of the CAP can only be properly implemented by means of effective simplification and debureaucratisation, minimising the cost of controls, which already amounts to around EUR 4 billion. I have noticed that all too often the paying agencies make inaccurate statements. The Commission had to revise upwards the error rates reported by as many as 42 out of 68 paying agencies. Proposals should be drawn up to penalise paying agencies.  (The President asked to speak more slowly) Proposals should be drawn up to penalise paying agencies, in the event of false declarations, to the point where the Commission can revoke the recognition of paying agencies in the event of serious inaccuracies. It is necessary to develop criteria to define which Member States perform best and which are the worst performing, so as to implement a programme for the dissemination of best practices. In short, we need a new rationalised CAP, a cap geared to farmers. Only in this way can we effectively reach the targets we set ourselves.

name: Bronis Ropė (Verts/ALE).
text: – I would like to congratulate the initiative, calling on the European Commission to make use of the process of simplifying the common agricultural policy. What is important is that this simplification would benefit not sofa farmers, but those who live out of agriculture. It is this life that shows how important greening is, because it is about responsible farming, one that is engaged in by people living in the countryside and working from generation to generation. Another important aspect is that it is important to take into account that the rules have changed consider a significant change in the new period, and I believe it is necessary for the Commission to encourage agencies not only to use fines if any error is found, but, on the contrary, to start with much less lenient measures: warning, training and everything else.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the bureaucracy and complexity of the common agricultural policy are affecting farmers and are one of the issues that the European Union must address. The system must be simplified if the common agricultural policy aid is to be improved and increased. The major problems of agriculture must be answered. In my country Greece, the greek farmers who are poor from the memorandum are unable to afford it, as last year they were tested by the disasters that hit production in my country. At the same time, the tax raid they have experienced and continue to experience under orders from the Troika has been illegally extended to the Community aid they receive. Over the past five years, the income of Greek farmers has fallen by 1.5 billion euros while taxes have increased by 150%. At the same time, the crisis that hit agriculture as a result of the Russian embargo economically destroyed Greek farmers. For these reasons, there must be an immediate increase in aid to the poor greek farmers from the memoranda.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, we are discussing a very important issue, having before us the excellent report drawn up by an excellent colleague, touching the problem at his heart. After what he said, we don't have to contribute and add much. The key word is 'efficiency' and we understand what it means when we consider the problem of 50 million transactions which are controls, which cost EUR 4 billion and which actually account for 7% of the money we give for the common agricultural policy. In other words, out of every EUR 100 we give, EUR 7 goes exclusively to checks. If, in the end, we are not prepared to take advantage of this important report and solve the problem at its root, then the rural economy will also be affected, and our farmers will suffer and win again the bureaucracy that kills every prospect and every development. It is therefore an opportunity to support our farmers by removing the administrative burden and by giving – I will propose an innovative proposal – the possibility of self-control in the agricultural sector.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, of course the simplification of the common agricultural policy is a way to reduce the number of controls on the spot. Simpler rules mean that it is going to be easier to implement them, easier for farmers to work with them and easier for authorities to check up on them. As some of you have said, Phil Hogan has already started with this simplification exercise and it is well advanced. We have received many contributions from all stakeholders. Some changes have already been implemented and the Commission will present more proposals in the coming months. However, we do not have to wait for new rules to impact on the number of controls farmers face. The current legislation allows Member States with reliable management and control systems to reduce the level of the spot checks. Some Member States have expressed interest in taking advantage of this possibility. The Commission services are working closely with them to ensure all conditions for this reduction are met. Of course we want simple rules and better application, but we also have a great responsibility in ensuring that taxpayers’ money is not misappropriated and does not end up where it should not. Member States are also encouraged, in the current legislation, to organise their controls in a way that reduces the burden for farmers. Let us not forget either that only 5% of farmers are subject to on-the-spot checks for compliance with CAP rules. Most of the controls they are faced with result from national laws and from cross-compliance requirements, which do not originate from CAP legislation. Obviously, to most farmers it does not make any difference whether a rule comes from Brussels or from their own country: they are faced with rules and they want fewer of them. They are absolutely right. They should be farming and not involved in constant bureaucracy. But we believe that Member States could, in so far as possible, try to group their own controls with those resulting from CAP obligations, and perhaps they could also learn more from each other than they do today. As I said, controls are, and will remain, necessary. If the EU legislator or the Member States has specified a conditional requirement to be respected before aid can be paid, then there needs to be a check that this condition or requirement has been met. The more numerous or complex the requirements, the more numerous or complex the controls. Taxpayers have the right to know whether subsidies from the EU budget are being spent according to the rules, and we will therefore not accept any proposal that might compromise the sound financial management of the EU budget. Finally, we should ask ourselves whether an error rate of 2% is, per se, the appropriate benchmark for a complex policy such as the CAP and, more concretely, rural development. In that context, we should also raise the issue of the acceptable relation between the cost and the benefits of controls. Any reflection that does not attempt to tackle this question would really be a missed opportunity. The common agricultural policy is, and will remain, a cornerstone of EU policies. It is in our common interest that this policy be as effective as possible and that it retain the support of farmers and citizens. Taxpayers will want to be sure that their money is well spent. I would like to thank Mr Sarvamaa very much for his report, which will be added to the contributions to the ongoing debate about simplification of the CAP.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Daniel Buda (PPE)
text: in writing. – There are 12 million farmers living in the EU, for whom agriculture is a permanent occupation (agriculture and the agri-food industry, which is dependent on the agricultural sector for supply). 500 million consumers in Europe depend on a reliable and affordable source of food. The CAP was created to help farmers in Europe, but the complexity of this policy and its bureaucracy have increased significantly in recent years for both competent authorities and farmers.  A CAP that can be clearly implemented and interpreted is needed in order to reduce the error rate. It is necessary to develop tools to demonstrate errors in cases of fraud, while ensuring that farmers can continue delivering food production. Furthermore, the Commission must consider eliminating the differences between European farmers, given that in some countries subsidies are below EU level, which is a huge handicap in competition with farmers from other EU countries. The Commission's initiative to simplify the CAP is welcome, with immediate consideration of the measures that can be implemented, benefiting farmers, paying agents, the institutions of the European Union and taxpayers. This would make it easier for the administrative tasks that arise.

name: Beata Gosiewska (ECR)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The four billion euros currently spent on control costs and providing advice to stakeholders and farmers is far too much. It is scandalous that so much money is being allocated to this purpose in the face of the crisis caused by the Russian embargo or the droughts that have affected Poland and other countries in Central and Eastern Europe. Unfortunately, the recent reform of the common agricultural policy (CAP) has contributed to a further diversification of the rules, which consequently leads to more errors on the ground. However, these costs may increase as a result of the implementation of the latest reform, in particular due to the introduction of greening measures. Therefore, simplifying and de-bureaucraticing the CAP should be a priority for us. I support mr Sarvamy's report because I believe that it is necessary to improve the quality of controls, not to increase them by the Member States, the Commission or the Court of Auditors. Cap bureaucracy needs to be reduced and a system of instruments in place to actually distinguish error from abuse.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Angelika Niebler, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on family businesses in Europe (2014/2210(INI)) (A8-0223/2015).

name: Angelika Niebler
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, Mr Vice-President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. First of all, I would like to express my sincere thanks to all my fellow Members – not only in my own group, but also in the other groups – for their support in drawing up the report on family businesses in Europe. It was really a beautiful and very interest-oriented collaboration. You probably all know the well-known company names, the De Longhi, Lego, Heineken, Oetker, Clarins and as they are all called – manufacturers of high-quality products that are known not only in their home country, but beyond european borders. These whole companies have one thing in common, ladies and gentlemen: these are family businesses that have existed for decades and are good at business. However, there are not only the large, successful family businesses, but in the European Union we have a total of around 14 million family businesses. All family businesses have some similarities: they think and act sustainably, they inherit their business from generation to generation, they have a close bond, a high social responsibility towards their workforce, their workforce, and usually they are very faithful to their location. In other words, they do not move from one place to another when the tax legislation is perhaps a little cheaper in one country or another. No, they also have a responsibility in their region, they remain in the region and are therefore just as important for the local city or community as they are for competitiveness in Europe. Everything – stability, renewal and growth – in the area of family businesses ultimately also favours our European economy and the growth that we so desperately need in the European Union. Many of the family businesses are small and medium-sized enterprises, but not all. There are many family businesses which have around 500 to 1 000 employees and are therefore unfortunately not covered by the definition of SMEs. And yet these larger family businesses also have the same problems as SMEs: they suffer from too much bureaucracy, from complicated tax systems, from too little support. At the same time, however, they do not benefit from special Support for SMEs. That is why I think it is right to ask ourselves the question here in Parliament too: should we perhaps move away from purely quantitative criteria when defining SMEs, should we not also take greater account of qualitative criteria, such as the interdependence of property, control and management, the risk of liability? In any case, we finally need an EU-wide definition of family business, which is also suitable for statistical offices in the Member States and with which work can be carried out. Family businesses all have the same problems almost all over Europe. One is the search for a suitable successor, which is very often difficult for many family businesses. Statistics say that every year there are about 150 000 companies that have problems that have to close because they cannot find suitable successors. If we convert this into jobs, we are talking about 600 000 jobs that are lost every year. And, of course, family businesses usually also have a significantly higher equity ratio than non-family companies. This leads to economic stability for businesses and for the economy as a whole. That is why this must be taken into account when investing. It is no wonder that companies in all Member States are complaining about excessive taxation. Equity that remains in the region invested to maintain operations should be spared tax burdens as much as possible. I urge the Commission to return to family businesses. Six years ago, there was a working group in the Commission which devoted itself to this chapter. Nothing has happened since then. I think that if we want growth, prosperity and employment in the European Union, as is our aim, then we must take into account the specificities of family businesses and simply ask ourselves: how can we give even more support to these family-run businesses – our backbone, also industry and the economy in the European Community – how can we better support them in their problems? There will be a lot of damage at national level. But I think that the best practices comparison and a clear commitment also at European level to promote and support these strong family businesses is an honourable thing. And that is why I would like to ask tomorrow for support for my report.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE).
text: – I would like to thank my colleague Angelika Niebler for her excellent text. The subject of family business that I have proposed will be adopted by Parliament in this plenary thanks to Angelica, and I believe that it will also be an inspiration to the Commission. Multigenerational family businesses strengthen the economy and set an example in social responsibility. It is therefore important to promote their value integrity and to guarantee them, as legal persons, the freedoms enshrined in the Charter of Fundamental Rights in the practice of values in business. Family businesses have specific needs. I believe that the adopted report will lead to an improvement in their position, because strengthening family entrepreneurship will help to increase employment, especially in economically weaker regions. At the same time, it can lead young people to work habits, because their absence is one of the most common reasons for youth unemployment in the European Union.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Madam President, this is a particularly important report because family businesses traditionally form the backbone of the European economy. Their survival and growth are crucial for creating a positive economic, social and demographic picture of the European continent, so I am pleased that the rapporteur recognises this. I would also agree with the need to internationalise the operations of these companies, as many of them have huge potential that remains untapped in local or regional business. In doing so, I believe that removing the administrative burden that increases production and trade is the most important step in the process of opening small family businesses to the Common European Market. Redundant regulation favours large economic operators and undermines the creation of monopolies, not only destroying the tradition of European family businesses, but also putting at risk 60% of the private sector jobs provided by these companies.

name: Eva Kaili (S&D).
text: – Madam President, allow me on behalf of the S&D Group to thank our colleague Angelika Niebler for her great report on family businesses, which are an important and vital element in the functioning of the European economy, especially in the most remote and peripheral areas of the EU. For the S&D Group it is particularly important that we stress with this report the significance of size when we are talking about family businesses, and we would like to underscore the social role that family businesses play in the European economy – on the path to recovery of course – and also the necessary standards for those working in family businesses, the quality of jobs and the need for everyone to have social insurance and a pension plan. We also want to ensure that we keep the references in this report to the balance between genders, the importance of smoothing transfers of ownership and management from generation to generation, and the tax burden. Last but not least, we expect the Commission to take the initiative to strengthen the framework in which family businesses operate in the EU today, and to improve their access to information, educational programmes and financial resources.

name: Juan Carlos Girauta Vidal (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, first of all, thanks to the rapporteur. Having said that, it is incredible that, as shadow rapporteur for this report, I do not have allotted time for debate in plenary.  But I am not going to waste the seconds left complaining to me, rather I am interested in highlighting the relevance of a report which draws attention to the great contribution that the family business makes to the European economy and which recalls how important it is to work to achieve a common definition that allows us to know the situation and challenges of these companies; create rules that simplify the process of transferring family businesses, often complicated by the application not only of commercial law, but also of inheritance law; promote innovation and the use of communication and information technologies to increase the potential scope of consumers; create a one-stop shop that provides them with all administrative procedures and includes in European educational curricules information on the characteristics of the management of a family business.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her I would also like to thank the rapporteur for her initiative and for showing the importance of family businesses in Europe. Europe has a very special significance here: about half of the top 500 family-owned companies in the world are based in Europe, which shows the dimension.  The top 10 companies in this sector generate about one hundred billion euros of European GDP and employ 2.5 million people. Overall, family businesses in Europe account for 13 percent of gross domestic product and 3.2 percent of total employment, while companies are 90 years old on average. Family businesses are much more competitive than other companies, they are geared towards long-term success, and the takeover – as has already been mentioned today – plays a very special role.  The report also highlighted the fact that some 480 000 companies were taken over each year in Europe. We have heard that there is probably no suitable successor for 150. It's a big issue. This is where policymakers must create the framework conditions. Equity – a second important issue – and the recognition of structures, namely ownership of family businesses, in addition to tax matters, framework conditions, non-wage labour costs, which are essential for the maintenance of these family structures.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, Mrs Niebler, for her excellent report.  Europe’s family businesses are important economic actors and deserve attention. Across Europe, about 70% of enterprises are family businesses and they account for between 40% and 50% of employment.  The most effective way to help family businesses is to address their problems in existing SMEs or industry-related policies such as the creation of a supportive business environment or participation in the various European Union funding programmes.  Family businesses need a level playing field when the implementation of national or EU policies has an impact on them. A number of points mentioned in the report have, to a large extent, already been addressed by the Commission, for example the contact points, the collection of statistical data and the need for vocational training for younger family members. However, we are ready to look at these issues with you again and, if needed, to take further steps to improve the situation.  There are also a number of important problems that are family-business specific and need special attention, like the smooth transfer of business to the next generation and its fiscal consequences. As you know, taxation is a sole competence of Member States, so we have pointed out the issue of the family business to them, asking them for more growth—friendly tax policies at national level.  To make governments more sensitive to the issue of family businesses, we took action to make more visible the economic importance of the sector. In many Member States, unfortunately, there is no statistical information. For this reason, we are financing a number of national statistical offices to collect data on family businesses in order to get a clearer picture on them. The results will be known in about two years’ time. We are also running a project on identifying good practices and useful tools in preparing on-time transfer of businesses because, as I said, the transfer of businesses is a problem for many families. In your report, you also referred to the need to offer young family members entrepreneurship education and training. I would like to mention that there are various programmes, like Erasmus for young entrepreneurs, from which all younger members of the family business can benefit if they envision entrepreneurship as an attractive and realistic career option.  Concerning the role of women in family businesses, we promote and support women entrepreneurship in Europe with concrete actions, providing encouragement, advice and support to women entrepreneurs. Such measures include the European Network of Female Entrepreneurship Ambassadors, the European Network of Mentors for Women Entrepreneurs and, as from 2016 onwards, the online e-platform for women entrepreneurs.  I hope we can continue our dialogue to improve the position of family businesses in the European Union.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Ева Паунова (PPE)
text: in writing. – Europe can become a unique ecosystem of innovative enterprises if together we implement successful models to support entrepreneurs in all Member States. Family businesses represent a long-term view of growth prospects and are a stable factor in job creation. They can play an important role in encouraging more citizens to be active participants in local economies. This is the result of the high level of social responsibility that these enterprises have in relation to their employees. Unfortunately, there is no uniform development of family businesses in all EU Member States. Equal opportunities for entrepreneurs across Europe are therefore needed. Europe needs synchronised rules and policies that create business security, encourage innovation and help start-ups develop at national and international level.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by João Ferreira, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on untapping the potential of research and innovation in the blue economy to create jobs and growth (2014/2240(INI)) (A8-0214/2015). Mr Sylikiotis is deputising for Mr Ferreira.

name: Νεοκλής Συλικιώτης
text: , Deputy Rapporteur. Madam President, the rapporteur for the report, Mr João Ferreira, has unfortunately not been able to be with us today, and that is why I will present on his behalf the main objectives pursued by this report. We note, first of all, that the report takes into account the Commission's report entitled 'Innovation in the Blue Economy: Exploiting the Potential of Our Seas and Oceans in order to promote employment and growth', a document which has a great deal of room for improvement, since it has a limited scope and does not cover all sectors. The following new elements are therefore added: - there is dissatisfaction with the short- and long-term impact on national research programmes of cuts in public investment in research, development and innovation; 2020" on research and innovation proposed by the Commission.  The proper development of the blue economy requires decent occupations linked to it and the creation of quality jobs with rights. The report therefore urges the Commission and the Member States to integrate the gender dimension at all stages of the development of the blue economy, as well as to encourage and enhance the effective participation of women in it. The Commission is called upon to identify all European funds allocated to finance the activities of the blue economy and to concentrate them on a single platform, to which all citizens will have access. It is also stressed that the Commission should provide funds for innovation and blue growth to finance basic research, vocational training, job creation, start-ups, small and medium-sized enterprises, social economy enterprises, cooperatives, education, poverty reduction of coastal areas, the development of biotechnology, transport links, energy interconnection, coastal access to broadband services , the protection of the environment and the commercial exploitation of innovative products, services and partnerships.  Ladies and gentlemen, investment in the blue economy should focus, inter alia, on eco-innovation, resource efficiency, the circular economy, nature conservation, the protection of the marine and coastal environment, climate change mitigation and adaptation to and sustainable use of resources. The report therefore calls on the Commission to incorporate these principles into existing and future support programmes. It is equally important to establish an appropriate financial framework to boost innovation, sustainable development of the blue economy and job creation. This framework will combine, coordinate and facilitate access to available financial instruments, structural and investment funds, public institutions, local authorities and businesses, in particular small and medium-sized enterprises, and non-governmental organisations, in order to provide broad information on existing opportunities.  It is important to stress that public investment plays a key role in promoting growth and making full use of the potential of the blue economy. They must therefore be strengthened, without this meaning that we will overlook the role of private investment. Public companies or majority-owned companies in sectors such as commercial shipping, port management, shipbuilding and maritime and coastal protection projects also play a very important role. We therefore reject the emphasis only on the private sector. All these points are included in the report and we call on colleagues to vote in favour of it in order to strengthen European policy on the blue economy.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, the report is indeed interesting and raises very important points. The blue economy covers a particular wide range of activity, fisheries, aquaculture, maritime transport, tourism, navigation, cruises. It should, above all, be based on innovation and new technologies. This also means support for small and medium-sized enterprises, but also support for quality itself. It means support for renewable energy sources and forms of local cooperation. It means trying to create new jobs and develop new products. It means that we must have support for economic social and territorial cohesion in the European Union. This means additional cooperation between the regions themselves. Aid is therefore needed through the Structural Funds, through the Regional Development Fund itself and through the European Social Fund.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, when we talk about the blue economy we could really talk about many topics because the blue economy is an extremely wide area. Croatia, the country from which I come, is a country that has the Adriatic Sea, and the blue economy plays a very important role in the development of our country. However, something I want to emphasise in particular is the issue of shipbuilding, which is why I would like to make it clear to Commissioner Timmermans in particular that I believe that the European Union must work as much as possible with national countries and local and regional self-government units to finance research and innovation in shipbuilding.  The ship is a unique European product. A unique European product because it can be made up of various parts coming from different countries. That is why I urge us not to forget about European shipbuilding, which, as we know, still gives many jobs to this day and of course I expect it to do so in the future.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioners, we give the Commission an intense job in this report. It was a relatively simple and fragmented approach and we give it back, I believe, a coherent piece of much greater ambition and also of much greater demand. We are now talking about an integrated approach, a comprehensive approach, which is part of sustainability as a central concept, which, on the other hand, wants to avoid the traditional risks, if it is to be, of the centuries, that the Commission itself sometimes offers us as a line of action. We are therefore talking about the role that Europe must play in our seas; a now fragmented and sparsely coordinated role that must acquire power, strategy and coherence. We are talking about aquaculture and the sustainability with which it should be contemplated; we talk about the precautionary principle in mining activity on the seabed; we talk about the knowledge that we must acquire and share about the wonders of the sea, but also about the many mistakes we have already made.  We cannot repeat the mistakes made on earth; the sea deserves our respect and our best strategy to understand it in an intelligent way.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I suppose one of the biggest problems with these five-minute debates is that we cannot adequately do justice to a subject – 31 pages of a report in a 60—second speech. I agree that tidal power is the future, but I hope that we can learn from the mistakes of wind power. It is best to get the research and cost correct first and then introduce a new technology, not the other way around. I believe we are getting towards that point with tidal power and we need to continue the research.  I will just pick up one other point that I have time for: the suggestion to move to liquefied natural gas as a transitional fuel to help the environment. The word ‘transitional’ implies that it will require more than one change in an industry which, frankly, certainly in the UK, is already on its knees, so I would urge extreme caution in that because we do not want to sleepwalk into creating unemployment.

name: Barbara Kappel (ENF).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her  The term "blue economy" covers all sectors of the economy that feel connected to the sea and the oceans. The interface between land and sea is a particularly important one. The blue economy generates three to five percent of European GDP; employs 5.6 million people and contributes to European esteem with a value added volume of EUR 495 million.  The report clearly deals with the interaction between sea and land, noting that data from land and sea must be seen as a single entity and that sustainable management is of essential interest, essential, and the role of new technologies, and here we are addressing innovation and research in particular.  The fourth point I would like to mention is investment: the report criticises the fact that Horizon 2020 is intended to save money. This is particularly bad for the blue economy and, of course, for other sectors of the economy, and we need to catch up here. The blue economy must be adequately supported and promoted here.

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank the rapporteur, even though he is not here, and the members of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) for this very extensive and welcome report, which also takes account of the opinions of the Committee on Fisheries and the Committee on Employment and Social Affairs.  It is an important contribution to the EU’s Blue Growth agenda. It recognises the significant potential of the Blue Economy to create jobs and growth, and stresses the importance of action by the EU and its Member States to unlock this potential. The report stresses that the sustainability dimension must be fully embedded in our approach, and I can confirm that the Commission is wholeheartedly in agreement with this approach. We must indeed protect, restore and maintain coastal and oceanic ecosystems, biodiversity, resilience and productivity, keep the oceans free from pollutants and litter and apply the precautionary principle. Cross-sectoral and inter-disciplinary research and rolling-out of innovation will be essential to achieve these goals, along with support from Member States. We are also looking at promoting innovation in both emerging and more traditional maritime sectors.  The focus on marine knowledge and seabed mapping, the creation of the marine research information platform and the work on developing skills will boost innovation and job creation over the whole varied range of interacting sectors, including existing industries. For instance, there are two specific articles in the European Maritime and Fisheries Fund Regulation which focus on innovation and sustainable development of fisheries and aquaculture; and Horizon 2020, the Framework Programme for Research Innovation, supports a considerable amount of research in the traditional sectors. The European Fund for Strategic Investments also offers possibilities for projects with a higher risk profile. I was very happy to read that the report asks for a proper assessment of the size of the Blue Economy and appraisal of its financial needs. We are already working on this. We have now made some first estimates of the size of the Blue Economy and will be comparing notes with statisticians and economists from Member States later this month. Solid figures will no doubt also help us to measure progress in driving the Blue Industry forward.  We are also working on delivering some other key points of your report. For example, we are considering how to close the skills gap in the Blue Economy, and calls for proposals will be issued in 2016 to tackle this. We are also making progress on developing an information platform to make the results of marine and maritime research more easily available.  Finally, I could not agree more that a global level playing field is needed to further strengthen the EU’s position as a global leader in a sustainable Blue Economy. I have launched an international public consultation on what the EU needs to do to improve the governance of the oceans, including ensuring a sustainable use of ocean resources and guaranteeing a level playing field. I encourage you to contribute to this consultation. In conclusion, the Commission very much welcomes this report and looks forward to working closely with the European Parliament in realising the full potential of the Blue Economy.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Fabio Massimo Castaldo (EFDD)
text: in writing. For a country that, like ours, is made up of a peninsula, the sea is an important aspect of both social life and the economy. The activities connected with the sea are therefore many and important, precisely for this reason it must be safeguarded. The report seems to be along these lines and also recognises that account must be taken of the specific characteristics of the reference ecosystems in Europe, but in addition to the statements of principle it expresses ways of intervention that endanger those ecosystems themselves. No limit is placed on mining, and therefore on oil and natural gas drilling and drilling. This shows that the contribution of scientific studies in this area is not taken into account at all, and that the precautionary principle, which is the basis of the economic sustainability for which we will continue to fight, is completely neglected.

name: Miriam Dalli (S&D)
text: in writing. – Our seas are extremely diverse one from the other and a ‘one-size-fits-all’ policy will definitely defy the purpose for which we are standing here today. However, there is one common factor. Our seas offer an extreme vast economic and job creation potential in a period of time when we need to create both employment demand and supply. We need to ensure that whilst maximising the potential of our seas we ensure the protection of our maritime environment from any damaging effects including the proliferation of further plastics and micro-plastics, which is an issue of utmost urgency. And issue a final message to the Commission to heed our call, and put all already existing policy and strategy formulation bodies related to the blue economy under one Authority. It is only when we have real coordination that we can reap the benefits of a proper blue economy.

name: Elena Gentile (S&D)
text: in writing. As shadow rapporteur for the Group of the Party of European People's Party (European Democratic And Rural Development) on the opinion that the EMPL Committee gave to the ITRE Committee, I shared from the outset the need to take full advantage of all the opportunities offered by the 'blue economy', in order to contribute to the sustainable use of marine resources and to stimulate growth and employment in the EU, through the creation of quality jobs in sectors such as fisheries. , aquaculture, maritime transport, seabed research, biotechnology, tourism, as well as all the activities that can be carried out on land such as recreational boating, processing industries and integrated inland development, promoting the social integration of vulnerable groups and women, taking into account the environmental risks arising from all sources of pollution.  However, in order to transform the potential of the blue economy into real development opportunities, the Commission must put in place actions aimed at making access to credit and public funding more accessible for SMEs, promoting the mobility and qualification of the workforce and supporting activities related to sustainable and responsible fishing practice. Finally, a balance must be sought between the often underestimated economic, social and environmental dimension of the sustainable integrated maritime policy.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D)
text: In writing. First of all, I would like to commend the Commission for having put the blue economy on the European agenda with determination. The prospect of 1.6 million jobs in this sector is a powerful motivator. Yet there are persistent obstacles to the development of the maritime economy. Against the scientific gaps, the lack of data on the oceans and the urgency of making them accessible, we will be a tireless support for the Commission. We also support it when it identifies the needs of ocean researchers, although we find it useful to add that training must cover all skill levels, including sailors, technicians and engineers. On the other hand, like the opinion of which I am the rapporteur, we are proposing two amendments. The first is the completeness of the List of Activities drawn up by the Commission. Renewable marine energy, new propulsion for the ships of the future, fishing selectivity and marine biotechnology, the list should not be closed. The ecological transition can find one of its best vectors here. There's still funding. While the Commission merely sums up the budgetary programmes to which the blue economy can claim, we believe that there will be no real stimulus without a budget line specifically dedicated to maritimes.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Michaela Šojdrová, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, on promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training (2015/2006(INI)) (A8-0239/2015).

name: Michaela Šojdrová
text: Rapporteur. – Ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to present to you the report Promoting Youth Entrepreneurship through education and training.  The preparation of this report has focused on a lot of knowledge from education systems and the business environment and leads to a clear conclusion: "Entrepreneurial skills need to be required, they can be taught and they can be learned. It is useful for individuals and for society." 225 amendments were tabled to the original report, so the report has attracted a lot of interest and is the result of very good cooperation with the rapporteurs of all the groups, to whom I also thank. With this report, the European Parliament is responding to high youth unemployment, which in some regions is up to 50%. While the Institutions of the European Union have repeatedly paid attention to promoting youth entrepreneurship. However, this report is the only one that deals with this issue on its own. We agreed, among other things, that young people need a sense of initiative and entrepreneurship. We emphasize the social dimension of entrepreneurship. Our report highlights the role of non-formal and informal education, which is the domain of the non-profit sector in particular, exceptionally also companies, and needs to be recognised and supported. The report details the definition of entrepreneurial skills and their teaching opportunities. The European Parliament confirms that a 'sense of initiative and entrepreneurship' is one of the key competences for lifelong learning. It includes, but is not limited to, creativity, the ability to introduce news, bear risks, financial and media literacy, plan and manage projects. The report places the main emphasis on the role of the European Commission and the Council and calls for better use of the instruments they have. This resolution is a major challenge for the European Commission. Due to the proactive approach of DG EAC to date, we would like to set specific dates and tasks. For example, for the Commission to strengthen support for entrepreneurship education as one of the objectives of erasmus+ for the next financial period after 2020 and to include these skills in the mandatory content of training programmes. From 2016, the European Commission should include education-related measures in this area in the indicators for the evaluation of the European Semester. It should then submit a report on best practices in this area by the end of 2017. We are aware that the Member States are not waiting for this resolution, but are already working to develop entrepreneurial skills themselves, albeit very diversely and insufficiently systematically. That is why the European Parliament also mentions measures for them that can help, for example in the form of start-ups, advice, facilitating access to loans, using crowdfunding or partnerships between businesses and universities, supporting business incubators and, above all, linking teaching to practice. The european social fund, the Youth Employment Initiative, the European Union Programme for Employment and Social Innovation, Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs and others will be the source for financing these activities. As teachers have a key role to play, we call on the Member States to initiate improvements in their training already in the framework of pedagogical study programmes. The European Parliament sees support for youth entrepreneurship through education as very promising, so we ask the Commission to present an evaluation report on the progress made in this area by the end of this parliamentary term. Once again, I thank my colleagues for their cooperation, and I believe that the measures we are proposing will help to improve the quality of education and improve employment. After all, business makes a profit. Both for entrepreneurs, i.e. for individuals and employees, and therefore for the whole company.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE).
text: – Madam President, Commissioner, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. I congratulate Mrs Šojdrová on her report, which raises important issues relating to the promotion of youth employment in the European Union. I would like to draw attention to one important aspect – namely the promotion of the development of the social economy and its important role in combating social exclusion, especially with regard to young people. Such companies not only generate revenue and drive the European economy, but also support the development of a civil society that is committed and sensitive to the needs of others. Many young people want work to be not only their passion, but also socially useful.  I therefore believe that building European social capital – from volunteering based on young people's knowledge and skills to valuable traineeships to international exchange programmes for students and young entrepreneurs – should be an important element in promoting entrepreneurship. These actions will certainly ensure the forward-looking development of the European Community.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I am pleased that the Commissioner is also here, and I believe that this is a commitment that we also entrust to the Commission, in cooperation with Parliament. I have to thank Mrs Šojdrová, she did a great job and we all worked very well together. I believe that to say, as we say all the time, that Europe needs more entrepreneurs, more innovation, creativity and more growth for small and medium-sized enterprises, is also achieved through the orientation of school curricula and opportunities for partnerships at school, university sites, with the business system, but also in education for the development of the entrepreneurial mindset and the central role that teacher training has in this field.  I think it is also a great instrument, as has been said, in favour of new employment: one in two young people in Europe, between the age of 15 and 25, says that they would prefer self-employment, but often there are no conditions for creating these skills. These are transversal competences, which serve not only to set up a company, but also serve to address the skills we call 'citizenship' skills, but I believe that it is very necessary to qualify teachers and to have a stronger alliance on this issue, including with European employers' associations.

name: Krzysztof Hetman (PPE).
text: – Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for his excellent work. Last year I organised a conference in Lublin – my hometown – for young people, which aimed, among other things, to encourage them to start their own business. As a result of this discussion with young people, I have made sure that the factor holding back them from developing this business is not the lack of good ideas or entrepreneurial spirit: they really have a lot of cool ideas. Rather, the question of the lack of financial barriers or unawareness of how to overcome these barriers is a bigger problem. I am therefore of the opinion that we need to put more emphasis on the information campaign on the tools available in this respect – such as the European Social Fund, the microfinance instrument and many other EU programmes, such as 'Business Angels'.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, some of the challenges in this report are common to all Member States in Europe, while other vary from one Member State to another. I will talk a little bit about the situation in the United Kingdom. We actually have a very good quality education system in the UK but quite often we educate in the wrong way, in the wrong things. We push almost half of all young people to go to university but actually, in fact, there are not that many graduate—level jobs available. We need to be doing more of this kind of thing: we need to be promoting entrepreneurship, we need to be promoting the kind of skills, the kind of training, that are going to develop young people in the right direction.  Paragraph 43 of this report urges the Commission to ensure nothing impedes the free movement of workers, but often that does impact on young people and takes young people away from employment when it allows older people coming into the country the opportunity to take advantage and compete for the same jobs, and they often win.

name: Ева Паунова (PPE).
text: – Madam President, the key words in this report are, in my view, three: the first is education, because business sense is a quality that needs to be built from a young age. The number of young entrepreneurs and business leaders can be repeatedly increased if the education system educates innovative, creative and critical thinking. The second word is digitization, because digital skills are necessary for the realization of every entrepreneur and young person. They improve their access to sustainable jobs, help them to be self-employed and teach them to better understand the needs of their future employers. And the third word is business, because large corporations can support small companies and new projects through know-how and experience, and we here, our job is to create the most suitable environment for entrepreneurship development. It is therefore absolutely important that traineeship, entrepreneurship training and programming are part of any training from an early age in all European countries.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President. I wish first to thank the rapporteur, Ms Šojdrová, for her very successful report, for the valuable points and concrete proposals she makes on a topic of increasing relevance. It is not the first time that you, the Parliament, and the Commission have discussed this topic, and my impression is that the discussion has reached a level of maturity that will enable substantial progress. We are no longer wondering whether entrepreneurship can be taught or not: whether a classroom is a proper place to do it. No, those questions are now obsolete, and we should focus on how to improve and increase the teaching of entrepreneurship in educational institutions, including schools, and how to reach a critical mass of pupils. One crucial point captured in the report is that learning entrepreneurship is not only about setting up a business: far from it. It is about bringing education and work closer, acquiring crucial skills, and most importantly acquiring values – a sense of initiative, creativity, teamwork, resilience, the ability to learn from mistakes, and self-confidence, among others. With still unacceptably high levels of youth unemployment in the EU, teaching and spreading entrepreneurship is definitely part of the solution to reduce the skills mismatch. Let me also mention the social dimension of entrepreneurship. Entrepreneurship is not only for the few highly qualified students. On the contrary, it is a powerful tool that can help address social exclusion.  As I said, this is not the first time we have spoken about entrepreneurship, and we must acknowledge that substantial progress has been accomplished in the last few years. This is well reflected in the Council conclusions of 12 December 2014 on entrepreneurship in education. The Commission has also put in place several policies to support and develop entrepreneurial skills in schools, as well as in further education and lifelong learning. Let me name a few.  First of all, the European Institute of Innovation and Technology (EIIT) has pioneered the integration of entrepreneurship education in the higher education curriculum. Students of the EIIT’s knowledge and innovation communities follow entrepreneurship and innovation-related courses in addition to their scientific education. Secondly, in line with the recommendation of the report, the Commission will continue to successfully upscale and support the HEInnovate initiative, which the Commission and the OECD launched together in 2013 to support higher education institutions in developing to become more entrepreneurial and innovative. As of today, we have some 500 European higher education institutions that have used the initiative voluntarily, and the number keeps growing. Do you know that, thanks to Erasmus placements, 55 000 students, one in five, benefitted from traineeships in enterprises in 2013; that the Commission supports knowledge alliances which are cooperation projects between businesses and higher education institutions; or that the Commission launched a project on creating companies in 20 different schools across five Member States? I will stop here because the list is long and I am not here to describe what the Commission has done, but rather to think about the way forward: supporting Member States in improving and extending the teaching of entrepreneurship throughout the EU. The first challenge to be met, and this is well reflected in the report, concerns ICT skills, a crucial sector in today’s economies, especially for youngsters. We must find ways to exploit the possibilities as effectively as possible for the benefit of young Europeans. The second challenge is the recognition of entrepreneurship skills. Assessing and certifying them at European level in order to allow mobility is of the essence. Pilot projects exist but, once again, we must reach a critical mass and make sure that entrepreneurial skills are increasingly recognised in curricula and throughout Member States. Honourable Members, I think we are on a good track. The Commission already supports Member States’ expanding and improving the teaching of entrepreneurship in schools and universities, but still more can and should be done. I hope, together with my colleagues Commissioners Bieńkovska and Thyssen, to improve on these encouraging results in the coming years. Allow me to finish by acknowledging the key role of the several NGOs and enterprises – vibrant civil-society operators – who are playing a crucial role and enabling remarkable progress to be made in this field.
