text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – Firstly, I would like to thank Mrs Michaela Šojdrová for her high-quality and comprehensive report on promoting young people's entrepreneurship through education and training. I appreciate your work. A high youth unemployment rate in the European Union remains a pressing problem, with an average youth unemployment rate of 22% in the EU and more than 50% in some countries and regions. confidently become part of today's knowledge-based economy and society. Entrepreneurship at all levels (basic, intermediate and high level) is a very effective tool for motivating young people and making decisions about starting their own businesses and careers and succeeding in this career. I believe that, in today's Europe, there is a great need for an approach that supports young people, for example in terms of their creativity, risk-taking capacity, failure management and responsible behaviour. Thank you very much for your attention.

name: Viorica Dăncilă (S&D)
text: in writing. – Currently, the youth unemployment rate in the European Union is more than 20% – double the unemployment rate for all age groups combined and almost 3 times higher than those over 25. The European Union promotes entrepreneurship through the Europe 2020 strategy and its flagship initiatives on 'New Skills and Jobs', 'A Digital Agenda for Europe', 'Innovation Union' and 'Youth on the Move'. Young people have the capacity to significantly influence the direction that the workforce in Europe will take in the years to come. I believe that the European Union, together with the Member States, must support young people to develop professionally and believe in their strength to generate change and contribute to the smart, sustainable and inclusive growth that the Europe 2020 strategy proposes.

name: Isabella De Monte (S&D)
text: in writing. The European Parliament's motion for a resolution on the promotion of entrepreneurship in young people through education and training deals with an issue of great interest to the growth policies that we have been pursuing in recent years. In fact, the economic and financial crisis has left the European continent with major imbalances within it, one of the most significant of which is youth unemployment.  For this reason, a joint effort is needed between European and national policies to support the education and university education of young people in order to increase their social inclusion. More than four and a half million young unemployed people are unacceptable, and therefore an entrepreneurial fabric of motivated young people, who pay particular attention to innovation and research, is a key to returning to growth, reducing unemployment. In this motion for a resolution, particular emphasis is made on the fundamental characteristics of entrepreneurship to be developed, such as creativity, innovation, the identification of opportunities and autonomy of thought, as key factors in building an active network of young enterprises, especially in the field of social entrepreneurship. Finally, the importance of promoting female entrepreneurship in order to enhance fundamental talents and skills to stimulate growth in Europe is underlined.

name: Damian Drăghici (S&D)
text: in writing. – As shadow rapporteur, I believe that this report is an important one, which must be an integral part of the European Union's strategy to support the younger generation for growth, employment, education and social integration. However, as a result of the very high rate of youth unemployment, they still face increased levels of poverty and social exclusion, especially those belonging to disadvantaged and vulnerable groups. The report makes it clear that disadvantaged groups need special attention and support throughout education, through the involvement of parents and communities in the educational process, as well as help to start, run or develop a business or enterprise. I supported the idea that non-formal and informal learning activities are of particular relevance to young people with fewer opportunities, giving them additional learning opportunities for their integration into the formal education and training system. I believe that The Member States must continue to develop systems for the recognition and validation of skills acquired in non-formal and informal learning in order to give young people the opportunity for reorientation and a second chance, but also to encourage self-recognition and further learning.

name: Ilhan Kyuchyuk (ALDE)
text: in writing. – I would like to express my support for the report on ‘Promoting youth entrepreneurship through education and training’. I am convinced that in order to promote youth entrepreneurship, we should start from education. Investing in all levels of education, in training and in developing transversal and soft skills is essential, because being entrepreneurial requires acquisition of different skills – not just to start a business, but also to plan it, run it and develop it.  Being entrepreneurial also helps us achieve sustainable employment and reveal our full potential. Entrepreneurial education develops a sense of initiative which will help young people with their own initiatives and their everyday life – NOT only for their companies and associations.  I do realise that youth entrepreneurship cannot completely solve the youth unemployment problem, but it is definitely one of the solutions, especially acknowledging that having an entrepreneurial mind-set is highly beneficial for the development of the creative sector, something that Europe very much needs in order to get back to growth and strengthen Europe’s competitiveness.  To encourage, help and support youth entrepreneurship we need a sustainable approach – we cannot achieve that with a single instrument. It requires sustainable, purposeful, long-term actions. I am happy that in this report we managed to set our clear direction.

name: Victor Negrescu (S&D)
text: in writing. – Youth entrepreneurship can be a future solution for increasing European competitiveness, but also for solving, at least in part, the problem of unemployment in Europe. As a former entrepreneur, I believe that education and training are central to a young person's ability to develop a business. Often, young people with very good ideas fail to implement their wishes, given the lack of information or managerial capabilities. The education system across Europe must be adapted to the new economic context and develop entrepreneurship among young people. This requires training for teachers, but also an adaptation of the curriculum so that entrepreneurship activities are developed. Last but not least, European funds must support youth entrepreneurship by supporting the training component, but also advising young entrepreneurs through whom Europe can take pride in a strong network of SMEs.

name: Андрей Новаков (PPE)
text: in writing. – Faith in young people and their potential makes me a defender of the idea of youth employment through entrepreneurship.  If you want to fly a plane, you can't do it in the classroom by reading a textbook – it requires many hours of hard work and practical training. Similarly, in order to become an entrepreneur and go the way from idea to successful product, you need to rely on practical experience and learn from the best entrepreneurs. And because young people value concrete proposals, not just words, I have two ideas: First of all, why not turn Erasmus for Young Entrepreneurs into a global programme opening up opportunities beyond the EU's borders. Let our young entrepreneurs learn from the best and bring this model here in Europe. Second, put an end to unpaid internships in Europe. Traineeships, practices and trainings are a shortcut to gaining experience, but around 50% of traineeships offered in the EU are unpaid. It's discrimination - if you can't afford it, you don't have an internship. Often unpaid or low-paid trainees have responsibilities on an equal footing with employees, and every job must be paid for.  Let us show the young that Europe means action in their interests and that is what is expected of us in this chamber.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Mircea Diaconu, on behalf of the Committee on Culture and Education, towards an integrated approach to cultural heritage for Europe (2014/2149(INI)) (A8-0207/2015).

name: Mircea Diaconu
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, the report I am now presenting is trying to convince policy makers of the importance of cultural heritage and the opportunities that this sector can create for both professionals in the field and for communities. This importance stems from the very title - "An integrated approach", says the title of this report. "Integrated" means that practically the cultural component exists in almost any subject that we can develop in everyday life in any public debate. Here are some points i would like to highlight for starters. We call for the early designation of a European year dedicated to cultural heritage with a budget to match. We then ask the European Commission to better organise information on the financing of cultural heritage, to establish a single portal at European Union level dedicated to cultural heritage. Let us stop hiding, please, behind the fact that all information is available on the Internet. The cruel reality is that the cultural field has an acute need for funding in all Member States and we must help cultural operators to use all the European funds to which they are entitled. Another important step we need to take is to remove from the FDR Regulation the threshold of five million euros set for cultural heritage projects. We have been fighting for the removal of this threshold, which has been set totally artificially, and our report is very clear on this subject. I therefore ask the European Commission not to ignore the voice of the citizens who have asked us for help in removing this threshold. Another crack identified by our report is the lack of an adequate quality control system for heritage projects. A project to restore a heritage site is not just a simple invoice listing. The moment we pour concrete over a medieval fresco, it doesn't matter that the financial audit was perfectly fine, covered with bills. That is why our report calls for mandatory mentions of the quality of restoration work to be included in the Rules of European Programmes. We can destroy with European funds what they have not destroyed for thousands of years of weather or war.  Because I arrived here with regret, I must remember only for a moment about the monstrous attack on the ancient city of Palmyra. There is only an ancient city in the wilderness; is an ancient city, a world heritage wonder, and a spring with both thermal water. There can be no other interests: there is no oil, there is no population, there is nothing. It's nothing, it's just deserted... And yet, some criminals have so cruelly attacked this exact place. Simple: because it's about global cultural memory. And I say this because it was recently voted on the proposal of the Chairman of the Committee on Culture, Mrs Silvia Costa, who is present in the plenary of Parliament, a resolution which considers this type of acts of destruction of the world cultural heritage as crimes against humanity. It's about murder.  Now, finally, I regret to say to you that, at least in my opinion, recent assessments of risk areas in the vicinity of the European Union have created an aberrant, dangerous, explosive situation. These assessments took into account political, geopolitical, military, probably economic, etc. criteria and no cultural criteria. I mean by that there is a risk that today's so-called refugee crisis, of huge, unexpected, explosive migration on the European Union, will hide in it another possible crisis, which may be a cultural crisis, of clashing cultures. I hope I am not right, I expect an appropriate and timely response from the European Commission. Thank you and I await your vote tomorrow.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Madam President, for me Europe is synonymous with culture and cultural heritage and I believe that Europe should be and remain the guardian of the entire European cultural heritage. I come from a country, Cyprus, whose cultural and religious treasures, of priceless and untold value, have been looted for forty-one years and are currently being trafficked, in the hands of smugglers, even within Europe itself. Cyprus is part of the European cultural and religious heritage. It is rightly called the Island of Saints. Thousands of churches, thousands of monuments, thousands of years of religious and antiquities culture have been destroyed and have become a commodity within Europe itself. When you steal an Antiquities Museum, you commit a crime. When you culturally destroy a country, you commit, in my opinion, a crime of sedation. I expect the Commission, to which I have addressed many times, to take measures and to establish a legislative framework for the automatic repatriation of antiquities moving in Europe. There should be no other victim countries as Cyprus has been - and I am thinking of Palmyra in Syria now - neither in Europe nor in other parts of the world.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Diaconu very much for his excellent report, for the great commitment he has put in; has really grasped a fundamental theme. That is why we wanted to follow up the Commission's communication with a report by Parliament, mr Commissioner, which means asking the Commission and the Council to continue this effort to relaunch the theme of cultural heritage, which is an axis of development, an axis of new employment, an axis of new form of intervention also with regard to investment and also , of course, it has a symbolic value that does not escape anyone.  Unfortunately, it was the tragic events that reminded us in the 10th anniversary of the UNESCO Convention on Cultural Diversity, which we will honour in committee on 15 September, that cultural heritage is a good thing for humanity. It is important to take up the important guidelines that come from the report, in particular with regard to an integrated approach, transversal to all policies, and also that brings together public and private actors, because resources are also the big issue on heritage.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, on the occasion of the debate on the integrated approach to Europe's cultural heritage, I would like to remind the House once again that, during the Second World War, Nazi occupying troops looted the archaeological treasures of my country, Greece. In fact, the list of associated archaeological treasures is contained both in the special volume issued in 1946 by the Greek Ministry of Education and in the corresponding special report prepared by the British Ministry of War. In accordance with Directive 93/7/EEC concerning the return to their place of origin of stolen archaeological treasures and in accordance with the 1970 UNESCO Unidroit Convention, the repatriation of cultural goods is envisaged. Therefore, Commissioner, I am putting to you again the issue that I raised with you a year ago, during the debate on your candidacy for the post of Commissioner. Do you have an answer, Commissioner, as to the return of nazi archaeological treasures to Greece?

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Madam President, they say that America will be one big shopping center, Asia factory, Africa tourist destination, and Europa museum in a hundred or more years. This is what futurists say, in good faith, showing that our material and intangible cultural heritage is invaluable. That's why I only want to underline one thing. Let's just look at what culture means for European tourism and with that we have already said everything. How much of the economy is there, exactly? How long is our identity here? That is why I support the European capitals project, but I suggest that the Commission also consider that we may also have regions as a cultural destination. That is, that we have an annual region of culture as we have a capital of culture.

name: Ernest Maragall (Verts/ALE).
text: – Madam President, talking about cultural heritage while we are contemplating the destruction of Palmyra impotently is at least a terrible paradox. May it at least help Europe become aware of what is at stake. The title of the report is very explicit: 'Towards an integrated approach to European cultural heritage', with a very clear, very coherent axis. Strategies, knowledge, resources, conservation lines, lines of action, lines of action must also be integrated, as has been said, of repatriation. Let us be clear, what this report tells us is that, if we want to talk about Europe in the future, we must start by respecting our own history, knowing it, showing it and giving it the European value precisely that always accompanies, always, the genuine cultural, religious, social or economic personality of a place, a space, a given culture. We are therefore in the right direction and that is why the report calls for both the availability of a single European portal that integrates and coordinates the scattered actions and the recognition of regions and cities as indispensable actors for this joint European strategy.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, the Commission would like to thank the rapporteur Mr Diaconu and the shadow rapporteurs for the quality and the comprehensiveness of his report. The report covers the full breadth of cultural heritage, making a wide spectrum of policy recommendations and suggesting next steps to be taken. The Commission shares the report’s view that supporting, enhancing and promoting cultural heritage through an integrated approach is of paramount importance.  In addition to its intrinsic value, cultural heritage contributes significantly to economic and social development and it touches the lives of all Europeans, nurturing their sense of belonging and strengthening their European identity.  As we speak, heritage is unfortunately the target of acts of vandalism, defacement and even destruction, as we can see in the terrible images of destruction in Iraq and Syria. But there are also other, less violent, threats to heritage. We are so used to our surrounding historic environment that we may forget that such a fragile beauty needs a lot of care to survive. The report will help the Commission to fine-tune the existing instruments and to make further progress on putting into practice tools, policies and mechanisms in an integrated way to address the challenges the heritage sector is facing today.  The Commission has already taken action on many of the spheres of action mentioned in the report. The Commission has started to work with the Member States on participatory governance. In 2016-2017 this work will be continued on heritage skills, training and knowledge transfer. The Commission is also promoting peer learning among cities and regions to support the exchange and transfer of the wealth of experience and good cultural practices, including heritage. The Commission will also continue to enhance internal cooperation and availability of information on financing opportunities within the existing European funding programmes. If I might just respond to the honourable Member’s observations: unfortunately, my answer is the same as it was during my hearing. The Commission has no powers to handle debates between two Member States and historic debates. We have simply no powers for that; these are bilateral conflicts and bilateral discussions.

text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: Writing. – I thank my colleague Diacon for presenting the report, which I consider to be very good, and I am glad that we unanimously supported it in committee. The new integrated approach to cultural heritage covers a number of aspects, often neglected, such as the need to support both tangible – i.e. monuments and intangible cultural heritage – folklore or theatre. The report is also a good message that culture is extremely important not only for our identity or leisure, but also for the economy and education. I would just like to emphasise these aspects. Cultural heritage is a source of growth and should be understood and promoted in this way. Cultural monuments attract tourists, and if they are alive with their content, they can serve great for educating younger generations. The report also wisely addresses the financial support of culture, where it calls, among other things, for breaking the ceiling of projects in order to better invest in cultural facilities. The exchange of best practices or the promotion of cultural workers' mobility are highlighted. I am glad that I was able to make a major contribution to it as shadow rapporteur and I appreciate the excellent cooperation with the rapporteur and other colleagues. I look forward to the report being adopted tomorrow and becoming the text on which the next debate and practical steps in promoting European culture will be unfolded.

name: Bogdan Brunon Wenta (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – I would like to congratulate Mr Diacon and all those who, in this report, have proposed a number of effective solutions for the protection of Europe's common cultural heritage. I support the report's initiative to set up an EU portal on this heritage, which provides information on EU cultural funding programmes. I would like to emphasise the importance of film heritage as an important part of Europe's cultural heritage, including the need to digitise European films, especially since only 1.5% of it has been subjected to it. It is also important to introduce film education at all levels of teaching from an early age, which would enable young viewers to enjoy the media critically and to better understand the content offered to the public. Parliament's adoption of my report on European film in the digital age is a good example of the fact that European cinematography and the need to digitise our film heritage is an important aspect of protecting European identity and common cultural heritage.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the report by Lynn Boylan, on behalf of the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Food Safety, on the follow-up to the European Citizens’ Initiative Right2Water (2014/2239(INI)) (A8-0228/2015).

name: Lynn Boylan
text: rapporteur. – Madam President. The Right2Water European Citizens’ Initiative (ECI) was the first successful example of this democratic mechanism and it reached almost double the minimum requirements with a staggering 1.8 million signatures. It is clear that the human right to water is an issue of great importance for citizens across Europe. Ownership and management of water services are clearly key concerns for citizens and cannot be ignored.  In my home country, Ireland, which you will be familiar with yourself, Madam President, the introduction of flat-rate regressive charges has resulted in some of the largest protests the country has ever seen. Given that Ireland previously had what was considered one of the most progressive forms of paying for water, through general taxation, this anger is understandable. Irish people should not have to submit to an unjust double taxation, which will also affect the poor the hardest. In spite of the unparalleled success of this ECI, the official response of the Commission was vague, disappointing and did not properly address the demands of the Right2Water campaign. The response lacked ambition and ignored the key demands of Right2Water. In this report I have tried to better answer the citizens who are still waiting for proper action from the EU. It is pitiful that the Commission had not come forward with legislative proposals enshrining water as a human right and a legal requirement across the European Union. This was a key demand of the Right2Water ECI and it has been roundly ignored by the Commission so far.  I have called on it in this report to rectify the situation. I have recognised that the provision of water services is a natural monopoly, where competition amongst private operators has not worked, does not work and will never work. Water is a public good and should never be commodified. Profits should not be made on public goods such as water. All revenues must be reinvested into improving infrastructure of water service and not go to shareholders or executives’ pay. It is critical that the Commission respect the Member States’ right to organise their water services as they see fit.  Indeed, across the world, we have experienced a growing rise in the re—municipalisation of water services. In other words, water services previously run by private companies are being brought back under public management due to the abject failures of privatisation in the water sector.  I would like to express my thanks for the support from the Right2Water campaign itself and the support of MEPs in the more progressive Groups, but I am extremely disappointed with the EPP Group, which along with the ECR has produced an alternative resolution which strips the strong and progressive aspects from my report.  I can see that they have worked very hard to disguise their sham, but if anyone reads the two reports it is clear where their ambitions lie. They have worked wormholes through the report to weaken it beyond any recognition. Gone is any criticism of the Commission’s failure to respond to the campaign. Gone is the call for the human right to water to be enshrined in legislation, and gone is any criticism of the privatisation of water services. They have removed the call for the Commission to remain neutral on the question of ownership and not to promote privatisation of water services. Indeed the whole motion is very private-sector-friendly, so much so that the original call for water services to be removed from TTIP is completely missing. They have deleted so many positive aspects of the report that it has gone from 37 pages to a 9-page document which reads more like an EPP position paper supported by the Tories than an honest response to the almost 2 million citizens who signed this ECI. It is a dishonest attempt to gag the voices of those who campaigned for the human right to water. Given that this was meant to be Parliament’s opportunity to respond to the Right2Water ECI it will reflect incredibly poorly on us as the supposed voice of European citizens if this alternative motion is passed, which is not supported by the Right2Water campaign. The ECI was meant to show citizens that the EU is willing to re-engage with them on matters which are important to them. If this alternative motion passes, then the ECI is dead in the water.

name: Ivan Jakovčić (ALDE).
text: – Mr. President, Istria, a small European region in the west of Croatia, is perhaps the best example of how public water supply can meet the needs of citizens and the right to water. And indeed, basic, elementary, the human right is the right to water. In one relatively rural region, we managed to get 99.4% of the population to have public water supply, drinking water. This is primarily thanks to the solidarity of citizens and the public local and regional sectors. That is why I am not, regardless of belonging to the ALDE group, to privatise the water supply system at all costs. In fact, on the contrary, it has been shown that water is something that every citizen is entitled to, and in this context I significantly advocate that water and water management be as publicly owned as possible, because it is a guarantee that then every citizen will also have the right to water.

name: Claude Turmes (Verts/ALE).
text: Madam President, I would like to thank the president for her Almost 2 million citizens in Europe have signed this call for water as a public good. In Europe, water should not be exposed to liberalisation, privatisation and competition, so that is not to organise corporations, but to organise municipal utilities. And thirdly, water should also be kept out of trade agreements, precisely in order to prevent corporations from dictating water management in third world countries. I thought we in Parliament had a broad majority to support that. This was also the case in the Committee on the Environment, Public Health and Social Affairs, and I am also very, very sad denunciing the approach of the Conservatives, PPE and ECR to take a quasi-glue approach to corporations and to demand that water management in Europe should also be liberalised, privatised and water also included in TTIP, TISA, CETA – that is, in the international trade agreements. I hope that we will be able to prevent this in the vote tomorrow. Thank you very much!

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, first of all I would like to congratulate the rapporteur on her report which includes everything we were able to discuss at the workshop organised by the SOSTE WATER movement in Thessaloniki last May, where we were invited to participate as speakers. I in turn support the fight against movements and the European citizens' initiative on the right to water and call on the Commission to exclude water services from the ongoing negotiations on TTIB and TiSA. The European Union must abide by the Treaty and stop promoting the privatisation of water companies, in particular, in countries that are in a memorandum, as is the case in Greece with EYATH in Thessaloniki. I support the report and oppose the EPP's amendments which try to weaken the report and the campaign of European citizens. Water is a public good and access to water and sanitation is an inalienable right of every citizen as determined by the UN General Assembly itself.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mrs Boylan for this important report. I come from a country in Italy, where more than 27 million voted for water to remain a common good, to remain public. Yet this referendum has been largely disregarded, not considered. Well, I would not like the law, the proposal for a popular initiative, the popular initiative of millions of European citizens, to do the same. That is why I am convinced that it is important to support ICE on the right to water and that Lynn Boyan has done a very good job in this direction.  I believe that the Eu ropean Union cannot be further slow in recognising what the UN has already recognised as a human right: the right to drinking water. We are already lagging behind in recognising this as a right in the European Union as well. I would add, for democracy, for the democratic structure of the Union, the Commission has a duty to respect the content of the ECI. I hope that the group, the intergroup of this Parliament on common goods and public services, will also be useful in this direction.

name: Jonathan Arnott (EFDD).
text: – Madam President, I am at a loss for how to vote on this one, because I agree with so much of what the rapporteur says. I agree: water is a human right. I agree that public services must be exempted from the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) – it is something which simply should not be negotiable. I agree that water must be a natural monopoly, personally. I share a lot of the concerns about foreign aid and helping with water supplies in the poorest countries, and we have a Citizens’ Initiative, where over a million-and-a-half citizens in Europe have petitioned – and yet fewer than 15 people are here today to debate it. We have had so much contact from constituents, and I support all that. At the same time, as somebody who is opposed to the European Union in principle, I have concerns about EU money, about nation states’ rights, about the direction of travel for more Europe. I genuinely do not know how I am going to vote on this one.

name: Tibor Navracsics
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like, on behalf of the Commission, to thank the European Parliament, and in particular, Ms Boylan, for the report on the follow-up to the European Citizens’ Initiative ‘Right2Water’. As the Commission has made clear in its response to the initiative, water is not a commercial product like any other, but rather a heritage which must be protected, defended and treated as such. Access to it cannot be taken for granted, although many people in Europe do so. The Commission has always underlined that an important condition for providing access to water is the preservation and protection of water resources. This is a cornerstone of EU environment policy. The EU directives on drinking water and urban wastewater treatment, as well as the Water Framework Directive, set the standards for water and sanitation and provide the basis for integrated water resource management. As your report states, globally, access to water and sanitation is a global issue of huge importance. Fifteen years on from the UN Millennium Declaration, the statistics are still challenging: 748 million people still do not have access to safe drinking water and 2.5 billion people lack access to basic levels of sanitation. Therefore I welcome Sustainable Development Goal 6, which aims to ensure availability and sustainable management of water and sanitation for all. The SDGs are at the core of the post-2015 agenda. The EU stands ready to play its full part in its implementation, both through its external action as well as its internal policies and actions, and I hope that we will be able to gather momentum with all partners to achieve universal access in the not too distant future. I wish to reaffirm the Commission’s position on the importance of the human rights dimension of access to safe drinking water and sanitation, including within the EU itself. Firstly, the Commission recognises the importance of water as a public good. The provision of water services is in general the responsibility of the local authorities, as they are closest to the citizens. Secondly, the Commission has clarified the principle of neutrality. Treaty rules require the EU to remain neutral in relation to national decisions governing the ownership regime for water undertakings, be it public or private. Moreover, EU rules on concessions acknowledge the specificity of water. Works and services concerning drinking water and sanitation have been excluded from the scope of the Concessions Directive, and the subsidiarity principle regarding the choice of method of water management has been fully recognised. This also applies to trade deals. No EU trade deal has ever restricted EU Member States’ freedom to organise their public services – including water – the way they choose. TTIP – the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership – will be no different. Thirdly, I re-confirm the Commission’s commitment to a number of actions which will ensure that these principles remain at the heart of its policies, and I welcome the emphasis placed in the committee’s report on the importance of Member States implementing EU legislation. The Commission will build on existing legislation and policies to continue to increase and improve access to safe drinking water and sanitation for the whole population through environmental policies and infrastructure funding. Let me now emphasise again the positive impact the Citizens’ Initiative has had on putting water issues high on the political agenda. We welcome your numerous calls on the Commission for action. The Commission is carefully considering them in the context of a number of actions, for example in the evaluation of the Drinking Water Directive, the preparation of the Water Re-use Initiative and the upcoming review of the Water Framework Directive, and the ongoing dialogue with the stakeholders – including the initiators of the Citizens’ Initiative – on benchmarking water quality and services. To conclude, I would like to add an important element. EU water policies and activities over the past decades have allowed access to adequate sanitation and drinking water services for the large majority of EU citizens. Challenges remain. Member States play a big role in the implementation of EU legislation, while further targeted action by the Commission is under way. We all have to play together in ensuring full compliance with EU water legislation, thus helping to ensure access to clean water and sanitation for all citizens throughout the EU. We welcome the strong support and additional calls from this House for more ambitious action, in particular to involve citizens and to provide more transparency. Also, the call for access to safe drinking water and sanitation is much welcomed and will be taken into account in future Commission work. As regards the European Citizens’ Initiative tool itself, I am pleased to note that this major innovation introduced by the Lisbon Treaty is now up and running and involving citizens more closely in EU agenda-setting. However, there is still clearly room for improvement. In the report on the application of Regulation No 211/2011 on the Citizens’ Initiative published on 31 March 2015, the Commission took stock of this situation after three years of application. The report identified a number of issues in the current functioning of the instrument as a basis for further discussion and reflection on how to improve it. The Commission is now awaiting input from stakeholders, in particular the own initiative report of the European Parliament on ECI. This report will feed into the Commission’s analysis on how to improve the functioning of the European Citizens’ Initiative and make the tool as effective as possible. The Commission is looking forward to further cooperation with Parliament on both these important issues: the follow-up of the Right2Water initiative and the evolution of the tool.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Tuesday, 8 September 2015. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D)
text: in writing. Right2Water is the first European citizens' initiative which, with its two million signatures, has reached the minimum threshold to be officially submitted to the European Commission. These numbers are sufficient to make us understand how much the subject is felt by the citizens of Europe. It is precisely for this reason that much more was expected from the Commission's communication, which is disappointing and une ambitious, but does not respond to the specific requests made by the initiative.  That is why this Parliament has an obligation to urge the European Commission to respond in practice to the concerns raised by the citizens. The Commission must work as a matter of priority on a revision of the Water Framework Directive that recognises universal access and the human right to water, just as universal access to safe drinking water and sanitation should be recognised in the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  Furthermore, we must be united in saying that water and sewerage services, as services of general interest, should be excluded from the rules of the internal market and from the trade agreements that the EU is currently negotiating, such as TTIP. I very much hope that the Commission will be able to follow up these demands. If it does not do so, the European Union as such will lose credibility in the eyes of its citizens.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D)
text: in writing. – Citizens have said this loud and clear: water is not a commercial good but a public good. The right to water and sanitation is a human right and yet only in the EU more than one million people do not have access to safe and clean drinking water and 2% of the population does not have sanitation services either. In the rest of the world, many millions of people suffer from this inhumane situation. The Commission's response to citizens is disappointing, it does not respond to their demands, which call for new action and the submission of a legislative proposal for the implementation of the human right to water and sanitation as essential public services for all, as recognized by the UN. We Socialists defend the right to water and sanitation of all people, which must be incorporated into the Framework Directive, we are committed to a model of public ownership and control of management, based on water as an undisputed right and not as a commodity, we oppose any attempt to privatize this public good and supply cuts to citizens without economic resources.

name: Jiří Maštálka (GUE/NGL)
text: Writing. – It is important to note the sad fact that at least 748 million people do not have permanent access to safe drinking water and that a third of the world's population does not have basic sanitary and sanitation facilities, which are absolutely alarming facts. As a result of this situation, the fulfilment of the right to health is threatened, there is a spread of diseases that cause suffering and death and significantly hinder development. The sad fact is that 4 000 children die every day from infectious diseases from poor water quality and inadequate sanitation, and 3.5 million people die every year as a result of infectious diseases from water. We need to change this trend. Almost 1.9 million citizens from all EU Member States supported the Right2water citizens' initiative. I hope, while clearly calling on the Commission, in line with the current main objective of the ECI, to put forward adequate legislative proposals in the foreseeable future!

name: Pavel Poc (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Citizens' Initiative is a new participatory democracy mechanism to enable European Union citizens to directly influence and shape the political agenda since 2012. Citizens' Initiative "Water and sanitation are human rights! Water is a public good, not a commodity!", known as Right2Water, received 1.6 million verified signatures from citizens from all EU countries at the time of submission, becoming the first successful European citizens' initiative. In view of this, as well as given the mass movements of citizens in each Member State, the signatories and organisers of the initiative expected an appropriate response from the European Commission. Instead, they received a completely vague answer that lacks any ambition. In particular, the Commission did not put forward any corresponding legislative proposal, which was a key requirement of the Right2Water initiative. The European Parliament has therefore decided to respond with an own-initiative report and to get the Commission to fulfil its commitments. Nevertheless, we are also seeing an effort to weaken this report by presenting an alternative resolution that lacks all the key elements voted on in the ENVI Committee. This alternative resolution is not supported by Right2Water and looks more like an ECR-supported PPE position document. I therefore appeal to all my colleagues in the Czech Republic not to support an alternative PPE resolution, which is not only not in line with what citizens want, but which completely devalues the entire mechanism of the European Citizens' Initiative.

name: Claude Rolin (PPE)
text: In writing. - "Water, a human right" or the theme of a citizens' initiative for which I had been an ambassador in my previous role as Secretary-General of the Confederation of Christian Trade Unions of Belgium. At that time, we had collected close to two million signatures. Two million Europeans who are calling for water to be accessible to all, who are calling for water not to be a commodity. Water is like air, we all need it to live. There is therefore no question of privatizing it. On the contrary, water must be accessible in quality and quantity for all. Prices for the first consumer tranches must be much lower than prices for large consumers. In any case, this citizen initiative is important - important for humanity, but also important in terms of democratic credibility. It is now up to the European Commission to implement what is in this initiative.

name: Daciana Octavia Sârbu (S&D)
text: in writing. – As a co-author of a previous Parliament resolution dealing with the right to water, I fully support the call for legislation to implement the right to water and sanitation. This is a human right as recognised by the United Nations and should be underpinned by the proper legal framework to ensure that it is a reality for everyone. I welcome the Commission’s recognition that water is not a commercial product, but overall I think the Commission’s response to the European Citizens’ Initiative ‘Right2Water’ has been disappointing. Pressure on water resources is growing. In the interests of the environment and human rights, the EU should provide the necessary support to ensure that resources are managed properly and water is accessible and affordable for all.
